Chapter 1 Probability basics

1.1 Probability spaces and a bit of measure theory

Underlying any probabilistic model is a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ), where

  • •

    Ω is the sample space that contains all possible outcomes ω, called elementary events;

  • •

    the event space ℱ⊂2Ω is a collection of subsets of the sample space that we wish to assign a probability to. A set A∈ℱ is called event;

  • •

    ℙ is a probability measure that assigns to each event A∈ℱ a probability ℙ⁢(A)∈[0,1].

Example 1.1.1.

Consider the experiment of throwing a fair coin twice. We model Ω={H⁢H,H⁢T,T⁢H,T⁢T}={ωi:i=1,…,4} and

ℱ=2Ω={ ∅,Ω,{H⁢H},{H⁢T},{T⁢H},{T⁢T},{H⁢H,H⁢T},{H⁢H,T⁢H},{H⁢H,T⁢T},{H⁢T,T⁢H},{H⁢T,T⁢T},
{TH,TT},{HH,HT,TH},{HH,HT,TT},{HH,TH,TT},{HT,TH,TT}}

Since the coin is fair, each of the 4 elementary events {H⁢H},{H⁢T},{T⁢H},{T⁢T} has the same probability, which is given by 1/4, i.e., ℙ⁢({ω})=1/4 for all ω∈Ω. The probability that one of the distinct outcomes H⁢T and T⁢H happens is intuitively obtained by summing up the probabilities, i.e., ℙ⁢({H⁢T,T⁢H})=ℙ⁢({H⁢T})+ℙ⁢({T⁢H})=1/4+1/4=1/2. More generally, for C⊂{1,…,n}, we may set

ℙ⁢({ωi:i∈C})=ℙ⁢(⋃i∈C{ωi})=∑i∈Cℙ⁢({ωi})=|C|/4.

Note however that with this definition, probabilities of unions of events (translates to “at least one of the events happens”) are not always obtained by summing up:

ℙ⁢({H⁢T}∪{H⁢T,T⁢H})=ℙ⁢({H⁢T,T⁢H})=1/2≠3/4=ℙ⁢({H⁢T})+ℙ⁢({H⁢T,T⁢H}).

The reason here: the events are not disjoint! With the above model we can for example identify “heads appears in first throw” with the event {H⁢H,H⁢T}, which has probability 1/2, or “heads appears at least once” with the event {H⁢T,T⁢H,H⁢H}, which has probability 3/4. A reformulation of this would be “tails does not appear twice” and the probability can be expressed as

3/4=1−1/4=1−ℙ⁢(“tails appears twice”)=1−ℙ⁢({T⁢T})=1−ℙ⁢(Ω∖{H⁢T,T⁢H,H⁢H}).

To make these notions mathematically rigorous, we introduce some fundamental concepts from measure theory, where one builds a consistent theory of assigning volumes to sets on general spaces. First we deal with the types of event spaces that we allow for a probability space.

Definition 1.1.2.

ℱ⊂2Ω is called a σ-algebra if all of the following are satisfied:

  1. (i)

    Ω∈ℱ

  2. (ii)

    A∈ℱ⟹Ac≔Ω∖A∈ℱ

  3. (iii)

    (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℱ⟹⋃n∈ℕAn∈ℱ

If ℱ is a σ-algebra over Ω, we call (Ω,ℱ) a measurable space.

Lemma 1.1.3.

Any σ-algebra ℱ has the following properties:

  1. (i)

    ∅∈ℱ

  2. (ii)

    A,B∈ℱ⟹A∪B∈ℱ

  3. (iii)

    A,B∈ℱ⟹A∩B∈ℱ

  4. (iv)

    (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℱ⟹⋂n∈ℕAn∈ℱ

  5. (v)

    A,B∈ℱ⟹A∖B∈ℱ

Proof.

Exercise. ∎

Example 1.1.4.

The simplest examples of σ-algebras are the trivial σ-algebra ℱ={∅,Ω} and the power set ℱ=2Ω (sometimes called discrete σ-algebra).

For uncountable spaces Ω, the power set 2Ω is usually a poor choice because it is simply too big in the sense that we cannot design meaningful measures that consistently assign volumes to all subsets of Ω (look up the Banach–Tarski paradox if you are interested why). Instead, we usually start with a nice family of subsets ℰ of Ω and works with the smallest σ-algebra that contains ℰ.

Definition 1.1.5.

Let ℰ be a family of subsets of Ω. Then σ⁢(ℰ) is defined as the smallest σ-algebra over Ω that contains ℰ, or equivalently,

σ⁢(ℰ)≔⋂ℱ∈𝒜ℱ,

where 𝒜={ℱ⊂2Ω:ℱ⁢ is a ⁢σ⁢-algebra and ⁢ℰ⊂ℱ}. The family ℰ is called a generator of σ⁢(ℰ).

Exercise 1.1.6.

Let Ω be a countable set and ℰ={{ω}:ω∈Ω}. Show that σ⁢(ℰ)=2ℰ.

For our statistical purposes the by far most important σ-algebra is the Borel σ-algebra ℬ⁢(ℝ) over the real numbers ℝ, which is defined as

ℬ⁢(ℝ)≔σ⁢({O⊂ℝ:O⁢ open}),

and we will always implicitly equip ℝ with this σ-algebra when considering it as a measurable space. The Borel σ-algebra has the following simpler characterisation.

Lemma 1.1.7.

All of the following families of sets are generators of ℬ⁢(ℝ):

  1. (i)

    ℰ1={(a,b):−∞<a≤b<∞}

  2. (ii)

    ℰ2={[a,b]:−∞<a≤b<∞}

  3. (iii)

    ℰ3={(a,b]:−∞<a≤b<∞}

  4. (iv)

    ℰ4={(−∞,a):a∈ℝ}

  5. (v)

    ℰ5={(−∞,a]:a∈ℝ}

Proof.

We only prove σ⁢(ℰ1)=ℬ⁢(ℝ), the remaining statements are left as an exercise. Since any open interval (a,b) is open in ℝ we have ℰ1⊂{O⊂ℝ:O⁢ open} and therefore

σ⁢(ℰ1)⊂σ⁢({O⊂ℝ:O⁢ open})=ℬ⁢(ℝ). (1.1)

Conversely, let O⊂ℝ be an arbitrary open set. Recall that O can then be written as a countable union of open intervals, that is, we can find sequences (an)n∈ℕ,(bn)n∈ℕ such that O=⋃n∈ℕ(an,bn). Since (an,bn)∈ℰ1⊂σ⁢(ℰ1) for all n, property (iii) of a σ-algebra implies that

O=⋃n∈ℕ(an,bn)⏟∈σ⁢(ℰ1)∈σ⁢(ℰ1).

Since O was chosen arbitrarily we conclude that

{O⊂ℝ:O⁢ open}⊂σ⁢(ℰ1),

and therefore also

ℬ⁢(ℝ)=σ⁢({O⊂ℝ:O⁢ open})⊂σ⁢(ℰ1). (1.2)

Combining (1.1) and (1.2) gives the result. ∎

Now that we have understood what a σ-algebra is, let us move on to the notion of a probability measure. We start a bit more general.

Definition 1.1.8.

A measure μ on a measurable space (Ω,ℱ) is a function μ:ℱ→[0,∞] that satisfies the following properties:

  1. (i)

    μ⁢(∅)=0

  2. (ii)

    if (An)n∈ℕ is a pairwise disjoint sequence in ℱ, it holds that

    μ⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn)=∑n∈ℕμ⁢(An) (σ-additivity)

The measure μ is called

  1. (i’)

    finite, if μ⁢(Ω)<∞

  2. (ii’)

    σ-finite, if there is a sequence (An)n∈ℕ in ℱ such that Ω=⋃n∈ℕAn and μ⁢(An)<∞ for all n.

Remark 1.1.9.

Note that by taking ∅=An+1=An+2=⋯ it follows from σ-additivity that for any finite, mutually disjoint collection A1,…,An∈ℱ we have μ⁢(A1∪⋯∪An)=∑k=1nμ⁢(Ak).

Definition 1.1.10.

A finite measure ℙ on a measurable space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is called probability measure if ℙ⁢(Ω)=1. The triplet (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is called probability space.

Definition 1.1.11.

A probability distribution (or simply distribution) is a probability measure on (ℝ,ℬ⁢(ℝ)).

Lemma 1.1.12.

Let (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) be a probability space and A,B∈ℱ be arbitrary events. Then,

  1. (i)

    if A⊂B, it holds that ℙ⁢(B∖A)=ℙ⁢(B)−ℙ⁢(A). In particular, ℙ⁢(Ac)=1−ℙ⁢(A).

  2. (ii)

    ℙ⁢(A∪B)=ℙ⁢(A)+ℙ⁢(B)−ℙ⁢(A∩B). In particular, ℙ⁢(A∪B)≤ℙ⁢(A)+ℙ⁢(B).

  3. (iii)

    if A⊂B, it holds that ℙ⁢(A)≤ℙ⁢(B).

Remark 1.1.13.

Analogous statements can be derived whenever we deal more generally with a finite measure μ. For infinite measures we need to be a bit more careful. E.g., while it is always true that μ⁢(A∪B)≤μ⁢(A)+μ⁢(B), we can only make sense of μ⁢(A)+μ⁢(B)−μ⁢(A∩B) if μ⁢(A∩B)<∞, in which case indeed also μ⁢(A∪B)=μ⁢(A)+μ⁢(B)−μ⁢(A∩B).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    A⊂B implies B=A⊎(B∖A), whence by σ-additivity, ℙ⁢(B)=ℙ⁢(B∖A)+ℙ⁢(A), or equivalently, ℙ⁢(B∖A)=ℙ⁢(B)−ℙ⁢(A). Letting B=Ω, we obtain from this

    ℙ⁢(Ac)=ℙ⁢(Ω∖A)=ℙ⁢(Ω)−ℙ⁢(A)=1−ℙ⁢(A).
  2. (ii)

    Let C=A∩B. We can write A∪B=(A∖C)⊎(B∖C)⊎C, which gives (using C⊂A,C⊂B and σ-additivity)

    ℙ⁢(A∪B)=ℙ⁢(A∖C)+ℙ⁢(B∖C)+ℙ⁢(C) =(i)⁢ℙ⁢(A)−ℙ⁢(C)+ℙ⁢(B)−ℙ⁢(C)+ℙ⁢(C)
    =ℙ⁢(A)+ℙ⁢(B)−ℙ⁢(C)
    =ℙ⁢(A)+ℙ⁢(B)−ℙ⁢(A∩B).
  3. (iii)

    immediate from (i) since ℙ⁢(B∖A)≥0.

∎

Lemma 1.1.14 (Continuity of measures).

Let (Ω,ℱ,μ) be a measure space.

  1. (i)

    If (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℱ is an increasing sequence in the sense that An⊂An+1 for all n∈ℕ, then

    μ⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn)=limn→∞μ⁢(An).
  2. (ii)

    If (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℱ is a decreasing sequence in the sense that An⊃An+1 for all n∈ℕ, and moreover μ⁢(A1)<∞, then

    μ⁢(⋂n∈ℕAn)=limn→∞μ⁢(An).
Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Of special interest to us will be the following measures on (ℝ,ℬ⁢(ℝ)), which are in a certain sense on opposite ends of the spectrum. The Lebesgue measure λ is the unique measure that satisfies

λ⁢((a,b])=b−a,−∞<a≤b<∞,

and therefore assigns a volume to any set in ℬ⁢(ℝ) that we would consider as natural based on our physical perception of the world. The Dirac measure δx at a point x∈ℝ is defined as

δx⁢(A)={1,x∈A0,x∉A,

i.e., it is a point mass that assigns unit volume to a measurable set A iff x∈A. In particular we have δx⁢({x})=1=δx⁢(ℝ), so that δx is our first example of a probability measure. Conversely to this, for the Lebesgue measure it holds

λ⁢({x})=λ⁢(⋂n∈ℕ(x−1/n,x+1/n])=limn→∞λ⁢((x−1/n,x+1/n])=limn→∞2n=0.

For the the second equality we used continuity of measures from Lemma 1.1.14. This means that any singleton {x} is a nullset for the Lebesgue measure according to the next definition.

Definition 1.1.15.

Let μ be a measure on some measurable space (Ω,ℱ). A set N∈ℱ such that μ⁢(N)=0 is called a μ-nullset. If some property holds for all ω∈Ω∖N, where N is a μ-nullset, we say that this property holds μ-almost everywhere (μ-a.e.). If μ is a probability measure we say instead μ-almost surely (μ-a.s.).

Exercise 1.1.16.

Show the following:

  1. (i)

    If ℙ1,ℙ2 are probability measures and λ1,λ2≥0, then λ1⁢ℙ1+λ2⁢ℙ2 is a probability measure iff λ1+λ2=1.

  2. (ii)

    For any a,b∈ℝ such that a<b it holds that

    λ⁢([a,b])=λ⁢([a,b))=λ⁢((a,b])=λ⁢((a,b)).
  3. (iii)

    The Lebesgue measure λ is σ-finite but not finite.

1.2 Independence and Conditional Probability

Throughout this section we fix a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ).

Definition 1.2.1 (Independence).

Two events A,B∈ℱ are defined to be independent if

ℙ⁢(A∩B)=ℙ⁢(A)⁢ℙ⁢(B).
Example 1.2.2.

Let the probability space from Example 1.1.1 be given. Consider the events A={H⁢T,H⁢H}≜“heads appears in first throw” and B={H⁢T,T⁢T}≜“tails appears in second throw”. Then

ℙ⁢(A∩B)={H⁢T}=1/4=12⋅12=ℙ⁢({H⁢T,H⁢H})⁢ℙ⁢({H⁢T,T⁢T})=ℙ⁢(A)⁢ℙ⁢(B),

so A and B are independent.

Definition 1.2.3 (Conditional Probability).

Let A∈ℱ s.t. ℙ⁢(A)>0. The conditional probability ℙ(⋅∣A) on (Ω,ℱ) is defined by

ℙ⁢(B∣A)=ℙ⁢(A∩B)ℙ⁢(A),∀B∈ℱ,

and we call ℙ⁢(B∣A) the conditional probability of B given A.

The definition entails that if ℙ⁢(A)>0, an event B∈ℱ is independent of A, iff ℙ⁢(B∣A)=ℙ⁢(B).

Proposition 1.2.4.

The conditional probability ℙ(⋅∣A) is a probability measure on (Ω,ℱ).

Proof.

We need to show that (i) ℙ⁢(∅∣A)=0, (ii) ℙ⁢(Ω∣A)=1 and (iii) for pairwise disjoint events (An)n∈ℕ in ℱ we have ℙ⁢(⋃nAn∣A)=∑nℙ⁢(An∣A). (i) is clear because A∩∅=∅. Since Ω∩A=A, it also follows

ℙ⁢(Ω∣A)=ℙ⁢(Ω∩A)ℙ⁢(A)=ℙ⁢(A)ℙ⁢(A)=1,

which establishes (ii). For (iii), note that we have A∩⋃nAn=⋃n(An∩A) and since (An)n are pairwise disjoint, the same remains true for (An∩A)n. Thus, σ-additivity of ℙ yields

ℙ⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn∣A)=ℙ⁢(⋃n∈ℕ(An∩A))ℙ⁢(A)=∑n∈ℕℙ⁢(An∩A)ℙ⁢(A)=∑n∈ℕℙ⁢(An∣A).

∎

Theorem 1.2.5 (Bayes’ formula).

Let A,B∈ℱ such that ℙ⁢(A),ℙ⁢(B)>0. Then, for any B∈ℱ,

ℙ⁢(B∣A)⏞posterior=ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B)⏞priorℙ⁢(A)=ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B)ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B)+ℙ⁢(A∣Bc)⁢ℙ⁢(Bc).
Proof.

We have ℙ⁢(A∣B)=ℙ⁢(A∩B)/ℙ⁢(B), or equivalently, ℙ⁢(A∩B)=ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B). Plugging this expression for ℙ⁢(A∩B) into ℙ⁢(A∣B)=ℙ⁢(A∩B)/ℙ⁢(B) gives the first stated equality. The second one follows from the first after decomposing A=(A∩B)⊎(A∩Bc), which gives

ℙ⁢(A) =ℙ⁢(A∩B)+ℙ⁢(A∩Bc) (law of total probability)
=ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B)+ℙ⁢(A∣Bc)⁢ℙ⁢(Bc) (partition formula)

∎

Example 1.2.6.

A doping test is performed after a football match. The league is just a little bit crooked this year so that 0.5% of the players are doped. Moreover, the test detects a doped player with 95% accuracy, but is also positive in 1% of the cases when a non-doped player is tested (false positive). Let us calculate the probability that a player has actually doped if the test returns positive: if we let A=“test positive” and B=“player is doped”, then ℙ⁢(B)=0.005, ℙ⁢(A∣B)=0.95 and ℙ⁢(A∣Bc)=0.01. Thus, using Bayes’ formula

ℙ⁢(B∣A⏟“player is doped given that test is positive”)=ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B)ℙ⁢(A∣B)⁢ℙ⁢(B)+ℙ⁢(A∣Bc)⁢ℙ⁢(Bc)=0.95⋅0.0050.95⋅0.005+0.01⋅(1−0.005)=0.952.94≈0.32.

This is why in sports there is always a B-sample taken.

Chapter 2 Random variables

2.1 Random variables and their distributions

2.1.1 Measurability

Definition 2.1.1.

Let (E,𝒜) be a measurable space. A function f:E→ℝ is called measurable if for any A∈ℬ⁢(ℝ) it holds that f−1⁢(A)∈𝒜.

This definition appears rather cumbersome at first sight, since σ-algebras such as ℬ⁢(ℝ) are too complicated to check the measurability condition by hand in most circumstances. Fortunately, we can reduce this often impossible task by just checking the preimage condition for generating sets of the Borel σ-algebra, that is open sets or – even simpler – families of intervals as established in Lemma 1.1.7. The formal statement is the following.

Proposition 2.1.2.

Let (E,𝒜) be a measurable space and let ℰ be a generator of ℬ⁢(ℝ), i.e., ℬ⁢(ℝ)=σ⁢(ℰ). Then, a function f:E→ℝ is measurable if, and only if, f−1⁢(ℰ)⊂𝒜.

Proof.

We skip the proof in the lecture. The proof is however quite enlightening, as it contains a powerful idea that is commonly applied in measure theory. I highly recommend to have a look at it in Appendix A. ∎

Example 2.1.3.
  1. (i)

    Let (E,𝒜) be a measurable space and define the indicator function of a set A∈𝒜 as

    𝟏A:E→ℝ,x↦{1,x∈A,0,x∉A.

    For any set B∈ℬ⁢(ℝ) we have

    𝟏A−1⁢(B)={x∈E:𝟏A⁢(x)∈B}={A,1∈B,0∉B,Ac,0∈B,1∉B,E,0,1∈B∅,0,1∉B,

    which shows 𝟏A−1⁢(B)∈𝒜 ⟹ 𝟏A is measurable.

  2. (ii)

    Any continuous function f:ℝ→ℝ is measurable: Let O⊂ℝ be open. By continuity f−1⁢(O) is open as well and since ℬ⁢(ℝ) is generated by open sets, this shows that f−1⁢(O)∈ℬ⁢(ℝ). By Proposition 2.1.2 this is sufficient to prove measurability.

Measurable functions are well-behaved under the usual analytic manipulations. We just record here a couple of important properties properties without proof (if you would like to try to prove some of these, Proposition 2.1.2 is very helpful).

Lemma 2.1.4.

Let (E,𝒜) be a measurable space.

  1. (i)

    If f,g are measurable functions on (E,𝒜), then f+g and f⋅g are also measurable.

  2. (ii)

    If f:E→ℝ and g:ℝ→ℝ are measurable, so is there composition g∘f.

  3. (iii)

    Let (fn)n∈ℕ be a sequence of measurable functions mapping from E to ℝ such that there exists a function f:E→ℝ for which the pointwise convergence limn→∞fn⁢(x)=f⁢(x) holds for any x∈E. Then, f is measurable.

2.1.2 Definition of random variables and their distributions

Definition 2.1.5.

A random variable on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is a measurable mapping X:Ω→ℝ, i.e., X−1⁢(A)∈ℱ for any A∈ℬ⁢(ℝ).

Remark 2.1.6.

In the following we will use the notation {X∈A}≔X−1⁢(A), which is motivated from the definition of the preimage X−1⁢(A)={ω∈Ω:X⁢(ω)∈A}. A random variable is therefore a mapping from the sample space Ω into the real numbers such that for any measurable set A in ℝ the preimage {X∈A} is a proper event on the probability space.

Since random variables are nothing else but measurable mappings in the context of probability spaces, we may recast Lemma 2.1.4 probabilistically.

Lemma 2.1.7.

Let (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) be a probability space.

  1. (i)

    If X,Y are random variables, then also X+Y and X⋅Y are random variables.

  2. (ii)

    If X is a random variable and g:ℝ→ℝ is measurable, then Y=g⁢(X) is also a random variable.

  3. (iii)

    Let (Xn)n∈ℕ be a sequence of random variables such that there exists X:Ω→ℝ for which the pointwise convergence limn→∞Xn⁢(ω)=X⁢(ω) holds for any ω∈Ω. Then, X is also a random variable.

Definition 2.1.8.

The distribution ℙX:ℬ⁢(ℝ)→[0,1] of a random variable X on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is defined by

ℙX⁢(B)=ℙ⁢(X−1⁢(B)),B∈ℬ⁢(ℝ).
Remark 2.1.9.

Analogously to before, we write interchangeably

ℙX⁢(B)=ℙ⁢(X−1⁢(B))=ℙ⁢({X∈B})=ℙ⁢(X∈B).

For an interval [a,b] we also write ℙ⁢(X∈[a,b])=ℙ⁢(a≤X≤b) with analogous conventions for open and half-open intervals. We also use the shorthand ℙ⁢(X∈(−∞,x])=ℙ⁢(X≤x) and write ℙ⁢(X∈A,X∈B)=ℙ⁢({X∈A}∩{X∈B}), ℙ⁢({X∈A}∣{X∈B})=ℙ⁢(X∈A∣X∈B) for A,B∈ℬ⁢(ℝ).

Theorem 2.1.10.

Let X be a random variable on (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). Its distribution ℙX is a probability measure on (ℝ,ℬ⁢(ℝ)).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    ℙX⁢(∅)=ℙ⁢(X−1⁢(∅))=ℙ⁢(∅)=0.

  2. (ii)

    ℙX⁢(ℝ)=ℙ⁢(X−1⁢(ℝ))=ℙ⁢(Ω)=1.

  3. (iii)

    It is easily checked that for a pairwise disjoint sequence (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℬ⁢(ℝ), the sequence (X−1⁢(An))n∈ℕ is also disjoint and by measurability of X it is a sequence in ℱ. Consequently,

    ℙX⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn) =ℙ⁢(X−1⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn))
    =ℙ⁢(⋃n∈ℕX−1⁢(An))
    =∑n∈ℕℙ⁢(X−1⁢(An))
    =∑n∈ℕℙX⁢(An),

    where we used σ-additivity of ℙ for the third line.

∎

Definition 2.1.11.

A random variable X is called discrete if there exists N∈ℕ∪{∞}, weights p1,…,pN≥0 and points x1,…,xN∈ℝ (both interpreted as sequences if N=∞) such that ∑k=1Npk=1 and

ℙX=∑k=1Npk⁢δxk.

We call

fX⁢(x)=ℙX⁢({x})=ℙ⁢(X=x)=∑k=1Npk⁢𝟏{xk}⁢(x),x∈ℝ,

either the discrete density function or probability mass function (pmf).

Example 2.1.12.

Consider a simple coin toss with probability of heads equal to p∈[0,1]. We may model Ω={H,T},ℱ=2Ω={{H},{T},{H,T},∅} and ℙ⁢({H})=p and then set X⁢(H)=1, X⁢(T)=0. The corresponding distribution ℙX can then be written as

ℙX=p⁢δ0+(1−p)⁢δ1,

and we call ℙX a Bernoulli distribution with success rate p. Alternatively, we can start with ℙX as above and use it as a distributional model for the coin toss experiment with random outcome X directly, without specifying the underlying probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ).111Note here that if we start with a distribution ℙX on (ℝ,ℬ⁢(ℝ)), we can always construct a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) and a random variable X:Ω→ℝ such that ℙX is the distribution of X. Indeed, we may simply set Ω=ℝ,ℱ=ℬ⁢(ℝ),ℙ=ℙX and X⁢(ω)=ω for all ω∈ℝ. This is referred to as the canonical construction. The latter modelling approach is particularly useful in situations, where a random phenomenon is far too complex to allow an explicit construction of the underlying probability space (think of a stock price for example) and is therefore the appropriate one for our statistical purposes.

Definition 2.1.13.

The distribution function FX:ℝ→[0,1] of a random variable X on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is defined by

FX⁢(x)=ℙX⁢((−∞,x])=ℙ⁢(X≤x),x∈ℝ.
Remark 2.1.14.

Distribution functions are often also called cumulative distributions functions, abbreviated as cdf; we shall use this abbreviation from here on.

Exercise 2.1.15.
  1. (i)

    Sketch the cdf from Example 2.1.12 for p=1/4.

  2. (ii)

    Show that ℙ⁢(X∈(a,b])=F⁢(b)−F⁢(a) for all a<b.

Distribution functions play a special role because they are much simpler objects compared to distributions (function vs. measure), but are sufficient to fully characterise the distribution.

Theorem 2.1.16.

Let ℙX and ℙY be two distributions. Then, ℙX=ℙY (that is, ℙX⁢(B)=ℙY⁢(B) for all B∈ℬ(ℝ)) if, and only if, FX=FY (that is, FX⁢(x)=FY⁢(x) for all x∈ℝ).

Proof (Sketch).

Generally, the following can be shown to be true: If ℙ, ℚ are two probability measures with underlying σ-algebra ℱ generated by a ∩-stable family of sets ℰ, i.e., ℱ=σ⁢(ℰ) and A∩B∈ℰ if A,B∈ℰ, then ℙ=ℚ iff ℙ⁢(B)=ℚ⁢(B) for all B∈ℰ. Here, we have ℬ⁢(ℝ)=σ⁢(ℰ) for ℰ={(∞,x]:x∈ℝ}, see Lemma 1.1.7, and ℰ is ∩-stable since (−∞,x]∩(−∞,y]=(−∞,x∧y]. Hence, ℙX=ℙY iff

∀x∈ℝ:ℙX⁢((−∞,x])⏟=FX⁢(x)=ℙY⁢((−∞,x])⏟=FY⁢(x).

∎

Proposition 2.1.17 (Properties of a cdf).

A cdf FX has the following properties

  1. (i)

    x↦FX⁢(x) is non-decreasing;

  2. (ii)

    limx→−∞FX⁢(x)=0 and limx→∞FX⁢(x)=1;

  3. (iii)

    x↦FX⁢(x) is right-continuous with left limits, i.e., for any a∈ℝ, limx↑aF⁢(x) exists and limx↓aFX⁢(x)=F⁢(a).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    For x<y we have (−∞,x]⊂(−∞,y] and hence by Lemma 1.1.12 FX⁢(x)=ℙX⁢((−∞,x])≤ℙX⁢((−∞,y])=F⁢(y).

  2. (ii)

    By the just established monotonicity and boundedness of FX, both limits exist and it is enough to check limn→∞FX⁢(−n)=0 and limn→∞FX⁢(n)=1. We only show the first claim, the second is left as an exercise: ((−∞,−n])n∈ℕ is a decreasing sequence, so continuity of measures from Lemma 1.1.14 gives

    limn→∞FX⁢(−n)=ℙX⁢(⋂n∈ℕ(−∞,−n])=ℙX⁢(∅)=0.
  3. (iii)

    Existence of left limits is a consequence of FX being increasing and bounded. Right-continuity can again be proven with continuity of measures (try it!).

∎

2.2 Continuous distributions and a very short sketch of integration theory

In Definition 2.1.11 we have already encountered discrete distributions that place probability mass on single points only. In undergrad probability modules you will also have encountered continuous distributions, which are defined via the cdf as follows: a random variable X is continuous if its cdf is given by

FX⁢(x)=∫−∞xf⁢(y)⁢dy

for a probability density function f:ℝ→ℝ, which is nice enough for the above integral to be well-defined as a Riemann integral. This gives rise to formulas such as

ℙ⁢(a≤X≤b)=∫abf⁢(y)⁢dy=∫[a,b]f⁢(y)⁢dy,

so that we are tempted to define the corresponding distribution as

ℙX⁢(B)=∫Bf⁢(y)⁢dy,B∈ℬ⁢(ℝ).

However, the meaning of such an integral in the sense of Riemann is unclear if the set B is not as nice as an interval (say B=ℚ). We therefore need a different notion of an integral, which is the Lebesgue integral.

2.2.1 Lebesgue integral

We let (E,𝒜,μ) again be a general space. Integrals are supposed to calculate volumes or areas enclosed by functions. We have already interpreted μ⁢(A) as the volume of a set A∈𝒜, which may be interpreted as well as an integral of the indicator 𝟏A w.r.t. the measure μ. So, given some scalar α≥0 it is natural for the function

f⁢(x)=α⁢𝟏A⁢(x),x∈A,

to assign the scaled volume α⁢μ⁢(A) as an integral, that is we define

∫Ef⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x)≔α⁢μ⁢(A).

Moreover, integrals should be linear, so for any simple function of the form

f⁢(x)≔∑k=1nαk⁢𝟏Ak⁢(x)⏟fk⁢(x),x∈E,

for some n∈ℕ, α1,…,αn≥0, and A1,…,An∈𝒜 pairwise disjoint, we define

∫Ef⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x)≔∑k=1nαk⁢μ⁢(Ak)=∑k=1n∫Efk⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x).

To extend the notion of the Lebesgue integral for simple functions to more general function classes, we use the following fundamental result.

Theorem 2.2.1.

For any non-negative, measurable function f:E→ℝ, there exists an increasing sequence of simple functions (fn)n∈ℕ such that we have the pointwise convergence

∀x∈E:limn→∞fn⁢(x)=f⁢(x).
Proof.

Let

fn⁢(x)≔∑k=0n⁢2n−1k2n⁢𝟏f−1([k2n,k+12n)⏟∈𝒜)⁢(x)+n⁢𝟏f−1⁢([n,∞))⏟∈𝒜⁢(x),x∈ℝ.

Then fn is simple and for any x∈ℝ it clearly holds that fn⁢(x)→f⁢(x) as n→∞. Moreover, if x∈f−1⁢([k⁢2−n,(k+1)⁢2−n)), for some k≤n⁢2n−1, then fn⁢(x)=k⁢2−n≤f⁢(x) and similarly, fn⁢(x)=n≤f⁢(x) for x∈f−1⁢([n,∞)). Thus, fn≤f. Finally, it follows from

[k⁢2−n,(k+1)⁢2−n)=⨄l=2⁢k2⁢k+1[l⁢2−(n+1),(l+1)⁢2−(n+1)),[n,n+1)=⨄l=2⁢(n+1)⁢(2n−1)(n+1)⁢2n+1−1[l⁢2−(n+1),(l+1)⁢2−(n+1))

that fn≤fn+1 as desired. ∎

Remark 2.2.2.

We call a sequence of simple functions as above an approximating sequence.

With this result and the intuitive definition of the Lebesgue integral for simple functions, we now define the general Lebesgue integral for any measurable function by taking limits. To this end, we let f+⁢(x)=max⁡{f⁢(x),0} be the positive part and f−⁢(x)=max⁡{−f⁢(x),0} be the negative part of a function f. Note that f=f+−f− and |f|=f++f−. Moreover, if f is measurable, so are f+ and f− and therefore also |f|.

Definition 2.2.3.

Let f:E→ℝ be a non-negative measurable function and (fn)n∈ℕ be an approximating sequence of simple functions. The Lebesgue integral of f is defined by

∫Ef⁢dμ≡∫Ef⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x)≔limn→∞∫Efn⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x).

We call a measurable function f:E→ℝ μ-integrable if ∫E|f|⁢dμ<∞ and define the Lebesgue integral of an integrable function by

∫Ef⁢dμ=∫Ef+⁢dμ−∫Ef−⁢dμ.
Remark 2.2.4.
  1. (i)

    It can be shown that if (fn)n and (gn)n are two approximating functions of a non-negative measurable function f, then limn→∞∫Efn⁢dμ=limn→∞∫Egn⁢dμ, so that the Lebesgue integral is well-defined.

  2. (ii)

    We will use the notation ∫Af⁢dμ≔∫Ef⁢𝟏A⁢dμ.

  3. (iii)

    If μ=λ is the Lebesgue measure, we usually write ∫Af⁢(x)⁢dλ⁢(x)=∫Af⁢(x)⁢dx.

Next, we state some important properties of the Lebesgue integral. We omit the proof but the strategy is always the same: first establish the desired statement for simple functions, then show it for non-negative measurable functions by taking limits and conclude for μ-integrable functions by decomposing into positive and negative parts.

Proposition 2.2.5.

Suppose that f,g:E→ℝ are μ-integrable.

  1. (i)

    Linearity: for any α,β∈ℝ, the function α⁢f+β⁢g is μ-integrable and

    ∫E(α⁢f+β⁢g)⁢dμ=α⁢∫Ef⁢dμ+β⁢∫Eg⁢dμ.
  2. (ii)

    Monotonicity: if f≤g μ-a.e., then

    ∫Ef⁢dμ≤∫Eg⁢dμ.
  3. (iii)

    Triangle inequality:

    |∫Ef⁢dμ|≤∫E|f|⁢dμ.
  4. (iv)

    If μ⁢(N)=0 then ∫Nf⁢dμ=0.

In many situations it is desirable to switch the order of integration and taking limits and the next two powerful results identify situations where this is allowed.

Theorem 2.2.6 (Monotone convergence).

Let (fn)n∈ℕ be an increasing sequence of measurable non-negative functions converging μ-a.e.  to a function f:E→ℝ, i.e., 0≤f1≤f2≤⋯⁢fn≤⋯ and limn→∞fn=f, μ-a.e. Then,

limn→∞∫Efn⁢dμ=∫Ef⁢dμ. (2.1)
Exercise 2.2.7.

Use continuity of measures to show (2.1) for the special case fn=𝟏An, An∈𝒜, and An⊂An+1 for any n∈ℕ.

Theorem 2.2.8 (Dominated convergence).

Let f,f1,f2,… be μ-integrable functions such that

  1. (i)

    limn→∞fn=f μ-a.e. and

  2. (ii)

    there exists some non-negative μ-integrable function g s.t. |fn|≤g μ-a.e. for any n∈ℕ,

Then,

limn→∞∫Efn⁢dμ=∫Ef⁢dμ.

2.2.2 Absolutely continuous distributions

With these preparations we can now finally construct continuous distributions.

Proposition 2.2.9 (Change of measure).

Let μ be a measure on (E,𝒜) and f:E→ℝ be a non-negative measurable function such that ∫Ef⁢dμ=1. Then, the set function ν defined by

ν⁢(B)≔∫Bf⁢dμ,B∈𝒜,

is a probability measure on (E,𝒜).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    ν⁢(∅)=∫∅f⁢dμ=∫f⁢𝟏∅⏟≡0⁢dμ=0.

  2. (ii)

    ν⁢(E)=∫Ef⁢dμ=1 by assumption.

  3. (iii)

    Let (An)n⊂𝒜 be pairwise disjoint. Then ∑n=1N𝟏An=𝟏⋃n=1NAn for all N∈ℕ∪{∞} and 0≤f⁢∑k=1n𝟏Ak≤f⁢∑k=1n+1𝟏Ak≤f. Thus,

    ν⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn) =∫Ef⁢𝟏⋃n∈ℕAn⁢dμ
    =∫Ef⁢limn→∞∑k=1n𝟏Ak⁢d⁢μ
    =limn→∞∫Ef⁢∑k=1n𝟏Ak⁢d⁢μ
    =limn→∞∫E∑k=1nf⁢𝟏Ak⁢d⁢μ
    =limn→∞∑k=1n∫Ef⁢𝟏Ak⁢dμ
    =∑n=1∞∫Ef⁢𝟏An⁢dμ
    =∑n=1∞μ⁢(An),

    where we used monotone convergence for the third and linearity for the fifth equality.

∎

Definition 2.2.10.

Let X be a random variable with distribution ℙX that is given by ℙX⁢(B)=∫Bf⁢dμ for a measure μ on (ℝ,ℬ⁢(ℝ)) and a non-negative measurable function f:ℝ→ℝ such that ∫f⁢dμ=1. Then we say that ℙX is absolutely continuous w.r.t. μ (denoted ℙX≪μ) and call f its μ-density. If μ=λ is the Lebesgue measure, we say that ℙX is absolutely continuous and that X is a continuous random variable. We then call f the probability density function (pdf) of ℙX. Generally, we call any non-negative measurable function f such that ∫ℝf⁢(x)⁢dx=1 a pdf and specify its associated distribution by ℬ⁢(ℝ)∋B↦∫Bf⁢(x)⁢dx.

Remark 2.2.11.

If ℙX≪μ we also say that μ dominates ℙX. The density is often symbolically written as f=d⁢ℙXd⁢μ (because then ℙX⁢(B)=∫Bd⁢ℙXd⁢μ⁢dμ) and called the Radon–Nikodym derivative of ℙX w.r.t. μ.

Exercise 2.2.12.

Let X be a continuous random variable. Show that ℙX⁢({x})=0 for every x∈ℝ. Deduce from this that FX is a continuous function.

2.3 Expectation of (transformed) random variables

Introducing the Lebesgue integral in the previous section now also allows us to define the expectation of a random variable. Throughout this section we fix a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) and implicitly understand all random variables to be defined there upon.

Definition 2.3.1.

Let X be a random variable that is either non-negative or ℙ-integrable. The expectation of X is defined by

𝔼⁢[X]=∫ΩX⁢dP.

Since the expectation is just a Lebesgue integral w.r.t. ℙ, we can recast Proposition 2.2.5 probabilistically.

Corollary 2.3.2.

Suppose that X,Y are ℙ-integrable random variables.

  1. (i)

    Linearity: for any α,β∈ℝ, α⁢X+β⁢Y is ℙ-integrable and 𝔼⁢[α⁢X+β⁢Y]=α⁢𝔼⁢[X]+β⁢𝔼⁢[Y].

  2. (ii)

    Monotonicity: if X≤Y, ℙ-a.s., then

    𝔼⁢[X]≤𝔼⁢[Y].
  3. (iii)

    Triangle inequality:

    |𝔼⁢[X]|≤𝔼⁢[|X|].
  4. (iv)

    If X=Y ℙ-a.s., then 𝔼⁢[X]=𝔼⁢[Y].

Recall that if g:ℝ→ℝ is measurable, Y=g⁢(X) is also a random variable, so that the expectation 𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)] is well defined provided g is non-negative or ∫Ω|g⁢(X)|⁢dℙ<∞. To see how to calculate an expected value, let us first look at the case g=𝟏A for some A∈ℬ⁢(ℝ). Then,

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[𝟏A⁢(X)]=∫Ω𝟏A⁢(X)⁢dℙ=∫Ω𝟏{X∈A}⁢dℙ=ℙ⁢(X∈A)=ℙX⁢(A)=∫ℝ𝟏A⁢dℙX=∫ℝg⁢dℙX, (2.2)

by the definition of the integral for simple functions. As it turns out, this result is generally true.

Theorem 2.3.3 (Transformation theorem for random variables).

Let X be a random variable and g:ℝ→ℝ be a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that ∫ℝ|g|⁢dℙX<∞. Then,

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]=∫ℝg⁢dℙX.
Proof.

Consider first the case that g=∑k=1nαk⁢𝟏Ak is a simple function. Then, using (2.2) and linearity it follows

∫ℝg⁢dℙX=∑k=1nαk⁢∫ℝ𝟏Ak⁢dℙX=∑k=1nαk⁢𝔼⁢[𝟏Ak⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[∑k=1nαk⁢𝟏Ak⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)].

Next, let g≥0 be measurable and let (gn)n∈ℕ be an approximating sequence of simple functions (recall: increasing and converges pointwise to g. Then also (gn⁢(X))n∈ℕ increasing sequence of measurable functions on Ω and limn→∞gn⁢(X)=g⁢(X)). From above, 𝔼⁢[gn⁢(X)]=∫ℝgn⁢dℙX and therefore, applying monotone convergence twice

∫ℝg⁢dℙX=∫ℝlimn→∞gn⁢d⁢ℙX=limn→∞∫ℝgn⁢dℙX=limn→∞𝔼⁢[gn⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)].

Finally, suppose that g is measurable and ∫ℝ|g|⁢dℙX<∞. We have just shown that

∫ℝ|g|⁢dℙX=∫Ω|g⁢(X)|⁢dℙ,

so that g⁢(X) is ℙ-integrable. Consequently, the above yields

∫ℝg⁢dℙX=∫ℝg+⁢dℙX−∫ℝg−⁢dℙX=𝔼⁢[g+⁢(X)]−𝔼⁢[g−⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]

as claimed. ∎

As a consequence, the expectations of transformations of a random variable X do not depend on the underlying probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ), but can be entirely expressed in terms of the distribution ℙX. This is particularly handy for modelling and explains why in statistics we wish to draw inference on ℙX for a given sample of random variables following this distribution. The above observation also motivates the following definition.

Definition 2.3.4.
  1. (i)

    Let X and Y be two random variables (not necessarily defined on the same probability space). We say that they are equal in distribution if ℙX=ℙY and denote this by X⁢=𝑑⁢Y.

  2. (ii)

    If ν is some distribution, we write X∼ν if ℙX=ν. If ℙX is absolutely continuous with density f, we simply write X∼f.

Remark 2.3.5.

Since distribution functions uniquely characterise the distribution, we have X⁢=𝑑⁢Y iff FX=FY.

Theorem 2.3.6 (Calculation rules).
  1. 1.

    Let X be a continuous random variable with pdf f. Let g:ℝ→ℝ be a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that ∫ℝ|g⁢(x)|⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx<∞. It then holds that

    𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]=∫ℝg⁢(x)⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx.
  2. 2.

    Let X be a discrete random variable with discrete density function f=∑k=1Npk⁢𝟏{xk} for some N∈ℕ∪{∞}, pk≥0, xk∈ℝ. Let also g:ℝ→ℝ be a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that ∑k=1N|g⁢(xk)|⁢pk<∞. It then holds that

    𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]=∑k=1Ng⁢(xk)⁢pk=∑k=1Ng⁢(xk)⁢ℙ⁢(X=xk).
Remark 2.3.7.

In particular, for the expectation of X we get 𝔼⁢[X]=∫ℝx⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx and ∑k=1Nxk⁢pk, respectively, provided integral and sum are well-defined.

Proof.

By Theorem 2.3.3 it suffices to show

∫ℝg⁢dℙX={∫ℝg⁢(x)⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx,X⁢ continuous,𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]=∑k=1Ng⁢(xk)⁢pk,X⁢ discrete.

This can be proved analogously to Theorem 2.3.3: (1) show the statement for simple g using linearity and the definition of ℙX; (2) extend to non-negative measurable functions via monotone convergence; (3) use (2) to show it for g satisfying the integrability criteria by splitting g=g+−g−. We leave the details to you. ∎

You may still be concerned about the expression ∫ℝf⁢(x)⁢g⁢(x)⁢dx: the notation looks quite inviting as it reminds us of the (improper) Riemann integral ∫−∞∞f⁢(x)⁢g⁢(x)⁢dx, which you have learned to calculate for many different choices of f,g. Fortunately, under mild assumptions (that will always be satisfied in any example/exercise of the module!) the integrals coincide and you can calculate as usual.

Theorem 2.3.8.

Let X be a continuous random variable with pdf f that is piecewise continuous. Let g:ℝ→ℝ be a also a piecewise continuous function that is either non-negative or such that ∫−∞∞|g⁢(x)|⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx<∞ (read as a Riemann integral). It then holds that

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X)]=∫−∞∞g⁢(x)⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx=limn→∞∫−nnf⁢(x)⁢g⁢(x)⁢dx.
Exercise 2.3.9.

Let λ>0 and fλ:ℝ→ℝ be given by

fλ⁢(x)=λ⁢e−λ⁢x⁢𝟏[0,∞)⁢(x),x∈ℝ.
  1. (i)

    Show that ∫ℝfλ⁢(x)⁢dx=1 and for any k∈ℕ, ∫ℝ|x|k⁢fλ⁢(x)⁢dx<∞.

  2. (ii)

    Let X be a random variable with pdf fλ as above. Show that FX⁢(x)=(1−e−λ⁢x)⁢𝟏[0,∞)⁢(x), 𝔼⁢[X]=1/λ and 𝔼⁢[X2]=2/λ2.

Exercise 2.3.10.

Let X be a continuous random variable with continuous pdf f. Show that FX′⁢(x)=f⁢(x) for all x∈ℝ.

2.4 Moments and moment generating functions

We finish this chapter with some important transformations that are particularly important in statistics.

Definition 2.4.1.

The variance Var⁡(X) of a random variable X such that 𝔼⁢[|X|2]<∞ is defined by

Var⁡(X)≔𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X])2].

The standard deviation is defined by

σX≔Var⁡(X).

We first note that the variance is well-defined because 𝔼⁢[|X|2]<∞ implies 𝔼⁢[|X|]<∞. This follows from the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality for random variables.

Theorem 2.4.2.

Let X,Y be two random variables on (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). Then,

𝔼⁢[|X⁢Y|]≤(𝔼⁢[X2])1/2⁢(𝔼⁢[Y2])1/2. (Cauchy–Schwarz inequality)

More generally, it holds for any p,q≥1 s.t. 1/p+1/q=1 that

𝔼⁢[|X⁢Y|]≤(𝔼⁢[Xp])1/p⁢(𝔼⁢[Yq])1/q. (Hölder inequality)
Lemma 2.4.3.

Suppose that 𝔼⁢[|X|2]<∞. Then,

Var⁡(X)=𝔼⁢[X2]−𝔼⁢[X]2.
Proof.

By integrability we can use linearity of the expectation and calculate as follows:

𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X])2]=𝔼⁢[X2−2⁢X⁢𝔼⁢[X]−𝔼⁢[X]2]=𝔼⁢[X2]−2⁢𝔼⁢[X⁢𝔼⁢[X]]⏟=𝔼⁢[X]⁢𝔼⁢[X]+𝔼⁢[𝔼⁢[X]2]⏟=𝔼⁢[X]2=𝔼⁢[X2]−𝔼⁢[X]2.

∎

Exercise 2.4.4.

Suppose that 𝔼⁢[|X|2]<∞. Show that for any a∈ℝ, we have Var⁡(a⁢X)=a2⁢Var⁡(X) and Var⁡(X+a)=Var⁡(X).

The variance is a quantity that roughly encodes how much a random variable X fluctuates around its mean 𝔼⁢[X]. To underline this point we need a fundamental integral inequality that in spite of its simplicity is of fundamental value in statistics.

Theorem 2.4.5 (Markov’s inequality).

Let X be a random variable and φ:[0,∞)→[0,∞) be a non-negative, non-decreasing and measurable function such that φ⁢((0,∞))⊂(0,∞). Then, for any t>0 it holds that

ℙ⁢(|X|≥t)≤𝔼⁢[φ⁢(|X|)]φ⁢(t).
Proof.

Since φ is increasing we have

∀ω∈Ω:|X⁢(ω)|≥t⟹φ⁢(|X⁢(ω)|)≥φ⁢(t)

and therefore

{|X|≥t}⊂{φ⁢(|X|)≥φ⁢(t)}. (2.3)

Note also that

𝟏{φ⁢(|X|)≥φ⁢(t)}≤𝟏{φ(|X∥)≥φ(t)}⁢φ⁢(|X|)φ⁢(t). (2.4)

We therefore obtain

ℙ⁢(|X|≥t)⁢≤(⁢2.3⁢)⁢ℙ⁢(φ⁢(|X|)≥φ⁢(t)) =𝔼⁢[𝟏{φ(|X∥)≥φ(t)}]
≤(⁢2.4⁢)⁢𝔼⁢[𝟏{φ(|X∥)≥φ(t)}⁢φ⁢(|X|)φ⁢(t)]
≤𝔼⁢[φ⁢(|X|)φ⁢(t)]
=𝔼⁢[φ⁢(|X|)]φ⁢(t),

where for the second and third inequality we used monotonicity of the expectation, cf. Corollary 2.3.2. ∎

Corollary 2.4.6 (Chebyshev’s inequality).

For any random variable X such that 𝔼⁢[X2]<∞ it holds that

ℙ⁢(|X−𝔼⁢[X]|≥t)≤Var⁡(X)t2,t>0.

In particular, we have

ℙ⁢(|X−𝔼⁢[X]σX|≥t)≤1t2,t>0.
Remark 2.4.7.

We call (X−𝔼⁢[X])/σX the standardisation of a random variable X.

Proof.

Exercise! ∎

Definition 2.4.8.

Let k∈ℕ. If 𝔼⁢[|X|k]<∞, we define the k-th moment of X as

μk′⁢(X)≔𝔼⁢[Xk],

and the k-th centered moment of X as

μk⁢(X)≔𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X])k].

We have already encountered the second centered moment as the variance of X. The third and and fourth centered moment also yield quantities with specific names:

  • •

    Skewness: μ3σX3=𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X]σX)3]. Indicates graphically whether a density is left-leaning (skewness positive) or right-leaning (skewness negative).

  • •

    Kurtosis: μ4σX4=𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X]σX)4]. By comparing it to kurtosis of a normal density (see next chapter) used to indicate how heavy the tails of the distribution are, i.e. how likely it is to observe outliers in a sample.

Definition 2.4.9.

The moment generating function (mgf) of a random variable X or a distribution ℙX is defined as

ψX⁢(t)≔𝔼⁢[et⁢X]=∫ℝet⁢x⁢dℙX⁢(x),t∈ℝ.

We say that the mgf exists at ∈ℝ, if ψX⁢(t)<∞.

The name originates from the fact that for a random variable, whose mgf around the origin, all moments can be derived from differentiation of the mgf.

Theorem 2.4.10.

Suppose that ψX exists on (−h,h) for some h>0. Then, we have for any n∈ℕ,

𝔼⁢[Xn]=dnd⁢tn⁢ψX⁢(t)|t=0.
Proof (Sketch).

It holds that

dnd⁢tn⁢et⁢X=Xn⁢et⁢X.

So, supposing that we may switch the order of differentiation and integration on (−h,h), it follows that

dnd⁢tn⁢ψX⁢(t)=dnd⁢tn⁢𝔼⁢[et⁢X]=𝔼⁢[dnd⁢tn⁢et⁢X]=𝔼⁢[Xn⁢et⁢X],t∈(−h,h),

which gives the result by plugging in t=0. The fact that pulling the derivative inside the expectation is allowed can be proven by dominated convergence. ∎

We have already seen that the distribution function FX uniquely characterises ℙX. The same holds true for the moment generating function, provided it exists. The proof is unfortunately out of scope of this lecture.

Theorem 2.4.11.

Suppose that X,Y are random variables such that their mgfs ψX,ψY exist on some open interval (−h,h), h>0. Then,

X⁢=𝑑⁢Y⇔ψX=ψY⁢ on ⁢(−h,h).
Exercise 2.4.12.

Let fλ be the density from Exercise 2.3.9 and X∼fλ.

  1. (i)

    Show that ψX⁢(t) exists iff t<λ and calculate ψX for these values.

  2. (ii)

    Deduce from (i) that 𝔼⁢[Xn]=n!λn.

2.5 P-values and quantiles

Here we get to know two important summary statistics of a random variable X that will be of central importance in our discussion of hypothesis testing later in the lecture. The situation is the following: suppose we are given a test statistic X and we want to check whether the hypothesis X∼P0 is plausible for some given distribution P0 with associated cdf F0. There are different ways to approach this problem:

  1. 1.

    Check whether the observed realization X⁢(ω) is suspiciously small by calculating P0⁢((−∞,X⁢(ω)])=F0⁢(X).

  2. 2.

    Check whether the observed realization X⁢(ω) is suspiciously large by calculating P0⁢([X⁢(ω),∞))=1−F0⁢(X⁢(ω)−).

  3. 3.

    Check both simultaneously by calculating 2⁢min⁡{F0⁢(X⁢(ω)),1−F0⁢(X⁢(ω)−)}.

This motivates the definition of the p-value.

Definition 2.5.1 (p-value).

Suppose that X is a random variable on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ0) such that X∼P0 under ℙ0.

  1. (i)

    The left-sided p-value pl is defined by pl≔F0⁢(X).

  2. (ii)

    The right-sided p-value pr is defined by pr≔1−F0⁢(X−).

  3. (iii)

    The two-sided p-value ps is defined by ps≔2min{F0(X,1−F0(X−)}.

A small p-value always indicates that the hypothesis X∼P0 might not be true. More precisely:

Lemma 2.5.2.

Suppose that X∼P0 under ℙ0. Then, the following are true for any α∈(0,1):

(i)ℙ0⁢(F0⁢(X)≤α)(ii)ℙ0⁢(1−F0⁢(X−)≤α)(iii)ℙ0⁢(2⁢min⁡{F0⁢(X),1−F0⁢(X−)}≤α)}⁢≤α,

with equality if X is continuous.

For the proof we introduce the pseudo-inverse of a distribution function F0 as

q0:(0,1)→ℝ,q0⁢(α)≔inf{x∈ℝ:F0⁢(x)>α}.
Proof.

For simplicity, we only consider the case that X is continuous. From Exercise 2.2.12 we know that then F0 is a continuous function and we claim that

F0⁢(q0⁢(α))=α. (2.5)

Indeed, observe that for any x<q0⁢(α) we have F0⁢(x)≤α, and therefore by continuity of F0,

F0⁢(q0⁢(α))=limx↑q0⁢(α)F⁢(x)≤α.

On the other hand, for x>q0⁢(α) it holds that F0⁢(x)>α and hence by right-continuity

F0⁢(q0⁢(α))=limx↓q0⁢(α)F⁢(x)≥α.

Combining both statements gives (2.5). Let us also show that

x≤q0⁢(α)⇔F0⁢(x)≤F0⁢(q0⁢(α)). (2.6)

Direction ⟹ is clear since F0 is increasing. Conversely, if F0⁢(x)≤F⁢(q0⁢(α)), then by (2.5), we have F0⁢(x)≤α, whence x≤q0⁢(α). Thus,

ℙ0(F0(X)≤α)=(⁢2.5⁢)ℙ0(F0(X)≤F0(q0(α))=(⁢2.6⁢)ℙ0(X≤q0(α))=F0(q0(α))=(⁢2.5⁢)α.

The remaining statements are easily derived from the first (try this!). ∎

Definition 2.5.3 (γ-quantile).

Let γ∈(0,1). A real number qγ is called γ-quantile of a distribution P, if

P⁢((−∞,qγ])≥γandP⁢([qγ,∞))≥1−γ.
Remark 2.5.4.
  1. (i)

    Interpretation: qγ splits the real axis in left and right half-lines with probability at least γ and 1−γ, respectively.

  2. (ii)

    Equivalently, qγ is a γ-quantile iff F⁢(qγ−)≤γ≤F⁢(qγ).

  3. (iii)

    If F0 is strictly increasing, γ-quantiles are unique.

2.6 Some basic univariate distributions

2.6.1 Discrete distributions

Bernoulli distribution

We say that X has a Bernoulli distribution with success probability p∈[0,1] if

ℙ⁢(X=x)={p,x=11−p,x=0,0,else

and we then write X∼ℬ⁢(p). The distribution of X can be equivalently written as

ℙX=p⁢δ1+(1−p)⁢δ0.

We have

𝔼⁢[X]=1⋅ℙ⁢(X=1)+0⋅ℙ⁢(X=0)=p,

and since

𝔼⁢[X2]=12⋅ℙ⁢(X=1)+02⋅ℙ⁢(X=0)=p,

it follows that

Var⁡(X)=𝔼⁢[X2]−𝔼⁢[X]2=p−p2=p⁢(1−p).

The mgf exists for all t∈ℝ and is given by

ψX⁢(t)=𝔼⁢[exp⁡(t⁢X)]=et⋅1⁢ℙ⁢(X=1)+et⋅0⁢ℙ⁢(X=0)=et⁢p+(1−p)=1+p⁢(et−1),t∈ℝ.

Interpretation: X models a single trial of a random experiment with probability of success p and probability of failure 1−p.

Binomial distribution

We say that X has a Binomial distribution with success probability p∈[0,1] and number of trials n∈ℕ if

ℙ⁢(X=x)={(nk)⁢pk⁢(1−p)n−k,x=k∈{0,1,…,n},0,else,

where the binomial coefficient

(nk)≔n!k!⁢(n−k)!,

describes the number of possibilities to choose k unordered elements (without replacement) from a set of n elements. We then write X∼Bin⁢(n,p). The distribution of the discrete random variable X can be equivalently written as

ℙX=∑k=0n(nk)⁢pk⁢(1−p)n−k⏟=ℙ⁢(X=k)⁣=pk⁢δk.

The fact that ℙX is a probability distribution follows from the binomial theorem:

∑k=0n(nk)⁢pk⁢(1−p)n−k=(p+(1−p))n=1.

For p=0 (p=1) we have X=n a.s. (X=0 a.s.) and hence in both cases 𝔼⁢[X]=n⁢p,Var⁡(X)=0=n⁢p⁢(1−p). For p∈(0,1) we get

𝔼⁢[X]=∑k=0nk⁢pk =∑k=0nk⁢(nk)⁢pk⁢(1−p)n−k
=∑k=1n−1n!(k−1)!⁢(n−k)!⁢pk⁢(1−p)n−k
=n⁢p⁢∑k=1n−1(n−1)!(k−1)!⁢(n−1−(k−1))!⁢pk−1⁢(1−p)n−1−(k−1)
=n⁢p⁢∑l=0n−1(n−1l)⁢pl⁢(1−p)n−l
=n⁢p,

where we substituted l=k−1 for the penultimate line. To show that generally Var⁡(X)=n⁢p⁢(1−p) we could try to calculate 𝔼⁢[X2] directly by invoking some combinatorial transformations as above, or we may try a different route by calculating the mgf. The latter is simple: by the binomial theorem,

ψX⁢(t)=∑k=0net⁢k⁢(nk)⁢pk⁢(1−p)n−k=∑k=0n(nk)⁢(p⁢et)k⁢(1−p)n−k=(p⁢et+(1−p))n,t∈ℝ.

Since

ψX′⁢(t)=n⁢p⁢et⁢(p⁢et+(1−p))n−1,ψX′′⁢(t)=n⁢p⁢et⁢(p⁢et+(1−p))n−1+n⁢(n−1)⁢p2⁢e2⁢t⁢(p⁢et+(1−p))n−2,

it follows that

𝔼⁢[X2]=ψX′′⁢(0)=n⁢p+n⁢(n−1)⁢p2,

and therefore

Var⁡(X)=𝔼⁢[X2]−𝔼⁢[X]2=n⁢p+n⁢(n−1)⁢p2−n2⁢p2=n⁢p−n⁢p2=n⁢p⁢(1−p).

Interpretation: X models the number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials.

Geometric distribution

We say that a random variable X has a geometric distribution with success probability p∈(0,1], if

ℙ⁢(X=x)={p⁢(1−p)k−1,x=k∈{1,2,…}0,else

and we then write X∼Geo⁢(p). Equivalently, we may express the distribution as

ℙX=∑k=1∞p⁢(1−p)k−1⁢δk.
Proposition 2.6.1 (Memorylessness).

If X∼Geo⁢(p), then for any m,n∈ℕ it holds that

ℙ⁢(X>n+m⁢∣X>⁢n)=ℙ⁢(X>m).

Interpretation: X models the number of independent Bernoulli trials with success probability p, until the first occurrence of success (X=k means that the first k−1 trials were unsuccessful, which happens with probability (1−p)−1, and the k-th trial is a success. Be aware that there are different conventions as to how to define the geometric distribution. Some authors prefer to model it as the number of failures until a success occurs, which changes the distribution to ℙX=∑k=0∞p⁢(1−p)k.

Exercise 2.6.2.

Show that ℙX is indeed a distribution. Determine the values t∈ℝ, at which the mgf ψX⁢(t) exists and calculate it for these. Use the mgf to show that 𝔼⁢[X]=1p and Var⁡(X)=(1−p)/p2.

Poisson distribution

We say that a random variable X has a Poisson distribution with with rate λ>0, if

ℙ⁢(X=x)={λkk!⁢e−λ,x=k∈{0,1,2,…}0,else

and we then write X∼Poi⁢(λ). ℙX is accordingly given by

ℙX=∑k=0∞λkk!⁢e−λ⁢δk.
Exercise 2.6.3.

Show that ℙX is indeed a distribution. Show that the mgf exists for all t∈ℝ and is given by

ψX⁢(t)=exp⁡(λ⁢(et−1)),t∈ℝ.

Use the mgf to show that 𝔼⁢[X]=Var⁡(X)=λ.

Interpretation: consider a situation, where random events occur subsequently at rate λ (i.e. on average λ events per time unit) and the interarrival time between two events is independent of the arrival times of previous events. If we let X be the number of events that have occurred in a unit time interval, then X∼Poi⁢(λ).

2.6.2 Continuous distributions

Uniform distribution

A continuous random variable X is said to be uniformly distributed on an interval [a,b] with a<b if its pdf is given by

f⁢(x)=1b−a⁢𝟏[a,b]⁢(x),x∈ℝ,

and we then write X∼𝒰⁢([a,b]). The piecewise linear cdf is given by

FX⁢(x)=∫−∞x1b−a⁢𝟏[a,b]⁢(y)⁢dy={0,x<ax−ab−a,x∈[a,b],1,else.

Expectation and variance are easily calculated as follows,

𝔼⁢[X] =∫ℝx⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx=1b−a⁢∫abx⁢dx=12⁢(b−a)⁢(b2−a2)⏟=(a+b)⁢(b−a)=a+b2
Var⁡(X) =∫ℝ(x−𝔼⁢[X])2⁢f⁢(x)⁢dx=1b−a⁢∫ab(x−a+b2)2⁢dx=1b−a⁢∫(a−b)/2(b−a)/2x2⁢dx
=2b−a⁢∫0(b−a)/2x2⁢dx=2⁢((b−a)/2)33⁢(b−a)=(b−a)212,

and the mgf exists everywhere and is given by

ψX⁢(t)=1b−a⁢∫abet⁢x⁢dx={et⁢b−et⁢at⁢(b−a),t≠0,1,t=0.
Exponential distribution

We say that a continuous random variable X is exponentially distributed with rate λ>0 if its pdf is given by

f⁢(x)=λ⁢e−λ⁢x⁢𝟏[0,∞)⁢(x),x∈ℝ,

and we then write X∼Exp⁢(λ). We recognize this as the pdf explored in Exercise 2.3.9 and Exercise 2.4.12, so we already know that

𝔼⁢[Xn]=n!λn,Var⁡(X)=1λ2,FX⁢(x)=1−e−λ⁢x,

and that the mgf exists on (−∞,λ) and is there given by

ψX⁢(t)=λλ−t,t<λ.

Like the discrete geometric distribution, the continuous exponential distribution has a lack of memory property.

Proposition 2.6.4.

Let X∼Exp⁢(λ) for some λ>0. Then, for any x,y≥0 we have

ℙ⁢(X>x+y⁢∣X>⁢x)=ℙ⁢(X>y).
Proof.

By definition of the conditional probability, we have

ℙ⁢(X>x+y⁢∣X>⁢x)=ℙ⁢(X>x+y,X>x)ℙ⁢(X>x)=ℙ⁢(X>x+y)ℙ⁢(X>x)=1−FX⁢(x+y)1−FX⁢(x) =e−λ⁢(x+y)e−λ⁢x
=e−λ⁢y
=ℙ⁢(X>y),

where we used {X>x+y}⊂{X>x} for the second equality. ∎

Remark 2.6.5.

It can be shown that exponential distributions are the only class of continuous probability distributions that is memoryless.

Interpretation: Suppose that X models the waiting time until the occurrence of a random event that arrives at rate λ and the waiting time is memoryless in the sense above. Then X∼Exp⁢(λ). Equivalently, we may describe an exponential distribution as the distribution of the independent interarrival times underlying the random events counted by a Poisson distribution with rate λ.

Normal distribution

A continuous random variable X is said to be normally distributed with mean μ∈ℝ and variance σ2 for σ>0, it its pdf is given by

f⁢(x)=12⁢π⁢σ2⁢e−(x−μ)22⁢σ2,x∈ℝ,

and we write X∼𝒩⁢(μ,σ2).

Exercise 2.6.6.

Show that f is a pdf.
Hint: Consider (∫ℝf⁢(x)⁢dx)2=∫ℝf⁢(x)⁢dx⁢∫ℝf⁢(y)⁢dy and use a polar substitution for x and y.

We call 𝒩⁢(0,1) the standard normal distribution and denotes its cdf by Φ. The cdf cannot be expressed in terms of elementary functions, but efficient numerical approximations are available. We observe that

X∼𝒩⁢(μ,σ2)⟹Y=a+b⁢X∼𝒩⁢(a+b⁢μ,b2⁢σ2),a,b∈ℝ,

since

FY⁢(x)=ℙ⁢(X≤(x−a)/b)=12⁢π⁢σ2⁢∫−∞(x−a)/be−(y−μ)22⁢σ2⁢dy=12⁢π⁢b2⁢σ2⁢∫−∞xe−(z−(a+b⁢μ))22⁢b2⁢σ2⁢dz=F𝒩⁢(a+b⁢μ,b2⁢σ2)⁢(x).

In particular the normalisation Z=(X−μ)/σ of X∼𝒩⁢(μ,σ2) is standard normal, i.e., Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1). The mgf exists everywhere and is calculated as follows: assume first that Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1). Then

ψZ⁢(t)=12⁢π⁢∫ℝet⁢x⁢e−x22⁢dx =12⁢π⁢∫ℝet⁢x−x22⁢dx
=12⁢π⁢∫ℝe−((x−t)22−t22)⁢dx (completing the square)
=et22⁢12⁢π⁢∫ℝe−(x−t)22⁢dx⏟=ℙ⁢(Y∈ℝ)=1⁢ for ⁢Y∼𝒩⁢(t,1)
=et22.

For general X∼𝒩⁢(μ,σ2), we have X⁢=𝑑⁢μ+σ⁢Z for some Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1), and hence by the above,

ψX⁢(t)=𝔼⁢[exp⁡(t⁢(μ+σ⁢Z))]=et⁢μ⁢𝔼⁢[exp⁡(t⁢σ⁢Z)]=et⁢μ⁢ψZ⁢(σ⁢t)=eμ⁢t+σ2⁢t22,t∈ℝ.

This gives

𝔼⁢[X] =ψX′⁢(0)=(μ+σ2⁢t)|t=0=μ
𝔼⁢[X2] =ψX′′⁢(0)=σ2+μ2⟹Var⁡(X)=𝔼⁢[X2]−𝔼⁢[X]2=σ2,

justifying us calling μ the mean and σ2 the variance of a normal distribution. Recall that the skewness and kurtosis are defined as the third and fourth moment, respectively of the standardised random variable Z=(X−μ)/σ.

Exercise 2.6.7.

Show that skewness of a normal random variable X∼𝒩⁢(μ,σ2) is 0 and its kurtosis is 3.

Interpretation: Many natural phenomena follow approximately a normal distribution, which can be mathematically explained by the Central Limit Theorem, which we will encounter soon.

Chapter 3 Multivariate distributions

3.1 Random vectors

Definition 3.1.1.

Let X1,…,Xn be random variables, all defined on the same probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). We call X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ an (n-dimensional) random vector.

Note that X:Ω→ℝn and we will now see that we can equivalently characterise a random vector X as a ℝn-valued random variable. The Borel σ-algebra on ℝn is defined analogously to the one-dimensional case,

ℬ⁢(ℝn)≔σ⁢({O:O⁢ open in ⁢ℝn}).
Definition 3.1.2.

An ℝn-valued random variable X on (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is a measurable mapping between the measurable space (Ω,ℱ) and (ℝn,ℬ⁢(ℝn)), that is, X:Ω→ℝn and

∀B∈ℬ⁢(ℝn):X−1⁢(B)∈ℱ.

To see the equivalence between both definitions, note that it can be shown that

ℬ⁢(ℝn)=σ⁢(ℬ⁢(ℝ)×⋯×ℬ⁢(ℝ)⏟n⁢ times).

Thus, according to Proposition 2.1.2, to show that a random vector X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ is ℱ/ℬ⁢(ℝn)-measurable and thereby an ℝn-valued random variable, it suffices to show that for any Cartesian product

B=×i=1nBi,B1,…,Bn∈ℬ(ℝ),

it holds that X−1⁢(B)∈ℱ. This follows from

X−1⁢(B1×⋯×Bn)={ω∈Ω:Xi⁢(ω)∈Bi⁢∀i=1,…,n}=⋂i=1nXi−1⁢(Bi)⏟∈ℱ∈ℱ,

whence any n-dimensional random vector is an ℝn-valued random variable. Conversely, if X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ is an ℝn-valued random variable, then for any i=1,…,n and B∈ℬ⁢(ℝ),

Xi−1⁢(B)=X−1⁢(ℝ×⋯×B⏟i⁢-th entry×⋯×ℝ⏞∈ℬ⁢(ℝn))∈ℱ,

so each of the coordinate mappings Xi is a (ℝ-valued) random variable on (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). We cast this observation in a lemma.

Lemma 3.1.3.

Every n-dimensional random vector is an ℝn-valued random variable and vice versa.

With this observation, it makes sense to speak of the distribution ℙX of a random vector.

Definition 3.1.4.

We call any probability measure on (ℝn,ℬ⁢(ℝn)) a multivariate distribution and define the joint distribution ℙX=ℙX1⊗⋯⊗Xn of a random vector X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ by the pushforward measure

ℙX1⊗⋯⊗Xn⁢(B)≔ℙ⁢(X−1⁢(B)),B∈ℬ⁢(ℝn).

In complete analogy to the one-dimensional case it can be shown that this indeed defines a probability measure on (ℝn,ℬ⁢(ℝn)). We leave the details to you.

Theorem 3.1.5.

The joint distribution of a random vector is a multivariate distribution.

Let us now introduce the natural analogue to a cdf in the multivariate case.

Definition 3.1.6.

Let X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ be a random vector. Its multivariate distribution function FX:ℝn→[0,1] is defined by

FX⁢(x1,…,xn)≔ℙX⁢((−∞,x1],…,(−∞,xn])=ℙ⁢(X1≤x1,…,Xn≤xn),x1,…,xn∈ℝ.

Moreover, we call ℙXi the marginal distribution of Xi.

Remark 3.1.7.

Given a multivariate distribution, its marginal distributions are obtained via the relation

ℙXi⁢(B)=ℙX1⊗⋯⊗Xn⁢(ℝ×⋯×B⏟i⁢-th entry×⋯×ℝ).

As in the one-dimensional case, the multivariate cdf uniquely characterises a multivariate distribution.

Theorem 3.1.8.

Suppose that X and Y are two random vectors. Then,

ℙX=ℙY⇔FX=FY.

We can again construct multivariate distributions in terms of an appropriate change of measure. We will be primarily dealing with continuous multivariate distribution, which are constructed via Lebesgue integrals w.r.t. the multivariate Lebesgue measure, which is the unique measure on (ℝn,ℬ⁢(ℝn)) that assigns a hypercuboid its natural volume, i.e.,

λn⁢((a1,b1]×⋯×(an,bn])=∏i=1n(bi−ai)=∏i=1nλ⁢((ai,bi]),ai,bi∈ℝ⁢ for all ⁢i=1,…,n.
Definition 3.1.9.

We say that a random vector X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ is absolutely continuous, if there exists a non-negative measurable function f:ℝn→ℝ such that ∫ℝnf⁢(x)⁢dx≡∫ℝdf⁢(x)⁢dλn⁢(x)=1 and

ℙX⁢(B)=∫Bf⁢(x)⁢dx≡∫Bf⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢dλn⁢(x1,…,xn),B∈ℬ⁢(ℝn).
Remark 3.1.10.

Using the general Proposition 2.2.9, it follows that any such f indeed yields a probability measure.

Next we state the analogue to Theorem 2.3.3 that tells us how to calculate the expectation of the one-dimensional random variable g⁢(X1,…,Xn) obtained from transforming the random vector with a function g:ℝn→ℝ.

Theorem 3.1.11.

Let X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ be a random vector. Suppose that g:ℝn→ℝ is a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that ∫ℝn|g⁢(x1,…,xn)|⁢dℙX⁢(x1,…,xn)<∞. Then,

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X1,…,Xn)]=∫ℝng⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢dℙX1⊗⋯⊗Xn⁢(x1,…,xn).

3.1.1 Product measures and Fubini’s theorem

Calculating such expectations can be very challenging, unless the joint distribution has a fairly nice structure. The essential tool in such situations is Fubini’s theorem. This, however, first requires the understanding of a product measure, which we will also heavily encounter in the next section on independence. Let (E1,𝒜1,μ1) and (E2,𝒜2,μ2) be σ-finite measure spaces. The product σ-algebra is defined as

𝒜1⊗𝒜2≔σ⁢(𝒜1×𝒜2)=σ⁢({A1×A2:A1∈𝒜1,A2∈𝒜2}),

and the product measure μ1⊗μ2 is the unique measure on 𝒜1⊗𝒜2 that satisfies

∀A1×A2∈𝒜1×𝒜2:μ1⊗μ2(A1×A2)=μ1(A1)μ2(A2).

Observe here that we have already encountered such a product measure before: the multivariate Lebesgue measure λn.

Fubini’s theorem now tells us that for product measures and non-negative transformations g, we may always integrate in arbitrary order.

Theorem 3.1.12 (Fubini’s theorem).

Let (E1,𝒜1,μ1) and (E2,𝒜2,μ2) be σ-finite measure spaces. Let g:E1×E2→[0,∞) be a measurable function w.r.t. the product σ-algebra 𝒜1⊗𝒜2. Then,111it is implicit here that the integrals make sense, that is Fubini’s theorem also states that x↦∫E2g⁢(x,y)⁢dμ2⁢(y) and y↦∫E1g⁢(x,y)⁢dμ1⁢(x) are measurable

∫E1×E2g⁢dμ1⊗μ2=∫E2(∫E1g⁢(x,y)⁢dμ1⁢(x))⁢dμ2⁢(y)=∫E1(∫E2g⁢(x,y)⁢dμ2⁢(y))⁢dμ1⁢(x).

Iterating this theorem yields the following for continuous random vectors.

Corollary 3.1.13.

Let X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ be a random vector with multivariate density f and g:ℝn→[0,∞) be measurable. Then, for any permutation (i1,…,in) of {1,…,n} it holds that

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X1,…,Xn)]=∫ℝ(∫ℝ(⋯⁢∫ℝg⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢f⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢dxi1⁢⋯)⁢dxin−1)⁢dxin.
Remark 3.1.14.

Because the order of integration does not matter, in short we may therefore just write

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X1,…,Xn)]=∫ℝng⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢f⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢dx1⁢⋯⁢dxn.

In particular, for any i∈{1,…,n} we get

ℙ⁢(Xi∈B)=∫B(∫ℝn−1f⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢dx1⁢⋯⁢dxi−1⁢dxi+1⁢⋯⁢dxn)⁢dxi,

so the marginal Xi is absolutely continuous with density

fi⁢(xi)≔∫ℝn−1f⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢dx1⁢⋯⁢dxi−1⁢dxi+1⁢⋯⁢dxn,xi∈ℝ,

which we call the i-th marginal density.

3.1.2 Expectation and covariance

Given a random vector we define its expectation to be the vector of expectations of the marginals.

Definition 3.1.15.

For a random vector X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ with well-defined marginal expectations 𝔼⁢[Xi], i=1,…,n, its expectation is defined as the vector

𝔼⁢[X]≔(𝔼⁢[X1],…,𝔼⁢[Xn])⊤.
Definition 3.1.16.
  1. (i)

    For two random variables X,Y that are defined on the same probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) and are such that 𝔼⁢[X2],𝔼⁢[Y2]<∞, their covariance is defined as

    Cov⁡(X,Y)≔𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X])⁢(Y−𝔼⁢[Y])].

    If Cov⁡(X,Y)=0 we call X and Y uncorrelated. If Var⁡X,Var⁡Y>0, their correlation is defined by

    ρX,Y≔Cov⁡(X,Y)Var⁡(X)⁢Var⁡(Y)=Cov⁡(X,Y)σX⁢σY.
  2. (ii)

    The covariance matrix of a random vector X=(X1,…,Xn) is defined as

    ΣX≔(Cov⁡(Xi,Xj))i,j=1,…,n=(Cov⁡(X1,X1)⋯Cov⁡(X1,Xn)⋮⋱⋮Cov⁡(Xn,X1)⋯Cov⁡(Xn,Xn)).
Remark 3.1.17.

We equivalently use the notation ΣX≡𝔼⁢[(X−𝔼⁢[X])⁢(X−𝔼⁢[X])⊤].

Exercise 3.1.18.

Show that

  1. (i)

    for any a,b∈ℝ, Cov⁡(a⁢X,b⁢Y)=a⁢b⁢Cov⁡(X,Y).

  2. (ii)

    Cov⁡(X,Y)=0 if X and Y are independent (see next subsection for definition of independence).

  3. (iii)

    ρX,Y∈[−1,1] if the correlation is well-defined.

Exercise 3.1.19.

Suppose that (X1,…,Xn)⊤ is a random vector such that 𝔼⁢[Xi2]<∞ for all i=1,…,n. Show that

Var⁡(X1+⋯+Xn)=∑i=1nVar⁡(Xi)+∑i≠jCov⁡(Xi,Xj).

Conclude that Var⁡(X1+⋯+Xn)=∑i=1nVar⁡(Xi), if X1,…,Xn are pairwise uncorrelated.

Exercise 3.1.20.

Let X be an n-dimensional random vector. Show that

  1. (i)

    ΣX is positive semi-definite, i.e., for any column vector a∈ℝn it holds that a⊤⁢ΣX⁢a≥0.

  2. (ii)

    for b∈ℝk and A∈ℝk×n a (k×n)-matrix, it holds that Σb+A⁢X=A⁢ΣX⁢A⊤.

3.2 Independence

The standard assumption in statistics is the following: we are given n random samples X1,…,Xn that are independent and follow a common distribution P that we wish to infer from the data. The definition of independence of random variables naturally derives from independence of events that we discussed in Chapter 1.

Definition 3.2.1 (Independence of random variables).
  1. (i)

    Let X1,…,Xn be random variables, all defined on the same probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). We say that X1,…,Xn are independent if

    ∀B1,…,Bn∈ℬ(ℝ):ℙ(X1∈B1,…,Xn∈Bn)=∏i=1nℙ(Xi∈Bi).

    If additionally ℙX1=⋯=ℙXn we say that X1,…,Xn are i.i.d. (independent and identically distributed). We then also call X1,…,Xn an i.i.d. sample

  2. (ii)

    A sequence of random variables X1,X2,… on a common probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) is defined to be independent (resp., i.i.d) if for any n∈ℕ the random variables X1,…,Xn are independent (resp., i.i.d.).

In terms of the joint distribution and the product distribution, the definition of independence reads equivalently

ℙX1⊗⋯⊗Xn(B)=ℙX1⊗⋯⊗ℙXn(B),∀B∈×i=1nℬ(ℝ).

Since ×i=1nℬ⁢(ℝ) is a ∩-stable generator of ℬ⁢(ℝn) and probability measures are uniquely characterised on such, we obtain the following nice formula.

Proposition 3.2.2.

A family of random variables X1,…,Xn is independent if, and only if,

ℙX1⊗⋯⊗Xn=ℙX1⊗⋯⊗ℙXn.

Based on this we collect other useful characterisations of independence.

Corollary 3.2.3.

A family of random variables X1,…,Xn is independent if, and only if, for every collection g1,…,gn:ℝ→ℝ of measurable, non-negative functions it holds that

𝔼⁢[∏i=1ngi⁢(Xi)]=∏i=1n𝔼⁢[gi⁢(Xi)]. (3.1)
Proof.

Suppose that X1,…,Xn are independent. Then, using Theorem 3.1.11, Proposition 3.2.2 and Fubini’s theorem, we have

𝔼⁢[∏i=1ngi⁢(Xi)] =∫ℝng1⁢(x1)⁢⋯⁢gn⁢(xn)⁢dℙX1⊗⋯⊗ℙXn⁢(x1,…,xn)
=∫ℝn−1(∫ℝg1⁢(x1)⁢∏i=2ngi⁢(xi)⁢d⁢ℙX1⁢(x1))⁢dℙX2⊗⋯⊗ℙXn⁢(x2,…,xn)
=lin.⁢∫ℝn−1∏i=2ngi⁢(xi)⁢(∫ℝg1⁢(x1)⁢dℙX1⁢(x1))⁢d⁢ℙX2⊗⋯⊗ℙXn⁢(x2,…,xn)
=lin.⁢∫ℝg1⁢(x1)⁢dℙX1⁢(x1)⁢∫ℝn−1∏i=2ngi⁢(xi)⁢d⁢ℙX2⊗⋯⊗ℙXn⁢(x2,…,xn).

Iterating the argument and then using Theorem 2.3.3 yields

𝔼⁢[∏i=1ngi⁢(Xi)]=∏i=1n∫ℝgi⁢(xi)⁢dℙXi⁢(xi)=∏i=1n𝔼⁢[gi⁢(Xi)].

If conversely (3.1) holds for any collection of non-negative measurable functions, we choose gi=𝟏Bi for arbitrary Bi∈ℬ⁢(ℝ) to conclude independence of X1,…,Xn. ∎

Corollary 3.2.4.

A family of random variables X1,…,Xn is independent if, and only if,

∀x1,…,xn∈ℝ:FX1⊗⋯⊗Xn(x1,…,xn)=∏i=1nFXi(xi).
Proof.

Follows from Proposition 3.2.2 and Theorem 3.1.8. ∎

Corollary 3.2.5.

If X1,…,Xn are independent and g1,…,gn:ℝ→ℝ are measurable functions, then g1⁢(X1),…,gn⁢(Xn) are independent as well.

Proof.

Exercise! ∎

Corollary 3.2.6.

Suppose that X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ is a continuous random vector with multivariate density f and marginal densities fi. Then, X1,…,Xn are independent if, and only if, for λn-a.e. x∈ℝn we have

f⁢(x1,…,xn)=∏i=1nfi⁢(xi).

Our final corollary of this section pertains to sums of independent random variables, which we will encounter frequently in the next chapters.

Corollary 3.2.7.

If X1,…,Xn are independent, then for the mgf of ∑i=1nXi it holds that

ψ∑i=1nXi⁢(t)=∏i=1nψXi⁢(t),t∈ℝ.

In particular, if X1,…,Xn are i.i.d. with ℙXi=ℙX for all i, we have

ψ∑i=1nXi⁢(t)=(ψX⁢(t))n.
Proof.

Exercise! ∎

Example 3.2.8 (Revisiting the binomial distribution).

When we introduced the binomial distribution Bin⁢(n,p), we interpreted it as modeling the number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials, without having a meaningful definition of independence at hand. We can make this precise now: let X1,…,Xn be i.i.d. random variables such that X1∼ℬ⁢(p). Then, ψXi⁢(t)=p⁢et+1−p and by Corollary 3.2.7 it follows that

ψX1+⋯+Xn⁢(t)=(p⁢et+1−p)n=ψX⁢(t),t∈ℝ,

where X∼Bin⁢(n,p). Since by Theorem 2.4.10 the mgf uniquely characterises the distribution of a random variable it follows that

X1+⋯+Xn⁢=𝑑⁢X.
Exercise 3.2.9.

Suppose that X,Y are independent and continuous random variables with densities fX,fY respectively. Show that the density fX+Y of X+Y is given by the convolution

fX+Y⁢(z)=fX∗fY⁢(z)≔∫ℝfX⁢(x)⁢fY⁢(z−x)⁢dx,z∈ℝ.
Exercise 3.2.10.

Let λ1,λ2>0 and let X1∼Exp⁡(λ1) and X2∼Exp⁡(λ2) be independent. Show that min⁡{X1,X2}∼Exp⁡(λ1+λ2).

Exercise 3.2.11.

Let X1∼𝒩⁢(μ1,σ12) and X2∼𝒩⁢(μ2,σ22) be independent. Show that X1+X2∼𝒩⁢(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22).

3.2.1 Multivariate normal distribution

Definition 3.2.12.

Let μ∈ℝn and Σ∈ℝn×n be a symmetric positive semi-definite matrix. A random vector X=(X1,…,Xn)⊤ is defined to have a multivariate normal (or Gaussian) distribution with mean vector μ and covariance matrix Σ, if for any real numbers a1,…,an,

a⊤⁢X=∑i=1ai⁢Xi∼𝒩⁢(a⊤⁢μ,a⊤⁢Σ⁢a)=𝒩⁢(∑i=1nai⁢μi,∑i,j=1nai⁢aj⁢Σi,j).

It is immediate from this definition that every entry Xi of a multivariate normal vector is normally distributed as well with Xi∼𝒩⁢(μi,Σi,i). It is important to remember however that if we are given Xi∼𝒩⁢(μ,σi2), i=1,…,n, then (X1,…,Xn)⊤ is not necessarily a multivariate random vector. If μ=0 and Σ=𝕀n is the identity, i.e., Cov⁡(Xi,Xj)=𝟏{i}⁢(j), X∼𝒩⁢(0,𝕀n) is called a standard normal random vector.

Multivariate normal distributions can always be generated by linearly transforming a standard normal random vector. Let Σ1/2∈ℝn×n denote the symmetric square root of a covariance matrix Σ, that is Σ=Σ1/2⁢Σ1/2=Σ1/2⁢(Σ1/2)⊤ (the square root always exists because we have seen that covariance matrices are symmetric positive semi-definite).

Theorem 3.2.13.

X∼𝒩⁢(μ,Σ) if, and only if, X⁢=𝑑⁢μ+Σ1/2⁢Z for a standard normal random vector Z.

For the proof we use the fact that the distribution of a random vector is uniquely characterised by the distributions of all linear combinations of its components, which can be proven via multivariate characteristic functions (not part of this module).

Theorem 3.2.14.

For two n-dimensional random vectors X and Y it holds that

X⁢=𝑑⁢Y⇔∀a∈ℝn:a⊤⁢X⁢=𝑑⁢a⊤⁢Y.
Proof of Theorem 3.2.13.

By the previous theorem it suffices to check that a⊤⁢X⁢=𝑑⁢a⊤⁢(μ+Σ1/2⁢Z) for any a∈ℝn and some Z∼𝒩⁢(0,𝕀n). By definition of X and Z it holds that a⊤⁢X∼𝒩⁢(a⊤⁢μ,a⊤⁢Σ⁢a) and

a⊤⁢(μ+Σ1/2⁢Z)=a⊤⁢μ+a⊤⁢Σ1/2⁢Z⏟∼𝒩⁢(0,a⊤⁢Σ1/2⁢(a⊤⁢Σ1/2)⊤)=𝒩⁢(0,a⊤⁢Σ1/2⁢(Σ1/2)⊤⁢a)=𝒩⁢(0,a⊤⁢Σ⁢a)∼𝒩⁢(a⊤⁢μ,a⊤⁢Σ⁢a),

whence a⊤⁢X⁢=𝑑⁢a⊤⁢(μ+Σ1/2⁢Z). ∎

Corollary 3.2.15.

If X∼𝒩⁢(μ,Σ), then Cov⁡(Xi,Xj)=Σi,j.

Using a multivariate extension of the moment generating function, the following can be established, which is a unique feature of normal random vectors.

Theorem 3.2.16.

Let X∼𝒩⁢(μ,Σ) be an n-dimensional normal random vector. Then X1,…,Xn are independent, if, and only if, Σ=𝕀n.

Remark 3.2.17.

In other words, for the components of a normal random vector to be independent, it suffices to check that they are pairwise uncorrelated.

By Theorem 3.2.16 we know that the multivariate density of a standard normal random vector Z is given by

fZ⁢(x1,…,xn)=∏i=1nfZi⁢(xi)=∏i=1n12⁢π⁢e−xi2/2=1(2⁢π)n/2⁢exp⁡(−∑i=1nxi22)=1(2⁢π)n/2⁢exp⁡(−∥x∥22).

Using the transformation formula from real analysis and Theorem 3.2.13 it can then be shown that for general X∼𝒩⁢(μ,Σ) with invertible Σ, the density is given by

fX⁢(x1,…,xn)=fμ+Σ1/2⁢Z⁢(x1,…,xn)=1(2⁢π)n⁢det⁡Σ⁢exp⁡(−12⁢(x−μ)⊤⁢Σ−1⁢(x−μ)),x∈ℝn.

3.2.2 Univariate distributions related to independent random variables

Gamma distribution

We say that a continuous random variable X has a Gamma distribution with shape parameter α and scale parameter β>0, if its density is given by

fα,β⁢(x)=βαΓ⁢(α)⁢xα−1⁢e−β⁢x⁢𝟏(0,∞)⁢(x),

where

Γ⁢(z)≔∫(0,∞)xz−1⁢e−x⁢dx,z>0,

is the Gamma function, which is easily shown to satisfy Γ⁢(1)=1 and the recurrence relation

Γ⁢(z+1)=z⁢Γ⁢(z),z>0.

Moreover, for later use we note that Γ⁢(1/2)=π since substituting x=y2 (↝dx=2ydy) yields

Γ⁢(1/2)=∫(0,∞)x−1/2⁢e−x⁢dx=∫0∞1y⁢e−y2⁢2⁢y⁢dy=2⁢∫0∞e−y2⁢dy=∫ℝe−y2⁢dy=π.

We then write X∼Γ⁢(α,β). We first note that for α=1, the Gamma distribution coincides with an exponential distribution, that is, Γ⁢(1,β)=Exp⁢(β). As it turns out, for α∈ℕ the Gamma distribution is the distribution of the sum of i.i.d. exponential random variables. More precisely, the mgf of X∼Γ⁢(α,β) exists for all t<β and is obtained from the following calculation for t<β:

ψX⁢(t) =βαΓ⁢(α)⁢∫(0,∞)et⁢x⁢xα−1⁢e−β⁢x⁢dx
=βαΓ⁢(α)⁢∫(0,∞)xα−1⁢e−(β−t)⁢x⁢dx
=βαΓ⁢(α)⁢∫(0,∞)(y/(β−t))α−1⁢e−y⁢1β−t⁢dy (substitution y=(β−t)⁢x)
=(ββ−t)α⁢1Γ⁢(α)⁢∫(0,∞)yα−1⁢e−y⁢dy⏟=ℙ⁢(Y>0)=1⁢ for ⁢Y∼Γ⁢(α,1)
=(ββ−t)α.

This implies that if X∼Γ⁢(α,β) and Y∼Γ⁢(γ,β) are independent, then

ψX+Y⁢(t)=ψX⁢(t)⁢ψY⁢(t)=(ββ−t)α+γ=ψΓ⁢(α+γ,β),t<β,

and therefore X+Y∼Γ⁢(α+γ,β) by Theorem 2.4.10. Iterating this argument for n i.i.d. Exp⁢(β)=Γ⁢(1,β) distributed random variables, yields ∑i=1nXi∼Γ⁢(n,β). We cast this formally into a proposition.

Proposition 3.2.18.

Let α,γ,β>0. If X∼Γ⁢(α,β) and Y∼Γ⁢(γ,β) are independent, then X+Y∼Γ⁢(α+γ,β). In particular, if X1,…,Xn are i.i.d. with X1∼Exp⁡(β) for some β>0, then ∑i=1nXi∼Γ⁢(n,β).

χ2-distribution

The χ2-distribution plays an important role in statistical test theory. Its definition derives from the following observation.

Lemma 3.2.19.

If X∼𝒩⁢(0,1), then X2∼Γ⁢(1/2,1/2).

Proof.

Let g≥0 be a measurable function. Then, by the transformation theorem

𝔼⁢[g⁢(X2)] =12⁢π⁢∫ℝg⁢(x2)⁢e−x22⁢dx
=2π⁢∫(0,∞)g⁢(x2)⁢e−x22⁢dx
=2π⁢∫(0,∞)g⁢(y)⁢e−y/2⁢12⁢y⁢dy (substitution y=x2)
=∫(0,∞)g⁢(y)⁢(1/2)1/2Γ⁢(1/2)⁢y1/2−1⁢e−y/2⁢dy (Γ⁢(1/2)=π)
=𝔼⁢[g⁢(Y)],

for Y∼Γ⁢(1/2,1/2). ∎

Definition 3.2.20.

The χ2-distribution with n degrees of freedom is defined by χn2=Γ⁢(n/2,1/2), so that the density and mgf of X∼χn2 are respectively given by

f⁢(x)=12n/2⁢Γ⁢(n/2)⁢xn/2−1⁢e−x/2⁢𝟏(0,∞)⁢(x),

and

ψX⁢(t)=1(1−2⁢t)n/2,t<1/2.

Combining the previous lemma and Proposition 3.2.18 yields the following.

Theorem 3.2.21.

If X1,…,Xn are i.i.d. and X1∼𝒩⁢(0,1), then

∑i=1nXi2∼χn2.

3.3 Conditional distributions and expectations

We now introduce conditional distributions and expectations. The general measure theoretic route would go via specifying conditional expectations first and then define conditional distributions from there. For the purposes of this module, we don’t need that sort of generality and will rather start with introducing the notion of a conditional distribution in a restricted setting.

Let us therefore assume in this section that X is an n-dimensional random vector and Y is an m-dimensional random vector such that their joint distribution can be expressed as

ℙX,Y⁢(B)=∫BfX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢dμ⊗ν⁢(x,y)⁢=Fubini⁢∫BfX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢dμ⁢(x)⁢dν⁢(y),B∈ℬ⁢(ℝn+1),

for some dominating product measure μ⊗ν (μ,ν σ-finite). If both μ and ν are Lebesgue measures, (X,Y) would simply be absolutely continuous, but with the above we also allow situations where X is continuous, Y is discrete, etc. We let

fX⁢(x)≔∫ℝmfX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢dν⁢(y),fY⁢(y)≔∫ℝnfX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢dμ⁢(x),

be the marginal densities of X and Y, respectively.

Inspired by the definition of conditional probability from Chapter 1, we then introduce the conditional density of X given Y=y as

fX∣Y⁢(x∣y)≔{fX,Y⁢(x,y)fY⁢(y),fY⁢(y)≠00.else

and define the conditional distribution of X given Y=y via

ℙX∣Y=y⁢(B)≔∫BfX∣Y⁢(x∣y)⁢dμ⁢(x),B∈ℝn.

Note that for any y such that fY⁢(y)≠0, ℙX∣Y=y is indeed a distribution because then

ℙX∣Y=y⁢(ℝn)=1fX⁢(x)⁢∫ℝnfX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢dμ⁢(x)⏟=fX⁢(x)=1.

If n=1, i.e., X is a random variable, we define

𝔼⁢[X∣Y=y]≔∫ℝx⁢dℙX∣Y=y⁢(x)=∫ℝx⁢fX∣Y⁢(x∣y)⁢dμ⁢(x),y∈ℝm,

as the conditional expectation of X given Y=y provided that 𝔼⁢[|X|]<∞ (check that the integral on the rhs is then well-defined!). If we understand this as a function, i.e. y↦g⁢(y)=𝔼⁢[X∣Y=y], the conditional expectation given Y=y then induces a random variable by plugging in,

𝔼⁢[X∣Y]≔g⁢(Y)=∫ℝx⁢fX∣Y⁢(x∣Y)⁢dμ⁢(x),provided ⁢𝔼⁢[|X|]<∞.

that we call the conditional expectation of X given Y. This now also motivates the the definition of the conditional distribution of X given Y, ℙX∣Y, which is defined via

ℙX∣Y⁢(B)≔∫BfX∣Y⁢(x∣Y)⁢dμ⁢(x),B∈ℬ⁢(ℝn),

such that (for n=1) 𝔼⁢[X∣Y]=∫ℝx⁢dℙX∣Y⁢(x). Conceptually, it is important to acknowledge that

  1. (i)

    for any B∈ℬ⁢(ℝn), ℙX∣Y⁢(B) is again a random variable;

  2. (ii)

    B↦ℙX∣Y⁢(B) is a probability measure ℙ-a.s.,222this is because for any ω∉{ω∈Ω:fY(Y(ω))=0)}≕N, B↦ℙX∣Y⁢(B)⁢(ω) is a probability distribution and ℙ⁢(N)=∫{fY=0}fY⁢(y)⁢dν⁢(y)=0.

which is why we call it a random probability measure.

We now state Bayes’ formula (recall the one for events from Chapter 1), which is at the heart of Bayesian statistics.

Theorem 3.3.1 (Bayes’ formula).

It holds that

fY∣X⁢(y∣x)⏟posterior density=fX∣Y⁢(x∣y)⁢fY⁢(y)⏞prior densityfX⁢(x),fX⁢(x)>0,fY⁢(y)>0.
Proof.

If x,y are such that fX⁢(x),fY⁢(y)>0, then

fY∣X⁢(y∣x)⁢fX⁢(x)=fX,Y⁢(x,y)=fX∣Y⁢(x∣y)⁢fY⁢(y).

∎

For completeness, we also give some important properties of the conditional expectation, which we justify in the appendix.

Proposition 3.3.2.

Let X,X1,X2,Y be as above s.t. 𝔼⁢[|X|],𝔼⁢[|Xi|]<∞, i=1,2.

  1. (i)

    For any α,β∈ℝ we have the ℙ-a.s. equality

    𝔼⁢[α⁢X1+β⁢X2∣Y]=α⁢𝔼⁢[X1∣Y]+β⁢𝔼⁢[X2∣Y]. (Linearity)
  2. (ii)
    𝔼⁢[𝔼⁢[X∣Y]]=𝔼⁢[X]. (tower property)
  3. (iii)

    if X and Y are independent,333similarly to random variables, if X, Y are n and m-dimensional random vectors, respectively, they are said to be independent if ℙ⁢(X∈B1,Y∈B2)=ℙ⁢(X∈B1)⁢ℙ⁢(Y∈B2) for any Borel sets B1,B2, which is equivalent to the factorisation identity fX,Y⁢(x,y)=fX⁢(x)⁢fY⁢(y) a.e. w.r.t. their dominating measure. then 𝔼⁢[X∣Y]=𝔼⁢[X], ℙ-a.s.

Chapter 4 Asymptotic Theory

4.1 Convergence of random variables

4.1.1 Convergence concepts

Definition 4.1.1.

Let X be a random variable and (Xn)n∈ℕ be a sequence of random variables that are all defined on a common probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). We say that

  1. (i)

    (Xn)n∈ℕ converges almost surely to X, if

    ℙ(limn→∞Xn=X)=1(⇔ℙ({ω∈Ω:limn→∞Xn(ω)=X(ω)})=1.)

    We then write Xn⁢⟶a.s.⁢X.

  2. (ii)

    given a real number p≥1, (Xn)n∈ℕ converges in p-th mean to X, if

    𝔼⁢[|Xn−X|p]⁢⟶n→∞⁢0.

    We then write Xn⁢⟶ℒp⁢0.

  3. (iii)

    (Xn)n∈ℕ converges in probability to X, if

    ∀ε>0:ℙ(|Xn−X|≥ε)⟶n→∞0(⇔∀ε>0:ℙ(|Xn−X|<ε)⟶n→∞1).

    We then write Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X.

Let us state some important relations between the different convergence concepts.

Theorem 4.1.2.

The following implications hold:

  1. (i)

    Xn⁢⟶a.s.⁢X⟹Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X

  2. (ii)

    Xn⁢⟶ℒp⁢X⟹Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X

  3. (iii)

    if 1≤r<s, then Xn⁢⟶ℒs⁢X⟹Xn⁢⟶ℒr⁢X.

The reverse implications generally do not hold.

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Let Λ≔{ω∈Ω:limn→∞Xn⁢(ω)=X⁢(ω)}. Then, by the assumption Xn⁢⟶a.s.⁢X, we have ℙ⁢(Λc)=0. Let ε be arbitrarily chosen. Since 𝟏{|Xn−X|}≥ε⁢𝟏Λ≤1 for any n∈ℕ. Moreover, by definition of Λ,

    ∀ω∈Λ:limn→∞𝟏{|Xn⁢(ω)−X⁢(ω)|≥ε}=0, (4.1)

    which shows that

    𝟏{|Xn−X|≥ε}⁢⟶a.s.⁢0.

    We therefore obtain from dominated convergence (cf. Theorem 2.2.8) that

    limn→∞ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|≥ε) =limn→∞𝔼⁢[𝟏{|Xn−X|≥ε}]=𝔼⁢[limn→∞𝟏{|Xn−X|≥ε}]=0.

    Since ε>0 was arbitrary, this shows Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X.

  2. (ii)

    We use Markov’s inequality (Theorem 2.4.5) with the strictly increasing function φ⁢(x)=xp, x≥0. Then, for any ε>0

    ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|≥ε)≤𝔼⁢[φ⁢(|X−Xn|)]φ⁢(ε)=𝔼⁢[|Xn−X|p]εp⁢⟶n→∞⁢0.
  3. (iii)

    Using Hölder’s inequality (Theorem 2.4.2) with p=s/r and q=s/rs/r−1 (note that then 1/p+1/q=1),

    𝔼⁢[|Xn−X|r]=𝔼⁢[|Xn−X|r⋅1]≤(𝔼⁢[(|Xn−X|r)s/r])r/s⁢(𝔼⁢[1q])1/q=(𝔼⁢[|Xn−X|s])r/s⁢⟶n→∞⁢0.

∎

Theorem 4.1.3 (Continuous mapping theorem).

Let φ:ℝ→ℝ be a continuous function.

  1. (i)

    Xn⁢⟶a.s.⁢X⟹φ⁢(Xn)⁢⟶a.s.⁢φ⁢(X).

  2. (ii)

    Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X⟹φ⁢(Xn)⁢⟶ℙ⁢φ⁢(X).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Let again Λ≔{ω∈Ω:limn→∞Xn⁢(ω)=X⁢(ω)} such that by assumption, ℙ⁢(Λ)=1. By continuity of φ,

    ∀ω∈Λ:limn→∞φ⁢(Xn⁢(ω))=φ⁢(limn→∞Xn⁢(ω))=φ⁢(X⁢(ω)).

    Thus, Λ⊂{limn→∞φ⁢(Xn)=φ⁢(X)} and therefore ℙ⁢(limn→∞φ⁢(Xn)=φ⁢(X))≥ℙ⁢(Λ)=1.

  2. (ii)

    For simplicity we only give the proof for the case that φ is uniformly continuous, that is for any ε>0 there exists δ>0 such that

    ∀x,y∈ℝ:|x−y|<δ⟹|φ(x)−φ(y)|<ε.

    Let ε>0 be given. Since φ is uniformly continuous, there exists δ>0 such that |φ⁢(Xn⁢(ω))−φ⁢(X⁢(ω))|<ε, whenever |Xn⁢(ω)−X⁢(ω)|<δ, which implies {|Xn−X|<δ}⊂{|φ⁢(Xn)−φ⁢(X)|<ε} and therefore

    ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|<δ)≤ℙ⁢(|φ⁢(Xn)−φ⁢(X)|<ε).

    By our assumption that Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X, it follows that ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|<δ)⁢⟶n→∞⁢1, and thus by the above also ℙ⁢(|φ⁢(Xn)−φ⁢(X)|<ε)⁢⟶n→∞⁢1. Since ε>0 was arbitrary, this shows φ⁢(Xn)⁢⟶ℙ⁢φ⁢(X).

∎

4.1.2 The Law of Large Numbers

For a given sample X1,…,Xn we call

X¯n≔1n⁢∑i=1nXi

the sample mean. If, 𝔼⁢[X1]=⋯=𝔼⁢[Xn]=μ, the sample mean is an unbiased estimator of the expectation μ in the sense that 𝔼⁢[X¯n]=μ. For i.i.d. data with second moment, we obtain convergence of the sample mean in ℒ2.

Proposition 4.1.4 (ℒ2-version of the LLN).

Let (Xn)n∈ℕ be an i.i.d. sequence of random variables such that 𝔼⁢[|X1|2]<∞. Then, for μ≔𝔼⁢[X1] and σ2≔Var⁡(X1) it holds that

𝔼⁢[|1n⁢∑i=1nXi−μ|2]=σ2n,

and hence in particular,

1n⁢∑i=1nXi⁢⟶ℒ2⁢μ.
Proof.

Using Exercise 2.4.4 and Exercise 3.1.19 we find for the i.i.d. sample X1,…,Xn that

Var⁡(1n⁢∑i=1nXi)=1n2⁢Var⁡(∑i=1nXi)=1n2⁢(∑i=1nVar⁡(Xi)⏟=n⁢Var⁡(X1)⁢ since ⁢ℙXi=ℙXj+∑i≠jCov⁡(Xi,Xj)⏟=0⁢ by independence)=1n⁢Var⁡(X1). (4.2)

Therefore,

𝔼⁢[|1n⁢∑i=1nXi−μ|2]=𝔼⁢[|1n⁢∑i=1nXi−𝔼⁢[1n⁢∑i=1nXi]|2]=Var⁡(1n⁢∑i=1nXi)=Var⁡(X1)n⁢⟶n→∞⁢0.

∎

The strong Law of Large Numbers (LLN) now states that for an i.i.d. sample, just the existence of the expectation is sufficient to get almost sure convergence to it.

Theorem 4.1.5 (strong LLN).

Let (Xn)n∈ℕ be an i.i.d. sequence of random variables such that 𝔼⁢[|X1|]<∞. Then, for μ≔𝔼⁢[X1] it holds that

1n⁢∑i=1nXi⁢⟶a.s.⁢μ.

The full proof of the strong LLN is rather involved and unfortunately out of scope of these lectures. We therefore only give a fairly compact proof under the additional (but not necessary!) assumption that the samples have finite fourth moment. To this end, we need the following, which is a direct consequence of the Borel–Cantelli lemma (see appendix).

Lemma 4.1.6.

Let Y be a random variable and (Yn)n∈ℕ be a sequence of random variables on a common probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ). Then,

∑n=1∞ℙ⁢(|Yn−Y|>ε)⁢<∞⁢ for all ⁢ε>⁢0⟹Yn⁢⟶a.s.⁢Y.
Proof of LLN when fourth moment is finite.

Assume additionally that 𝔼⁢[X14]<∞. By the previous lemma it suffices to check that

∀ε>0:∑n=1∞ℙ⁢(|X¯n−μ|>ε)<∞, (4.3)

where X¯n=n−1⁢∑i=1nXi, μ=𝔼⁢[X1]. Fix ε>0. Using Markov’s inequality and the assumption 𝔼⁢[X14]<∞, it follows that

ℙ⁢(|X¯n−μ|>ε) ≤𝔼⁢[|X¯n−μ|4]ε4.

Let Yi=Xi−μ. Then, for any i,j,k,l∈{1,…,n} with i∉{j,k,l} we get by independence and 𝔼⁢[Yi]=0 that

𝔼⁢[Yi⁢Yj⁢Yk⁢Yl]=𝔼⁢[Yi]⁢𝔼⁢[Yj⁢Yk⁢Yl]=0,

and therefore

𝔼⁢[|X¯n−μ|4] =1n4⁢∑i,j,k,l=1n𝔼⁢[Yi⁢Yj⁢Yk⁢Yl]
=1n4⁢(∑i=1n𝔼⁢[Yi4]+(42)⁢∑i≠j𝔼⁢[Yi2⁢Yj2])
=1n4⁢(n⁢𝔼⁢[Y14]+3⁢n⁢(n−1)⁢𝔼⁢[Y12]2).

Consequently,

ℙ⁢(|X¯n−μ|>ε)≤n⁢𝔼⁢[Y14]+3⁢n⁢(n−1)⁢𝔼⁢[Y12]2ε4⁢n4≤4⁢𝔼⁢[Y14]ε4⁢n2,

which yields

∑n=1∞ℙ⁢(|X¯n−μ|>ε)≤4⁢𝔼⁢[Y14]ε4⁢∑n=1∞1n2<∞.

This proves (4.3) and therefore establishes

X¯n⁢⟶a.s.⁢𝔼⁢[X1].

∎

Let us also note that the strong LLN is not the strongest version: for instance, it is sufficient to require pairwise independence of the identically distributed samples (Etemadi’s LLN).

4.2 Convergence in distribution

The previous convergence concepts for random variables express in different ways the idea that Xn→X if Xn and X are close to another with increasing probability as n→∞. In many situations, this concept is however too strong. Consider for e.g. the case that we choose X∼𝒰⁢([0,1]) and Xn=1−X for all n. Then Xn∼𝒰⁢([0,1]) for all n, but for any ε>0,

ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|<ε)=ℙ⁢(|2⁢X−1|<ε)↛1.

So although ℙX=ℙXn, i.e., the distributions are identical, the previous convergence concepts cannot catch this intimate relationship. We therefore aim at a convergence concept that expresses the idea that Xn→X if ℙXn→ℙX in some appropriate sense.

Definition 4.2.1.

Let X be a random variable and (Xn)n∈ℕ be a sequence of random variables. We say that (Xn)n∈ℕ converges in distribution to X if for any point of continuity111that is, limy→xFX⁢(y)=x x∈ℝ of FX, it holds that

limn→∞FXn⁢(x)=FX⁢(x).

We then write Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X.

Let’s have a look at the continuity requirement in the above definition. Consider the sequence Xn=1n (that is, Xn⁢(ω)=1/n for all ω∈Ω). Then Xn⁢(ω)→0≕X for any ω∈Ω, so we would certainly want Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢0 for convergence in distribution to be a meaningful concept. Since FXn⁢(x)=𝟏[1/n,∞)⁢(x) and FX=𝟏[0,∞)⁢(x), we have at the discontinuity point 0 of FX that

FXn⁢(0)=0≠1=FX⁢(0),

and therefore FXn⁢(0)↛FX⁢(0). This illustrates why we do not want to factor in discontinuity points of the limiting cdf.

We now state an equivalent and very useful alternative characterisation of convergence in distribution. We let

𝒞⁢(ℝ)≔{g:ℝ→ℝ:g⁢ continuous},𝒞b⁢(ℝ)≔{g:ℝ→ℝ:g⁢ continuous and bounded}.
Theorem 4.2.2.

We have Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X if, and only if,

∀g∈𝒞b(ℝ):𝔼[g(Xn)]⟶n→∞𝔼[g(X)].
Corollary 4.2.3 (Continuous mapping).

Let φ∈𝒞⁢(ℝ). Then,

Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X⟹φ⁢(Xn)⁢⟶𝑑⁢φ⁢(X).
Proof.

Choose an arbitrary g∈𝒞b⁢(ℝ). Since g and φ are continuous, so is g∘φ; and since g is bounded, the same is also true for g∘φ. Thus, g∘φ∈𝒞b⁢(ℝ) and Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X implies that

𝔼[g(φ(Xn)]⟶n→∞𝔼[g(φ(X)].

Since g was arbitrary, this gives φ⁢(Xn)⁢⟶𝑑⁢X. ∎

Exercise 4.2.4.

Suppose that Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X. Show that for a∈ℝ then a⁢Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢a⁢X and Xn+a⁢⟶𝑑⁢X+a.

Theorem 4.2.5.

The following hold:

  1. (i)

    Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢X⟹Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X.

  2. (ii)

    If Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢c for some constant c∈ℝ, then Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢c.

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Let x be a continuity point of FX. We need to show FXn⁢(x)⁢⟶n→∞⁢FX⁢(x). To this end, let ε>0 be arbitrarily chosen and observe that

    {X≤x−ε}∩{Xn>x}⊂{|Xn−X|>ε}, (4.4)

    which implies

    FX⁢(x−ε)=ℙ⁢(X≤x−ε) =ℙ⁢(X≤x−ε,Xn>x)+ℙ⁢(X≤x−ε,Xn≤x)
    ≤ℙ⁢(X≤x−ε,Xn>x)+ℙ⁢(Xn≤x)
    ≤ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|>ε)+FXn⁢(x) (by (4.4))

    Thus, taking n→∞ and using that by assumption ℙ⁢(|Xn−X|>ε)⁢⟶n→∞⁢0, it follows that

    FX⁢(x−ε)≤lim infn→∞FXn⁢(x),

    and thus, using that x was chosen such that FX⁢(x−)=FX⁢(x),

    FX⁢(x)=FX⁢(x−)=limε↓0FX⁢(x−ε)≤lim infn→∞FXn⁢(x).

    In the same way, we can show that

    FX⁢(x+ε)≥lim supn→∞FXn⁢(x),

    and thus by right-continuity of FX,

    FX⁢(x)=limε↓0FX⁢(x+ε)≥lim supn→∞FXn⁢(x).

    Combining both estimates,

    FX⁢(x)≤lim infn→∞FXn⁢(x)≤lim supn→∞FXn⁢(x)≤FX⁢(x),

    which implies limn→∞FXn⁢(x)=FX⁢(x).

  2. (ii)

    Fix ε>0. We have {|Xn−c|>ε}={Xn>c+ε}⊎{Xn<c−ε} and c−ε,c+ε are continuity points of FX for X≡c. Since Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢c it follows that

    ℙ⁢(|Xn−c|>ε) =ℙ⁢(Xn>c+ε)+ℙ⁢(Xn<c−ε)
    ≤1−FXn⁢(c+ε)+FXn⁢(c−ε)
    ⟶1−FX⁢(c+ε)+FX⁢(c−ε)
    =1−1+0=0,

    where we used for the last line that FX⁢(x)=𝟏[c,∞)⁢(x). Since ε>0 was arbitrary, this shows Xn⁢⟶ℙ⁢c.

∎

Theorem 4.2.6 (Slutsky’s theorem).

Let X,X1,X2,… and Y1,Y2,… be random variables on a common probability space such that Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X and Yn⁢⟶ℙ⁢c for some c∈ℝ. Then,

  1. (i)

    Xn+Yn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X+c.

  2. (ii)

    Yn⁢Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢c⁢X.

  3. (iii)

    Xn/Yn⁢𝟏{Yn≠0}⁢⟶𝑑⁢X/c if c≠0.

Remark 4.2.7.

Note that by Theorem 4.2.5, the assumption Yn⁢⟶ℙ⁢c for a constant c∈ℝ is equivalent to only requiring Yn⁢⟶𝑑⁢c. If instead Yn⁢⟶𝑑⁢Y for some random variable that is not a.s. constant, it is generally not true that Xn+Yn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X+Y.

Proof.

We only prove part (i). Let t∈ℝ be a fixed continuity point of FX+c and ε>0. Then,

FXn+Yn⁢(t) =ℙ⁢(Xn+Yn≤t)
=ℙ⁢(Xn+Yn≤t,|Yn−c|<ε)+ℙ⁢(Xn+Yn≤t,|Yn−c|≥ε)
≤ℙ⁢(Xn+Yn≤t,|Yn−c|<ε)+ℙ⁢(|Yn−c|≥ε)
≤ℙ⁢(Xn≤t−c+ε)+ℙ⁢(|Yn−c|≥ε),

and similarly,

FXn+Yn⁢(t)≥ℙ⁢(Xn≤t−c−ε)−ℙ⁢(|Yn−c|≥ε). (4.5)

Since any cdf can have at most countable discontinuities (why?), we may choose a sequence (εm)m∈ℕ, such that each of the points t−c+εm and t−c−εm are points of continuity of FX. Since Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X and Yn⁢⟶ℙ⁢c, it therefore follows that for any m∈ℕ,

lim supn→∞FXn+Yn⁢(t) ≤lim supn→∞(ℙ⁢(Xn≤t−c−εm)−ℙ⁢(|Yn−c|≥εm))
=FX⁢(t−c+εm)
=FX+c⁢(t−εm).

Taking m→∞ and using that t is a point of continuity of X+c, we obtain

lim supn→∞FXn+Yn⁢(t)≤FX+c⁢(t).

Similarly, using (4.5), it follows that

lim infn→∞FXn+Yn⁢(t)≥FX+c⁢(t).

Combining both statements yields limn→∞FXn+Yn⁢(t)=FX+c⁢(t) for the arbitrarily chosen point of continuity t and therefore Xn+Yn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X+c. ∎

Lemma 4.2.8.

Suppose that Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X for a continuous random variable X. Then, for any −∞<a≤b<∞ it holds that

ℙ⁢(Xn∈[a,b])⁢⟶n→∞⁢ℙ⁢(X∈[a,b]).
Proof.

Note that

ℙ⁢(Xn∈[a,b])=FXn⁢(b)−FXn⁢(a)⏟=ℙ⁢(Xn∈(a,b])+ℙ⁢(Xn=a).

Since X is continuous, a and b are continuity points of FX and therefore by assumption

FXn⁢(b)−FXn⁢(a)⁢⟶n→∞⁢FX⁢(b)−FX⁢(a)=ℙ⁢(X∈(a,b])⁢=FX⁢ cont.⁢ℙ⁢(X∈[a,b]).

It therefore remains to prove that ℙ⁢(Xn=a)⁢⟶n→∞⁢0. To this end let us define the tent function

φk⁢(x)≔{1+k⁢(a−x),x∈[a,a+1/k],1+k⁢(x−a),x∈[a−1/k,a),0,otherwise,x∈ℝ,k∈ℕ.

Then, for any k, φk∈𝒞b⁢(ℝ) and 𝟏{a}≤φk. Since Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X, this implies that

ℙ⁢(Xn=a)=𝔼⁢[𝟏{a}⁢(Xn)]≤𝔼⁢[φk⁢(Xn)]⁢⟶n→∞⁢𝔼⁢[φk⁢(X)],

and therefore for any k,

lim supn→∞ℙ⁢(Xn=a)≤𝔼⁢[φk⁢(X)].

Since φk⁢⟶k→∞⁢𝟏{a} pointwise and |φk|≤1, we conclude with dominated convergence and continuity of X that

lim supn→∞ℙ⁢(Xn=a)≤limk→∞𝔼⁢[φk⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[limk→∞φk⁢(X)]=ℙ⁢(X=a)=0,

which yields

limn→∞ℙ⁢(Xn=a)=lim supn→∞ℙ⁢(Xn=a)=0.

∎
