We now head towards the big result in asymptotic probability that together with the LLN forms the basis of all of asymptotic statistics. Consider an i.i.d. sample X1,…,Xn with finite variance σ2 and mean μ. Recall that the sample mean is given by X¯n≔1n⁢∑i=1nXi. By (4.2) it holds that

Var⁡(X¯n)=σ2n⟹σX¯n=σn

and by linearity 𝔼⁢[X¯n]=μ. The normalisation of X¯n is therefore given by

Zn≔X¯n−𝔼⁢[X¯n]σX¯n=X¯n−μσ/n=n⁢X¯n−μσ.
Exercise 4.2.9.

Show that if X1,…,Xn are i.i.d. with X1∼𝒩⁢(μ,σ2), the normalisation Zn satisfies Zn∼𝒩⁢(0,1).

The Central Limit Theorem now states that for arbitrary i.i.d. samples with finite second moment, the exact relationship for the standardisation of normal random variables becomes an asymptotic relationship in distribution.

Theorem 4.2.10 (Central Limit Theorem (CLT)).

Let (Xn)n∈ℕ be an i.i.d. sequence such that 𝔼⁢[|X1|2]<∞ and Var⁡(X1)>0. Let

Zn≔X¯n−𝔼⁢[X¯n]Var⁡(X¯n)=n⁢X¯n−μσ,

for μ≔𝔼⁢[X1], σ2≔Var⁡(X1). Then, for Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1), it holds that

Zn⁢⟶𝑑⁢Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1).
Remark 4.2.11.

This is often denoted as Zn⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,1), with the right hand side representing a generic standard normal random variable. If we let Yi≔(Xi−μ)/σ, then the CLT reads

n⋅Y¯n⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,1).

Thus, while the empirical mean Y¯n converges almost surely to the trivial limit 0 according to the LLN, the CLT states that scaling it by n gives convergence in distribution to a standard normal.

As for the LLN, we cannot give a full proof of the CLT in these notes, but we illustrate the argument with an object that we have already encountered: the moment generating function. A deep result on the mgf is the following.

Theorem 4.2.12 (Lévy’s continuity theorem).

Let (Yn)n∈ℕ be a sequence of random variables, whose mgfs exist in some common neighborhood (−h,h) of 0:

ψYn⁢(t)=𝔼⁢[exp⁡(t⁢Yn)]<∞,∀t∈ℝ,n∈ℕ.

Let Y be another random variable whose mgf ψY also exists on (−h,h). If

∀t∈(−h,h):ψYn(t)⟶n→∞ψY(t),

then Yn⁢⟶𝑑⁢Y.

Proof of a restricted version of the CLT.

We assume for simplicity that ψX1 exists and is twice continuously differentiable in some interval (−h,h). Let us first consider the special case μ=0,σ2=1. Let Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1). From Chapter 2 we know that ψY⁢(t)=et2/2, so that by Lévy’s continuity theorem it is enough to show

∀t∈(−h,h):ψZn(t)⟶n→∞ψZ(t),for Zn≔nX¯n=∑i=1nXin.

By Corollary 3.2.7 it holds that

ψZn⁢(t)=𝔼⁢[exp⁡(tn⁢∑i=1nXi)]=ψ∑i=1nXi⁢(t/n)=∏i=1nψXi⁢(t/n)=(ψX1⁢(tn))n. (4.6)

Let L⁢(t)≔log⁡ψX1⁢(t). Then, using the differentiability assumption on ψX1,

L⁢(0) =0
L′⁢(0) =ψX1′⁢(0)⏞=𝔼⁢[X1]ψX1⁢(0)⏟=1=𝔼⁢[X1]=0
L′′⁢(0) =ψX1′′⁢(0)⁢ψX1⁢(0)⏞=𝔼⁢[X12]−ψX1′⁢(0)2⏞=𝔼⁢[X1]2ψX1⁢(0)2=𝔼⁢[X12]−𝔼⁢[X1]2=Var⁡(X1)=1.

By (4.6), we need to show

(ψX1⁢(tn))n⁢⟶n→∞⁢ψZ⁢(t)=et2/2,t∈(−h,h),

which by taking logs is equivalent to

n⁢L⁢(tn)⁢⟶n→∞⁢t22,t∈(−h,h).

Using L’Hôpital’s rule twice and the above, we indeed get

limn→∞n⁢L⁢(tn)=limn→∞L⁢(t/n)n−1 =limn→∞−n3/2⁢t⁢L′⁢(t/n)−2⁢n−2
=limn→∞t⁢L′⁢(t/n)2⁢n−1/2
=limn→∞−n−3/2⁢t2⁢L′′⁢(t/n)−2⁢n−3/2
=t22⁢limn→∞L′′⁢(t/n)
=t22⁢L′′⁢(0)=t22.

Thus, for the special case μ=0,σ2=1 we have proved that Zn⁢⟶𝑑⁢Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1). For general μ and σ2 consider X^n≔(Xn−μ)/σ. Then, (X^n)n∈ℕ is an i.i.d. sequence with Var⁡(X^1)=1,𝔼⁢[X1^]=0, such that from above it follows

Zn=n⁢1n⁢∑i=1nXi−μσ=∑i=1nXi^n⁢⟶𝑑⁢Z∼𝒩⁢(0,1).

∎

Theorem 4.2.13 (delta method).

Let μ∈ℝ, σ>0 and g:ℝ→ℝ be a measurable function that is differentiable at μ and is such that g′⁢(μ)≠0. Suppose that (Yn)n∈ℕ is a sequence of random variables such that

n⁢Yn−μσ⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,1).

Then,

n⁢g⁢(Yn)−g⁢(μ)σ⁢g′⁢(μ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,1).
Proof.

Let

r⁢(h)≔{g⁢(μ+h)−g⁢(μ)h−g′⁢(μ),h≠00,h=0.

Then,

g⁢(Yn)−g⁢(μ)=g′⁢(μ)⁢(Yn−μ)+(Yn−μ)⁢r⁢(Yn−μ),

and therefore

n⁢g⁢(Yn)−g⁢(μ)σ⁢g′⁢(μ)=n⁢Yn−μσ+n⁢Yn−μσ⁢g′⁢(μ)⁢r⁢(Yn−μ). (4.7)

Let us show that the second term converges to zero in probability. By assumption we have

Zn:-n⁢Yn−μσ⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,1), (4.8)

and therefore Yn−μ=σ⁢n−1/2⁢Zn⁢⟶ℙ⁢0 (this follows, e.g., from Slutsky’s theorem and Theorem 4.2.5). Since g is differentiable at μ, r is a continuous function. Consequently, the continuous mapping theorem implies that

r⁢(Yn−μ)⁢⟶ℙ⁢0. (4.9)

Combining (4.8) and (4.9) with Slutsky’s theorem therefore yields

n⁢Yn−μσ⁢g′⁢(μ)⁢r⁢(Yn−μ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢0,

which by Theorem 4.2.5 also gives

n⁢Yn−μσ⁢g′⁢(μ)⁢r⁢(Yn−μ)⁢⟶ℙ⁢0.

This together with (4.7) and (4.8) finally yields

n⁢g⁢(Yn)−g⁢(μ)σ⁢g′⁢(μ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,1),

by yet another application of Slutsky’s theorem. ∎

Finally, let us also discuss the multivariate CLT, which concerns convergence in distribution of normalisations of sample means of random vectors. To this end, we need to talk about independence of random vectors and convergence in distribution of random vectors. These concepts extend straightforwardly from the univariate case.

Definition 4.2.14.
  1. (a)

    A collection of d-dimensional random vectors X1,…,Xn (that is, Xk=(Xk,1,…,Xk,d)⊤ for some random variables Xk,i) is defined to be independent, if

    ∀A∈ℬ(ℝd):ℙ(X1∈A1,…,Xn∈An)=∏i=1nℙ(Xi∈Ai).
  2. (b)

    A sequence of random vectors (Xn)n∈ℕ is defined to be independent, if for any n∈ℕ, X1,…,Xn are independent.

  3. (c)

    A sequence of d-dimensional random vectors (Xn)n∈ℕ is said to converge in distribution to a d-dimensional random vector X (denoted by Xn⁢⟶𝑑⁢X) if

    ∀φ∈𝒞b(ℝd):limn→∞𝔼[φ(Xn)]=𝔼[φ(X)],

    where

    𝒞b⁢(ℝd):-{φ:ℝd→ℝ:φ⁢ continuous and bounded}.
Theorem 4.2.15 (Multivariate CLT).

Let (Xn)n∈ℕ be an i.i.d. sequence of d-dimensional random vectors such that Σ:-ΣX1 exists and is invertible. Let X¯n:-1n⁢∑i=1nXi and μ≔𝔼⁢[X1]. Let

Zn≔ΣX¯n−1/2⁢(X¯n−𝔼⁢[X¯n])=n⁢Σ−1/2⁢(X¯n−μ).

Then, it holds that

Zn⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,𝕀d).
Remark 4.2.16.

Equivalently, we have

n⁢(X¯n−μ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢𝒩⁢(0,Σ).

The proof is a straightforward consequence of the univariate CLT and the Cramér–Wold device, which allows us to break down multivariate distributional convergence to univariate distributional convergences of linear combinations of the random vector entries.

Theorem 4.2.17 (Cramér–Wold device).

Let Z,Z1,Z2,… be d-dimensional random vectors. Then,

Zn⁢⟶𝑑⁢Z⇔∀a∈ℝd:a⊤⁢Zn⁢⟶𝑑⁢a⊤⁢Z.

Chapter 5 Fundamental concepts in inference

5.1 Introduction

Suppose that a set of n data points 𝒙={x1,…,xn} are collected in an experiment to estimate some unknown quantity. Statisticians view 𝒙 as realisations from random variables 𝑿={X1,…,Xn}. Throughout the rest of this course, we will focus on the case where X1,…,Xn are i.i.d with some distribution P. The goal of statistical inference is to learn about the data generating mechanism P, using the available sample 𝒙.

Example 5.1.1.
  • •

    Coin flipping;

  • •

    Quality control in manufacturing;

  • •

    Clinical trials for new drug efficacy;

  • •

    Language ability tests in a school;

  • •

    Tracking someone’s weight over time; (the i.i.d assumption is unlikely to be true in this case; Time series analysis is predominately concerned with statistical inference under temporal dependence, which relax the independence assumption)

  • •

    …

Remark 5.1.2.

To distinguish quantities that are deterministic and random, we mostly use lowercase letters to denote deterministic quantities, e.g. x, and uppercase letters to denote random variables, e.g. X. In particular, for deterministic quantities, we have 𝔼⁢[x]=x and Var(x)=0.

We will work under the assumption that P belongs to some statistical model that can be parameterised by some parameter θ, as defined below. Again, there are many situations where such an assumption may not be appropriate - see the course on Nonparametric Statistics for further discussions.

Definition 5.1.3 (Statistical model).

Let Θ denote the parameter space and 𝒮 denote the sample space. A statistical model is a family of probability distributions on 𝒮. A parametric statistical model is a set of distributions parametrised by θ∈Θ⊆ℝd, written as {Pθ:θ∈Θ}.

Example 5.1.4.

Some examples of statistical models

  • •

    {N⁢(θ,1):θ∈Θ=ℝ};

  • •

    {N⁢(θ,1):θ∈Θ=[−2,5]};

  • •

    {N⁢(μ,σ2⁢Id):θ=(μ,σ)∈Θ=ℝd+1};

  • •

    {Ber(θ):θ∈[0,1]}.

We shall write

X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ,θ∈Θ, (5.1)

to denote that random variables X1,…,Xn:Ω→𝒮 are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) with distribution Pθ. Recall that this means for some probability measure ℙθ on (Ω,ℱ), X1,…,Xn are i.i.d. with distribution ℙθ⁢(X−1⁢(⋅))=Pθ⁢(⋅). We shall always assume that Pθ is dominated by some (σ-finite) measure μ on 𝒮, and therefore it is equivalent to write (5.1) as

X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ,

where f⁢(x;θ)=d⁢Pθd⁢μ⁢(x). In statistics, the measure μ is often the Lebesgue measure (for continuous random variables) or the counting measure (for discrete random variables).

Definition 5.1.5 (Statistic).

Given X={X1,…,Xn}, any (measurable) function of X that does not depend on unknown quantities is called a statistic.

Remark 5.1.6.

We often use θ^n⁢(X) to denote a statistic. Statistics are computed mostly to estimate the unknown quantity θ in the data generating mechanism Pθ, and therefore we often also call it an estimator. Note that the subscript n in θ^n⁢(X) indicate that it is a function of the sample size n. Note also that it is a random variable since it depends on X which is random, whereas θ is a deterministic quantity in this course. We will explore the possibility of viewing θ as a random variable in the Bayesian Inference and Computation course.

Example 5.1.7.

Some examples of statistics

  • •

    θ^n⁢(X)=X;

  • •

    θ^n⁢(X)=1n⁢∑i=1nXi

  • •

    θ^n⁢(X)= median(X)

Most statistical problems can be identified as one of following three types:

  • •

    (Point) Estimation: Constructing θ^n⁢(X) such that for all θ∈Θ, when Xi∼Pθ, our estimator θ^n is close to θ.

  • •

    (Hypothesis) Testing: Making decisions about whether we are under the null hypothesis H0 or the alternative hypothesis H1 using some test statistic Tn⁢(X) that takes value 0 or 1. The goal is constructing Tn⁢(X) such that Tn⁢(X)=0 when H0 is true and Tn⁢(X)=1 when H1 is true, with high probability.

  • •

    Confidence sets: Finding sets or intervals (depending on the dimensionality of the parameter) Cn⁢(X) such that for α∈(0,1) we have ℙθ⁢(θ∈Cn⁢(X))≥1−α, for all θ∈Θ.

5.2 Point estimation

We consider the task of estimating the parameter θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. Given an an i.i.d. sample X1,…,Xn for a statistical model (Pθ)θ∈Θ, an estimator θ^n⁢(X1,…,Xn) is a statistic that is designed to estimate the unknown parameter of interest θ. To assess the quality of the estimator θ^n, we may consider the following quantities.

Definition 5.2.1 (Bias and mean squared error).
  1. (i)

    We call

    Bias⁡(θ^n)≔𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ

    the bias of θ^n (w.r.t. the unknown parameter θ). We say that θ^n is unbiased, if

    ∀θ∈Θ:Bias⁡(θ^n)=0.

    Note that to compute the bias, we need to compute 𝔼⁢[θ^n]=∫ℝnθ^n⁢(x1,…,xn)⁢𝑑Pθn⁢(x1,…,xn) which usually leads to a function of the unknown parameter θ. Sometimes people use 𝔼θ to emphasize the fact that the random variables have distribution Pθ, but we simply write 𝔼 as long as the source of randomness is clear. Moreover, using properties of expectation (especially linearity) can often simplify the calculation.

  2. (ii)

    We call

    MSE⁡(θ^n)≔𝔼⁢(θ^n−θ)2

    the mean squared error of θ^n (w.r.t. the unknown parameter θ). As we will show shortly, computing MSE is equivalent to computing the bias and variance of θ^n.

Example 5.2.2.

Let Pθ=𝒩⁢(θ,σ2) for θ∈ℝ and variance σ2. Let X1,X2,…,Xn be an i.i.d. sample from Pθ and define θ^n≔X¯n=∑i=1nXi/n. For any θ∈ℝ, 𝔼⁢[θ^n]=𝔼⁢[X¯n]=θ, so the sample mean X¯n is an unbiased estimator for θ. For the mean squared error, note that

𝔼⁢(θ^n−θ)2=𝔼⁢(X¯n−θ)2=𝔼⁢(X¯n−𝔼⁢(X¯n))2=Var⁢(X¯n)=σ2/n.
Lemma 5.2.3 (Bias-variance decomposition).

Let θ^n be an estimator for the unknown parameter θ of a statistical model (Pθ)θ∈Θ. It holds that

∀θ∈Θ:MSE(θ^n)=(Bias(θ^n))2+Var(θ^n).
Proof.
MSE⁡(θ^n) =𝔼⁢[|(θ^n−𝔼⁢[θ^n])+(𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ)|2]
=𝔼⁢[|θ^n−𝔼⁢[θ^n]|2]+2⁢𝔼⁢[(θ^n−𝔼⁢[θ^n])⁢(𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ)]⏟=𝔼⁢[(θ^n−𝔼⁢[θ^n])]⏟=𝔼⁢[θ^n]−𝔼⁢[θ^n]=0⁢(𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ)+𝔼⁢[|𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ|2]⏟=|𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ|2
=𝔼⁢[|θ^n−𝔼⁢[θ^n]|2]+|𝔼⁢[θ^n]−θ|2
=Var⁡(θ^n)+(Bias⁡(θ^n))2

∎

Example 5.2.4.

Let Pθ=Exp⁡(θ) for θ∈(0,∞), i.e.

f⁢(x;θ)=θ⁢e−θ⁢x,x≥0,θ>0.

Suppose n>2. Consider θ^n=1X¯n and we would like to compute its bias and mean squared error. Since X1,…,Xn are i.i.d Exp(θ), we have ∑i=1nXi has distribution Γ⁢(n,θ) (See Proposition 3.2.18) with density function fn,θ. Therefore,

𝔼⁢[1X¯n] =𝔼⁢[n∑i=1nXi]=∫0∞ny⁢fn,θ⁢(y)⁢𝑑y=∫0∞ny⁢θnΓ⁢(n)⁢yn−1⁢e−θ⁢y⁢𝑑y
=n⁢θ⁢Γ⁢(n−1)Γ⁢(n)⁢∫0∞θn−1Γ⁢(n−1)⁢yn−2⁢e−θ⁢y⁢𝑑y=nn−1⁢θ⁢∫0∞fn−1,θ⁢(y)⁢𝑑y=nn−1⁢θ.

Then we have

Bias⁢(θ^n)=nn−1⁢θ−θ=1n−1⁢θ.

We leave it as an exercise to show that

Var⁢(θ^n)=n2⁢θ2(n−1)2⁢(n−2).

Combining the results for bias and variance of θ^n, we can conclude using Lemma 5.2.3 that

MSE⁢(θ^n)=Bias⁢(θ^n)2+Var⁢(θ^n)=(1n−1⁢θ)2+n2⁢θ2(n−1)2⁢(n−2)=n+2(n−1)⁢(n−2)⁢θ2.

Bias, variance, and mean squared error are all important quantities regarding an estimator that we might be interested in. In particular, they describe different aspects of the finite-sample (non-asymptotic) behavior of an estimator. We are also interested in asymptotic properties of an estimator, which describes the behavior of an estimator as the sample size n becomes infinite. The power of asymptotic evaluation is that when we let the sample size becomes infinite, calculations simplify.

Definition 5.2.5 (Consistency and Asymptotics).
  1. 1.

    We say that θ^n is consistent, if

    ∀θ∈Θ:θ^n⟶ℙθθ(⇔∀θ∈Θ,ε>0:ℙθ(|θ^n−θ|≥ε)⟶n→∞0)
  2. 2.

    We say θ^n is mean square consistent, if

    MSE⁢(θ^n)⁢⟶n→∞⁢0,

    and θ^n is asymptotically unbiased if

    Bias⁢(θ^n)⁢⟶n→∞⁢0.
Remark 5.2.6.

Note that mean square consistent is equivalent to say θ^n⁢⟶ℒ2⁢θ by definition. However, 𝔼⁢(θ^n−θ)→0 does not imply 𝔼⁢|θ^n−θ|→0, and therefore asymptotically unbiasedness does not imply convergence in ℒ1.

Proposition 5.2.7.

Let (θ^n)n∈ℕ be a sequence of estimators for the unknown parameter θ of a statistical model (Pθ)θ∈Θ. If MSE⁡(θ^n)⁢⟶n→∞⁢0 for all θ∈Θ, then (θ^n)n∈ℕ is consistent.

Proof.

It is a direct consequence of convergence in ℒ2 implies convergence in probability (Theorem 4.1.2). We repeat this proof here again. For all θ∈Θ and ε>0, Markov’s inequality gives

ℙθ⁢(|θ^n−θ|≥ε)≤𝔼⁢[|θ^n−θ|2]ε2=MSE⁡(θ^n)ε2⁢⟶n→∞⁢0.

This establishes θ^n⁢⟶ℙ⁢θ for all θ∈Θ, i.e., consistency. ∎

Example 5.2.8.

Let Pθ=𝒩⁢(0,θ2) for θ∈(0,∞) and let X1,X2,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ. Consider θ^n2≔1n⁢∑i=1nXi2, we have immediately

𝔼⁢[θ^n2]=𝔼⁢[X12]=θ2,

and therefore it is an unbiased estimator for θ2. Moreover, since θ2<∞, by the strong LLN, for any θ2∈(0,∞) it holds that θ^n2⁢⟶a.s.⁢θ2 and therefore also θ^n2⁢⟶ℙ⁢θ2, so θ^n2 is a consistent estimator for θ2.

Now, consider θ^n≔1n⁢∑i=1nXi2. By the continuous mapping theorem, it holds that

∀θ∈Θ:θ^n⟶ℙθ.

If we tried to show the consistency of θ^n for θ by computing its MSE, it would be much more difficult.

We can draw the following conclusion between various concepts introduced so far. Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ. All the statements below are regarding the parameter θ.

  • •

    If θ^n is unbiased, then it is asymptotically unbiased. The converse is not true (See Example 5.2.4).

  • •

    If θ^n is mean square consistent, then it is consistent (Proposition 5.2.7). The converse is not true.

  • •

    If θ^n is mean square consistent, then it is asymptotically unbiased.

  • •

    Asymptotically unbiased and consistency generally do not imply each other. (See exercises below).

Exercise 5.2.9.

Show that if X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Exp⁢(θ), then Xmin=min⁡{X1,…,Xn} has distribution Exp(n⁢θ). Use this to show that Tn⁢(X)=n⁢Xmin is unbiased for 1/θ, i.e. 𝔼⁢(n⁢Xmin)=1/θ. Also compute Var⁢(Tn⁢(X)) and conclude that it is not mean square consistent for 1/θ.

Given the result from the above exercise, we have for any ε>0

ℙθ(|nXmin−1/θ|>ε)≥ℙθ(nXmin−1/θ>ε)=ℙθ(Xmin>(ε+(1/θ))/n)=exp(−(θε+1),

and therefore we can conclude that n⁢Xmin is an unbiased estimator for 1/θ, but it is not consistent.

Exercise 5.2.10 (*).

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ,θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, and suppose we have an estimator θ^n that is consistent and 𝔼⁢(θ^n2)≤C, for some constant C>0 and any n∈ℕ. Show that θ^n is also asymptotically unbiased.

Having discussed various desirable properties of an estimator, we will introduce a principled way of deriving estimators that enjoy some of these properties (especially from an asymptotic point of view) in the next chapter. It is known as the Maximum Likelihood Estimator (MLE).

5.3 Confidence intervals

A confidence interval is a random interval C expressed in terms of the data X1,…,Xn such that with a certain degree of confidence – that needs to be made precise – contains the unknown parameter θ.

Definition 5.3.1.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢ℙθ,θ∈Θ⊆ℝ.

  1. (i)

    A random interval Cn⁢(X)=[Ln⁢(X1,…,Xn),Un⁢(X1,…,Xn)]⊆ℝ, where Ln,Un are measurable functions, is called a (non-asymptotic) confidence interval (CI) at level 1−α∈(0,1) for θ, if ∀θ∈Θ

    ℙθ⁢(θ∈Cn⁢(X))⏟=ℙθ⁢(Ln⁢(X1,…,Xn)≤θ≤Un⁢(X1,…,Xn))≥1−α.
  2. (ii)

    We call Cn⁢(X) an asymptotic (or approximate) confidence interval for θ at level 1−α, if for ∀θ∈Θ

    limn→∞ℙθ⁢(θ∈Cn⁢(X))≥1−α.
Remark 5.3.2.
  • •

    It is important to stress that the confidence interval Cn⁢(X) is a random quantity and the parameter θ is fixed (non-random)! The correct interpretation of CIs is that if we construct many confidence intervals from repeated random samples, at least 100⁢(1−α)% of these intervals would contain the true parameter θ.

  • •

    Confidence intervals often requires distributional properties of some estimator for θ to be understood. It is typically difficult to characterize the distribution of some estimator for every finite n, but their limiting distributions are often easier to obtain thanks to results like CLT and Delta method (Theorem 4.2.13). Under the same statistical model, CIs are often wider than asymptotic CIs, but they are valid for every finite n (hence the same non-asymptotic) whereas asymptotic CIs are only valid when n is sufficiently large.

Confidence interval for the unknown mean of a population
Example 5.3.3.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(θ,1), θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. The interval C=(−∞,∞) is a CI at level 1−α for any α∈(0,1), but it is useless in the sense that it does not help us infer anything about θ. In general, for a given α, we are interested in finding Cn such that its length |Cn| is as small as possible. However, we shall not dive into this issue here in this course; see Section 9,3 in Casella and Berger (2024) for a complete treatment.

A more reasonable way of think about CIs is viewing it as quantifying the uncertainty of a point estimator. Consider X¯n as an estimator for θ. Then if we can show

ℙθ⁢(|X¯n−θ|≤uα)≥1−α, (5.2)

then we have [X¯n−uα,X¯n+uα] is a CI for θ at level 1−α. Indeed, if (5.2) is true, then we have

ℙθ⁢(X¯n−uα≤θ≤X¯n+uα)≥1−α.

In practice, we can replace X¯n with the observed data x¯n=∑i=1nxi/n, and the remaining question is to find uα such that (5.2) holds. This can be done using the fact that X¯n∼N⁢(θ,1/n) and therefore n⁢(X¯n−θ)∼N⁢(0,1)

ℙθ(|X¯n−θ|≤uα)=ℙθ(|n|X¯n−θ|≤nuα)=ℙ(|Z|≤nuα)=ℙ(−nuα<Z<nuα)=2(Φ(nuα)−1/2),

where Z∼N⁢(0,1) and Φ⁢(z)=ℙ⁢(Z≤z) is the CDF of the standard normal distribution. For the above to be greater equal than 1−α, we need

2⁢(Φ⁢(n⁢uα)−1/2)≥1−α⟹uα≥1n⁢Φ−1⁢(1−α/2).

Therefore, we conclude that

[X¯n−1n⁢Φ−1⁢(1−α/2),X¯n+1n⁢Φ−1⁢(1−α/2)],

is a CI for θ at level 1−α.

For a given value of α∈(0,1), Φ−1⁢(1−α/2) is sometimes called critical values and it can be explicitly found from the normal table (also known as the z-score table) in Table A.1. More easily, if you use R as the programming language, Φ−1⁢(1−α/2) can be found using

⬇
qnorm(1-alpha/2)

where alpha is your input value for α. Sometimes, we write z1−α/2:=Φ−1⁢(1−α/2) so that

ℙ⁢(X≤z1−α/2)=1−α/2.

To give a specific example, suppose that x={2.86,3.45,1.76,4,3.7,2.88,5.6}, then we have n=7 and x¯n=3.464. For α=0.05, Φ−1⁢(1−α/2)=1.96, and therefore, we conclude that

[X¯n−1.96n,X¯n+1.96n]≈[3.464−1.967,3.464+1.967]≈[2.724,4.204]

is a 95% CI for θ.

The same arguments used in the above example leads immediately to the following result.

Proposition 5.3.4.

If X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(θ,σ2), θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, and assume σ>0 is known. Then

Cn=[X¯n−σn⁢z1−α/2,X¯n+σn⁢z1−α/2],

is a CI for θ at level 1−α.

Example 5.3.5.

In the example above, the key step in deriving the CI for θ is that we use the distributional property of X¯n to control (5.2). Now, consider X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ, θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, with 𝔼⁢(X1)=θ and Var⁢(X1)=σ2. We assume σ>0 is known. Even if we do not know the distribution of X¯n, we can still show

[X¯n−1.96⁢σn,X¯n+1.96⁢σn]

is an asymptotic 95% CI for θ by using CLT and Lemma 4.2.8. Indeed, we have n⁢X¯n−θσ⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1) by CLT, and therefore

ℙθ⁢(n⁢X¯n−θσ∈[−z,z])⁢⟶n→∞⁢2⁢Φ⁢(z)−1,

and choosing z=z1−α/2=Φ−1⁢(1−α/2) gives an asymptotic CI for θ at level 1−α as

Cn=[X¯n−σn⁢z1−α/2,X¯n+σn⁢z1−α/2].

Further choosing α=0.05 leads to an asymptotic 95% CI for θ.

Exercise 5.3.6.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ, θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, with 𝔼⁢(X1)=θ and Var⁢(X1)=1.Then, for any α∈(0,1),

Cn⁢(X)≔[X¯n−1α⁢n,X¯n+1α⁢n],

is an 1−α confidence interval for the unknown mean θ.

Note that the size difference between the asymptotic confidence intervals Cn from Example 5.3.5 and the non-asymptotic confidence intervals from Exercise 5.3.6 – denoted for the moment by C~n – can be large. E.g., for the typical choice α=0.05, we |C~n|≈8.94⁢n−1/2. On the other hand, for the same choice of α, |Cn|=3.92⁢σ⁢n−1/2. Keep in mind however that Cn only guarantees an asymptotic 1−α coverage and is therefore only useful for sufficiently large sample sizes, whereas C~n gives a 1−α coverage in probability for any finite sample size n.

Asymptotic normality and CI in the case of unknown variance

As we saw above, a common way to establish asymptotic CIs for θ is by showing some estimator θ^n has an asymptotic normal distribution, as defined below.

Definition 5.3.7.

Let (Pθ)θ∈Θ be a statistical model with parameter space Θ⊆ℝ. We say an estimator θ^n is asymptotically normal if, for some σn→0 as n→∞,

θ^n−θσn⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1).

If σn=σ/n, for some σ>0, then we say θ^n is asymptotically normal with asymptotic variance σ2, since in this case

n⁢(θ^n−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,σ2)
Exercise 5.3.8.

Given a statistical model (Pθ)θ∈Θ and an asymptotically normal estimator θ^n with known σn→0, show that the interval

Cn=[θ^n−σn⁢z1−α/2,θ^n+σn⁢z1−α/2]

is an asymptotic confidence interval (CI) for θ at level 1−α.

Proposition 5.3.9.

If θ^n is asymptotically normal, as defined above, then it is also consistent for θ, i.e. θ^n⁢⟶ℙ⁢θ. If, in addition, 𝔼⁢(θ^n2)<∞ for all n∈ℕ, then θ^n is also asymptotically unbiased.

Proof.

Since σn→0 as n→∞, by Slutsky’s theorem, we have

σn⋅θ^n−θσn⁢⟶𝑑⁢0⟹θ^n−θ⁢⟶ℙ⁢0⇔θ^n⁢⟶ℙ⁢θ.

The second part of proof follows from exercise 5.2.10. ∎

Example 5.3.10.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ, θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, with 𝔼⁢(X1)=θ and Var⁢(X1)=σ2, but with unknown σ>0. CLT shows θ^n=X¯n is asymptotically normal with σn=σ/n, i.e.

n⁢X¯n−θσ⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1).

From Exercise 5.3.8, we have

[X¯n−σn⁢z1−α/2,X¯n+σn⁢z1−α/2]

is an asymptotic CI for θ at level 1−α. In practice, we often do not know the value of σ and it has to be estimated using the data. However, as long as we have a consistent estimator for σ, i.e. σ^n⁢⟶𝑃⁢σ then

[X¯n−σ^nn⁢z1−α/2,X¯n+σ^nn⁢z1−α/2]

is again an asymptotic CI for θ at level 1−α. This is because we actually have

n⁢X¯n−θσ^n=n⁢X¯n−θσ⁢σσ^n⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1),

due to Slutsky’s theorem, where σσ^n⁢⟶ℙ⁢1 can seen by applying continuous mapping theorem to σ^n⁢⟶𝑃⁢σ.

Chapter 6 Maximum Likelihood Estimation

The construction of estimators for individual problems is made much simpler by the existence of some general techniques for doing so. One of the most widely used approaches in statistics centers around the likelihood function.

6.1 Likelihood function and maximum likelihood estimator (MLE)

Definition 6.1.1.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ. The likelihood function is defined as

L⁢(θ;X):=∏i=1nf⁢(Xi;θ),

and the log-likelihood function is defined as

l⁢(θ;X):=log⁡L⁢(θ;X)=∑i=1nlog⁡f⁢(Xi;θ).

The maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) is defined as

θ^M⁢L⁢E⁢(X):=arg⁢maxθ∈Θ⁡L⁢(θ;X)=arg⁢maxθ∈Θ⁡l⁢(θ;X).
Remark 6.1.2.
  • •

    Suppose we observed x=(x1,…,xn) as the realisations of X=(X1,…,Xn). Then, we call L⁢(θ;x):=∏i=1nf⁢(xi;θ) the observed likelihood function, l⁢(θ;x):=log⁡L⁢(θ;x) the observed log-likelihood function, and θ^M⁢L⁢E⁢(x):=arg⁢maxθ∈Θ⁡L⁢(θ;x) the maximum likelihood estimate. These quantities are fixed and can computed once the actual data x=(x1,…,xn) is given.

  • •

    Both the L⁢(θ;X) and l⁢(θ;X) should be viewed as a function of θ, and MLE is the maximiser of both functions in θ.

  • •

    L⁢(θ;X) is not a pdf/pmf for θ and in particular ∫ΘL⁢(θ;X)⁢𝑑θ≠1.

  • •

    Finding MLE is essentially an optimisation problem. MLE may not exist and it may not be unique, depending on the complexity of the statistical model {f⁢(x,θ),θ∈Θ}. However, we shall later implicitly assume a set of regularity conditions that avoids such issues so that MLE exists and is unique.

  • •

    Note that, by definition, θ^M⁢L⁢E⁢(X)∈Θ, i.e. the estimator always belongs to the parameter space.

  • •

    We note that θ^M⁢L⁢E⁢(X) is a random variable with distribution depending on f⁢(x,θ), so we will be interested in studying the statistical properties of θ^M⁢L⁢E⁢(x), e.g. bias, consistency, and asymptotic normality.

  • •

    MLE usually turns out to be quite intuitive if there is a clear interpretation of the parameter that you try to estimate. It gives a principled way to obtain point estimation and confidence intervals when the statistical model becomes more complex, and it also enjoys several desirable statistical properties.

One could view the definition of likelihood function as the joint pdf/pmf of X1,…,Xn and it takes the product form due to our assumption that they are independent. This view also leads to the following motivation for MLE:

If L⁢(θ1;X)>L⁢(θ2;X) (equivalently, if l⁢(θ1;X)>l⁢(θ2;X)), then θ1 is more likely to have been responsible for producing the observed X1,…,Xn. In other words, f⁢(x;θ1) is a better model than f⁢(x;θ2) in terms of how well it fits the observed data.

One can extend the definition of Likelihood function to allow dependence as well as change in distribution. The simplest extension is perhaps to the case where the data are independent but not identically distributed. A prominent example of this case is the linear regression problem.

Example 6.1.3.

Suppose that Yi=xi⊤⁢β+εi,i=1,…,n, where εi⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(0,σ2) with known σ>0, and xi∈ℝd is assumed to be known and fixed/deterministic/non-random. The parameter β∈Rd is the regression coefficient. Using properties of Gaussian random variables, we have

Yi∼N⁢(xi⊤⁢β,σ2),

and they are independent. Therefore, the likelihood function, or joint pdf of Y=(Y1,…,Yn), in this case is

L⁢(β;Y,x)=∏i=1n12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−12⁢σ2⁢(Yi−xi⊤⁢β)2),

and the MLE for β can be found as

β^M⁢L⁢E⁢(Y,x)=arg⁢maxβ∈ℝd⁡L⁢(β;Y,x)

The following exercise shows that the MLE for β in a regression problem can be obtained by a method known commonly as the least square method.

Exercise 6.1.4.

Suppose that Yi=xi⊤⁢β+εi,i=1,…,n, where εi⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(0,σ2) with known σ>0, and xi∈ℝd is assumed to be known and fixed/deterministic/non-random. Show that the MLE for β coincides with

β^⁢(Y,x):=arg⁢minβ∈ℝd⁢∑i=1n(Yi−xi⊤⁢β)2,

i.e. β^M⁢L⁢E⁢(Y,x)=β^⁢(Y,x). Find β^⁢(Y,x) explicitly by solving the above optimization problem, assuming ∑i=1nxi⁢xi⊤ is invertible.

6.2 Examples

Example 6.2.1.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), where

f⁢(x;θ)=12⁢π⁢exp⁡(−(x−θ)2/2),x∈ℝ,θ∈ℝ.

Now, the likelihood function is

L⁢(θ;X)=(12⁢π)n⁢exp⁡(−12⁢∑i=1n(Xi−θ)2),

and the log-likelihood function is

l⁢(θ;X)=−n⁢log⁡(2⁢π)−12⁢∑i=1n(Xi−θ)2.

To find the maximiser of l⁢(θ;X), we first compute ∂l∂θ and set it to zero to find stationary points:

∂l⁢(θ;X)∂θ=∑i=1n(Xi−θ)=0⟹θ^n=X¯n.

To conclude θ^n is indeed the global maximiser, we can take the second derivative

∂2l⁢(θ;X)∂θ2=−n<0.

Note that f⁢(x;θ) is actually the density function of N⁢(θ,1). Now that we have established X¯n is MLE for θ, we consider some statistical properties of it

  • •

    Bias(X¯n) = 𝔼⁢(X¯n−θ)=0, Var(X¯n)=1/n, MSE(X¯n)=1/n.

  • •

    X¯n is consistent and asymptotically unbiased for θ since it is mean square consistent for θ.

  • •

    Since X¯n∼N⁢(θ,1/n), we have X¯n is asymptotically normal with σn=1/n. As a result, by Exercise 5.3.8, we have [X¯n−z1−α/2n,X¯n+z1−α/2n] is an asymptotic CI for θ at level 1−α. (Alternatively, one can directly use the arguments in Example 5.3.3 to see this is in fact a non-asymptotic CI)

Example 6.2.2.

Suppose that X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), where θ=(μ,σ) and

f⁢(x;μ,σ)=12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−(x−μ)2/(2⁢σ2)),x∈ℝ,μ∈ℝ,σ>0.

We consider the case where both μ and σ are unknown and therefore, both of them need to be estimated. The likelihood function is

L⁢(μ,σ;X)=(12⁢π⁢σ)n⁢exp⁡(−12⁢σ2⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2)

and the log-likelihood is

l⁢(μ,σ;X)=−n⁢log⁡(2⁢π⁢σ)−12⁢σ2⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2.

To find MLE for μ and σ, we first take partial derivative to find the stationary point (μ^n,σ^n) of l⁢(μ,σ;X):

∂l∂μ=1σ2⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ)=0,∂l∂σ=−nσ+1σ3⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2=0

Solving these equations leads to

μ^n=X¯n,σ^n2=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2.

Now, we must check this stationary point (μ^n,σ^n) is indeed the global maximum. There are many arguments one can use to justify it. One simple argument would be noticing that for any μ≠X¯n

∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2>∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2.

Therefore, for any σ>0,

l⁢(μ^n,σ;X)≥l⁢(μ,σ;X),

and it just remains to verify l⁢(μ^n,σ;X) achieves its global maximum at σ^n. Taking the second derivative

∂2∂(σ)2⁢l⁢(μ^n,σ^n)=∂∂σ⁢∂∂σ⁢l⁢(μ,σ)|μ=μ^n,σ=σ^n=−2⁢nσ^n2<0,

we can conclude that (μ^n,σ^n) is indeed the global maximum and hence the MLE for θ=(μ,σ).

A more direct approach to verify (μ^n,σ^n) is the MLE involves computing the Hessian matrix. We leave that as an exercise. Now, let’s consider some statistical properties of the MLE (μ^n,σ^n) .

Asymptotic confidence interval for μ:

Recall from Proposition 5.3.4, a CI for μ at level 1−α is

[X¯n−σn⁢z1−α/2,X¯n+σn⁢z1−α/2],

when σ is known. We also have shown in Example 5.3.10 that if we have a consistent estimator for σ, then we can just replace σ in the above CI by its estimator. To that end, we need to study the properties of σ^n2. The following identity is useful:

σ^n2=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2=1n⁢∑i=1nXi2−X¯n2.

Now, by SLLN and continuous mapping theorem, we have

1n⁢∑i=1nXi2⁢⟶a.s.⁢𝔼⁢[X12],X¯n2⁢⟶a.s.⁢𝔼⁢[X1]2,

Hence,

σ^n2⁢⟶a.s.⁢𝔼⁢[X12]−𝔼⁢[X1]2=σ2⟹σ^n⁢⟶ℙ⁢σ.

Now that we have found a consistent estimator for σ, we can conclude

[X¯n−σ^nn⁢z1−α/2,X¯n+σ^nn⁢z1−α/2],

is an asymptotic CI for μ at level 1−α, when σ is unknown, where σ^n=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2.

We note that a non-asymptotic CI for μ can be constructed by introducing the student’s t distribution. We will discuss this later in the course in the context of hypothesis testing.

Confidence interval for σ2:

To construct a (non-asymptotic) confidence interval for σ, we need to understand the distribution of σ^2. We state the result directly. For a proof of this result, search Cochran’s theorem.

Theorem 6.2.3.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2), then

∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2σ2∼χn−12.

To see this result intuitively, we note the following identity

∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2σ2=∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2σ2−n⁢(X¯n−μ)2σ2∼χn2−χ12,

the key calculation is to argue X¯n and ∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2 are independent.

Note that Theorem 6.2.3 implies

n⁢σ^n2σ2∼χn−12,

which leads to the following CI for σ2.

Corollary 6.2.4.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2), σ^n2=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2. Given the critical values χn−1,α/22 and χn−1,1−α/22, a confidence interval for σ2 at level 1−α is

[n⁢σ^n2χn−1,1−α/22,n⁢σ^n2χn−1,α/22]

The specific values of χn−1,1−α/22 and χn−1,α/22 can be obtain from R using the command

⬇
qchisq(1-alpha/2, n-1), qchisq(alpha/2, n-1),

respectively.

Proof.

Since n⁢σ^n2σ2∼χn−12, we know

ℙ⁢(χn−1,α/22≤n⁢σ^n2σ2≤χn−1,1−α/22)≥1−α,

by the definition of χn−1,α/22 and χn−1,1−α/22. Simply rewriting the inequalities inside the probability gives

ℙ⁢(n⁢σ^n2χn−1,1−α/22≤σ2≤n⁢σ^n2χn−1,α/22)≥1−α.

∎

In fact, we can immediately see from the proof above,

[n⁢σ^n2χn−1,1−α/22,n⁢σ^n2χn−1,α/22]

is a CI for σ at level 1−α, since ⋅ is an increasing function. This is simple because our CI for σ2 is non-asymptotic. We shall see later that using asymptotic arguments, one need to resort to Delta method (Theorem 4.2.13) to derive asymptotic CI for σ.

The notion of sample variance:

Finally, we discuss another important terminology used widely in statistics - sample variance. To motivate it, we observe that since n⁢σ^n2σ2∼χn−12, we have

𝔼⁢(σ^n2)=n−1n⁢σ2,

using the property that 𝔼⁢(W)=k, if W∼χk2. This shows MLE are not necessarily unbiased. We easily construct an unbiased estimator for σ2 based on σ^n2. Indeed, we have

𝔼⁢(nn−1⁢σ^n2)=𝔼⁢(1n−1⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2)=σ2,

and this means S2:=1n−1⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2 is unbiased for σ2. We call S2 the sample variance essentially due to its unbiasedness.

Example 6.2.5.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), where

f⁢(x;θ)=θ⁢e−θ⁢x,x>0,θ>0.

Thus, we have:

L⁢(θ;X)=θn⁢e−θ⁢∑i=1nXi,l⁢(θ;X)=n⁢log⁡(θ)−θ⁢∑i=1nXi

To find the maximiser of l⁢(θ;X), we can first compute ∂l∂θ and set it to zero to find stationary points:

∂l⁢(θ)∂θ=nθ−∑i=1nXi=0⟹θ^n=1X¯n.

where X¯n denotes the sample mean. To verify the above θ^n indeed achieves maximum, we check

∂2l∂θ2=−nθ2<0,

which concludes that θ^n=1X¯ is the MLE. We studied its properties in Example 5.2.4 and we showed that

  • •

    Bias(θ^n)=1n−1θ, MSE(θ^n)=n+2(n−1)⁢(n−2)⁢θ2→0, as n→∞. Therefore θ^n is asymptotically unbiased but not unbiased for any finite n. It is consistent since it is mean square consistent.

  • •

    We can actually show that n⁢(θ^n−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,θ2) using Delta method (Theorem 4.2.13) - check this yourself! We will present some more general arguments later on.

Exercise 6.2.6.

Suppose we observe actual data x={x1,…,xn} and decide to model them by X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Ber⁢(p), where p∈(0,1).

(1) Write down the likelihood function and find the MLE for p.

(2) Construct an asymptotic confidence interval for p at level 1−α using the value Φ−1⁢(1−α/2), where Φ is the CDF for N⁢(0,1), and justify your construction.

(3) Suppose the actual data we observe is x={1,0,1,1,1,0,0,1,0}. Write down an asymptotic confidence interval for p at level 0.95 based on your answer to (2).

Exercise 6.2.7.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), where

f⁢(x;θ)=1θ,x∈[0,θ],θ>0.

(1) Write down the likelihood function. Show that the MLE for θ is θ^n=X(n)=max⁡{X1,…,Xn}.

(2) Show that

n⁢(θ−θ^n)⁢⟶𝑑⁢Exp⁢(1/θ).

(This is in fact a purely probability exercise, but it demonstrates the fact that not all MLEs are asymptotically normal, i.e. some regularity conditions are required for asymptotically normality of MLE to hold!).

Exercise 6.2.8.

Suppose that X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), where θ=(μ,σ) and

f⁢(x;μ,σ)=12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−(x−μ)2/(2⁢σ2)),x∈ℝ,μ∈ℝ,σ>0.

Verify that μ^=X¯n and σ^=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2 are the MLE for μ and σ, respectively, by showing that the Hessian matrix is negative definite at (μ^,σ^). This is the multivariate version of the second derivative test. Hint: this requires computing

∂2l⁢(μ,σ;X)∂μ2,∂2l⁢(μ,σ;X)∂(σ)2,∂2l⁢(μ,σ;X)∂μ⁢∂σ,

where l⁢(μ,σ;X) is the log-likelihood function.

6.3 Properties of MLE

6.3.1 Invariance - we did not cover this in the lecture so this subsection on invariance is not examinable

Now, suppose that we are interested in estimating a function of θ, denoted by τ=g⁢(θ). If g is one-to-one (known as bijective), then we can define the likelihood function for τ by replacing θ in L⁢(θ;X) by g−1⁢(θ):

L~⁢(τ;X):=L⁢(g−1⁢(τ);X).
Theorem 6.3.1 (Invariance of the MLE).

Let X1,X2,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ. Let τ=g⁢(θ) be a function of θ such that g−1 exists, i.e. g is bijective. Then, if θ^n is the MLE for θ then g⁢(θ^n) is the MLE for g⁢(θ).

Proof.

We need to show that if θ^n maximizes L⁢(θ;X), then g⁢(θ^n) maximizes L~⁢(τ;X). By the definition of L~⁢(τ;X) and the existence of g−1, we have

L~⁢(g⁢(θ^n);X)=L⁢(θ^n;X).

Hence for any other τ=g⁢(θ),

L~⁢(τ;X)=L⁢(θ;X)≤L⁢(θ^n;X)=L~⁢(g⁢(θ^n);X),

and therefore g⁢(θ^n) is the MLE for g⁢(θ). ∎

In the case where g−1 does not exist (e.g. g⁢(x)=x2), one can modify the likelihood function for τ but the conclusion of Theorem 6.3.1 still holds. (See Theorem 7.2.10 in Casella and Berger (2024))

6.3.2 Asymptotic properties

Theorem 6.3.2.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼iid⁢f⁢(x;θ), θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, and let θ^MLE be the MLE based on X=(X1,…,Xn). Assume certain regularity conditions hold, including222For a full list of assumptions; see Casella and Berger (2024), Section 10.6.2:

  • •

    {x:f⁢(x,θ)>0} is the same for all θ∈Θ.

  • •

    The log-likelihood function l⁢(θ;X) is differentiable in θ and sufficiently smooth.

  • •

    θ^MLE is the unique stationary point of l⁢(θ;X).

Then the MLE θ^MLE is consistent and asymptotically unbiased. Moreover,

n⁢(θ^MLE−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,I⁢(θ)−1),

where

I⁢(θ)=Var⁢[∂∂θ⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;θ)]=−𝔼⁢[∂2∂θ2⁢log⁡f⁢(X1,θ)].
Remark 6.3.3.
  • •

    The regularity conditions guarantee that the MLE exists and is unique. They also exclude examples like X1⁢…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Unif⁢(0,θ),θ>0, which violates asymptotic normality (See Exercise 6.2.7).

  • •

    Since θ^MLE is both asymptotically normal and consistent, we can immediately write down an asymptotic confidence interval for θ as:

    θ^M⁢L⁢E±z1−α/2⁢1n⁢I⁢(θ^M⁢L⁢E),

    assuming I⁢(θ) is continuous.

  • •

    We call

    S⁢(θ;X1):=∂∂θ⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;θ),X1∼f⁢(x;θ)

    the score function, and I⁢(θ), the variance of the score, is called the Fisher information (with sample size 1) and sometimes written as I1⁢(θ). Under the i.i.d assumption, we have

    In⁢(θ):=Var⁢(∂∂θ⁢l⁢(θ;X))=∑i=1nVar⁢(S⁢(θ;Xi))=n⁢I⁢(θ).
Lemma 6.3.4.

For any θ∈Θ, suppose X∼f⁢(x;θ), assume sufficient strong conditions on f⁢(x,θ) such that we can interchange integration and differentiation, then

𝔼⁢[S⁢(θ,X)]=0,Var⁢(S⁢(θ,X))=−𝔼⁢[∂∂θ⁢S⁢(θ,X)]
Proof.

We only prove the expectation statement, the variance part is left as an exercise. Note that

𝔼[S(θ,X)]=𝔼[∂∂θlogf(X;θ)]==𝔼[∂∂θ⁢f⁢(X;θ)f⁢(X;θ)]=∫∂∂θ⁢f⁢(x;θ)f⁢(x;θ)f(x;θ)dx=∂∂θ∫f(x;θ)dx=0.

∎

Exercise 6.3.5.

Suppose X∼f⁢(x;θ),x∈𝒳,θ∈Θ and let S⁢(θ;X)=∂∂θ⁢log⁡f⁢(X;θ). Assuming sufficient strong conditions on f⁢(x,θ) such that we can interchange integration and differentiation, we showed in lecture that For any θ∈Θ,

𝔼⁢(S⁢(θ;X))=0.

By taking derivative with respect to θ on both sides, show that

Var⁢(S⁢(θ,X))=−𝔼⁢[∂∂θ⁢S⁢(θ,X)].

Hint: You may use the identity: S⁢(θ,x)=∂∂θ⁢log⁡f⁢(x,θ)=1f⁢(x,θ)⁢∂f⁢(x,θ)∂θ,

Example 6.3.6.

Suppose that X1,…,Xn⁢∼iid⁢Ber⁢(p),p∈(0,1). We know from Exercise 6.2.6, the MLE for p is

p^MLE=X¯n.

By central limit theorem, we have

n⁢(X¯n−p)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,p⁢(1−p)).

Alternatively, we can obtain the same result using asymptotic normality of MLE by computing I⁢(p). Note that for Bernoulli random variable we have

f⁢(X1;p)=pX1⁢(1−p)1−X1.

To find I⁢(p), we first compute

∂∂p⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;p)=X1p−1−X11−p,

then we have

I⁢(p)=Var⁢(∂∂θ⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;θ))=Var⁢(X1p−1−X11−p)=Var⁢(X1−pp⁢(1−p))=1p⁢(1−p)

Hence, by Theorem 6.3.2

n⁢(X¯n−p)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,p⁢(1−p)).
Proof sketch for Theorem 6.3.2.

We only sketch the proof for asymptotic normality. Denote θ^MLE by θ^ for notation simplicity and we write θ0 for the true parameter, i.e. X1⁢…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x,θ0),θ0∈Θ. Note that the log-likelihood function is still l⁢(θ)=∑i=1nlog⁡f⁢(Xi;θ). We also write l′⁢(θ) for ∂l⁢(θ)∂θ, l′′⁢(θ) for ∂2l⁢(θ)∂θ2, l′′′⁢(θ) for ∂3l⁢(θ)∂θ3 and S′⁢(θ;X) for ∂∂θ⁢S⁢(θ;X) . Note that l′⁢(θ^)=0.

Using a Taylor expansion of l′⁢(θ) around θ0, specifically Lagrange form of the remainder, we have:

l′⁢(θ)=l′⁢(θ0)+(θ−θ0)⁢l′′⁢(θ0)+(θ−θ0)22⁢l′′′⁢(θ~),

where θ~∈[θ,θ0]. Evaluate l′⁢(θ) at θ=θ^:

0=l′⁢(θ0)+(θ^−θ0)⁢l′′⁢(θ0)+(θ^−θ0)22⁢l′′′⁢(θ~),

which is equivalent to

n⁢(θ^−θ0)=−n⁢l′⁢(θ0)l′′⁢(θ0)+12⁢(θ^−θ0)⁢l′′′⁢(θ~)=−n⋅1n⁢l′⁢(θ0)1n⁢l′′⁢(θ0)+12⁢(θ^−θ0)⁢l′′′⁢(θ~)/n

Recall that

l′⁢(θ)=∑i=1n∂∂θ⁢log⁡f⁢(θ;Xi)=∑i=1nS⁢(θ;Xi),

and l′⁢(θ0) means that we evaluate the function of l′⁢(θ) at θ=θ0 so that we have l′⁢(θ0)=∑i=1nS⁢(θ0;Xi). since Xi⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x,θ0), by Lemma 6.3.4, we have 𝔼⁢(S⁢(θ0;Xi))=0 and Var⁢(S⁢(θ0;Xi))=I⁢(θ0). Therefore, by CLT, we have

n⋅1n⁢l′⁢(θ0)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,I⁢(θ0)).

Similarly,

1n⁢l′′⁢(θ)=1n⁢∑i=1n∂2∂θ2⁢log⁡f⁢(θ;Xi)=1n⁢∑i=1n∂∂θ⁢S⁢(θ,X1)⁢⟶a.s.⁢𝔼⁢[∂∂θ⁢S⁢(θ,X1)],

since X1∼f⁢(x,θ0), 1n⁢l′′⁢(θ0)⁢⟶a.s.⁢𝔼⁢[S′⁢(θ0,X1)]=−I⁢(θ0).

Finally, we will assume it holds that the term

12⁢(θ^−θ0)⁢l′′′⁢(θ~)/n⁢⟶ℙ⁢0,

which can be shown using more involved arguments333These arguments are known as uniform law of large numbers. Note that here one cannot use continuous mapping theorem since l′′′⁢(θ;X) is a random function. Together, we apply Slutsky’s Theorem to conclude

n⁢(θ^−θ0)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1I⁢(θ0)).

∎

Theorem 6.3.7 (Multivariate version).

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼iid⁢f⁢(x;θ), θ∈Θ⊆ℝd, and let θ^MLE be the MLE based on X1,…,Xn. Define the Fisher Information matrix I⁢(θ)∈ℝd×d to be the covariance matrix of ∇θlog⁡f⁢(X1,θ), i.e.

I⁢(θ)i,j=Cov⁢[∂∂θi⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;θ),∂∂θj⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;θ)]=−𝔼⁢[∂2∂θi⁢θj⁢log⁡f⁢(X1;θ)].

Assume the same regularity conditions hold as in Theorem 6.3.2, then the MLE θ^MLE is consistent and asymptotically unbiased. Moreover,

n⁢(θ^MLE−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,I⁢(θ)−1).

Note that we again have

In⁢(θ):=Var⁢(∇θl⁢(θ;X))=∑i=1nVar⁢(∇θlog⁡f⁢(Xi,θ))=n⁢I⁢(θ).

due to the i.i.d assumption.

Example 6.3.8.

Recall the setup of Example 6.2.2, where we have X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), with θ=(μ,σ) and

f⁢(x;μ,σ)=12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−(x−μ)2/(2⁢σ2)),x∈ℝ,μ∈ℝ,σ>0.

We consider the case where both μ and σ are unknown. See the solution for Week 9 exercises where we obtain

∂2l∂μ2=−nσ2,∂2l∂(σ)2=nσ2−3σ4⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2,∂2l∂μ⁢∂σ=∂2l∂σ⁢∂μ=−2σ3⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ).

Taking expectation for each term, we have

𝔼⁢(∂2l∂μ2)=−nσ2,𝔼⁢(∂2l∂(σ)2)=−2⁢nσ2,𝔼⁢(∂2l∂μ⁢∂σ)=0

Therefore, the Fisher information matrix with sample size n is

In⁢(θ)=(nσ2002⁢nσ2,)

and

I⁢(θ)=1n⁢In⁢(θ)=(1σ2002σ2).
Exercise 6.3.9.

Suppose that Yi=xi⊤⁢β+εi,i=1,…,n, where εi⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(0,σ2) with known σ>0, and xi∈ℝd is assumed to be known and fixed/deterministic/non-random. Recall that the log-likelihood function is

l⁢(β;Y,x)=−n⁢log⁡(2⁢π⁢σ)−12⁢σ2⁢∑i=1n(Yi−xi⊤⁢β)2.

Find the Fisher information matrix In⁢(β)∈ℝd×d.

Now that we have discussed asymptotic properties of MLE. It is natural to wonder how does it compare to other potential estimators? The following result known as the Cramér-Rao lower bound shows that MLE achieves the smallest variance among all unbiased estimators, asymptotically.

Theorem 6.3.10 (Cramér-Rao lower bound).

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ⊆ℝ, under certain regularity conditions, for any unbiased estimator T⁢(X) for θ, based on X=(X1,…,Xn), it holds that

Var⁢(T⁢(X))≥1n⁢I⁢(θ).
Remark 6.3.11.
  • •

    We say an unbiased estimator based on X1,…,Xn is efficient if its variance equals the lower bound 1n⁢I⁢(θ), for any θ∈Θ. However, as this is a non-asymptotic notion, finding efficient estimators can be difficult in general.

  • •

    We can equivalently write the statement as, for any unbiased estimator T⁢(X)

    Var⁢[n⁢(T⁢(X)−θ)]≥1I⁢(θ).

    Now, compare to the asymptotic normality of MLE in Theorem 6.3.2

    n⁢(θ^MLE−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1I⁢(θ)),

    we observe that in the limit, MLE achieves the Cramér-Rao lowerbound, which is the smallest possible variance among all unbiased estimators. Therefore, MLE is said to be asymptotically efficient.

  • •

    Recall that given the asymptotically normality of MLE, we always have an asymptotic CI for θ as

    θ^MLE±z1−α/2⁢1n⁢I⁢(θ^MLE),

    which has length

    2⁢z1−α/2n⁢I⁢(θ^MLE)

    Therefore, we should expect asymptotic CI based on MLE to have the shortest length among all CIs based on asymptotically unbiased estimators.

6.3.3 Plug-in estimators and delta method

Theorem 6.3.12 (Delta method. This is a restatement of Theorem 4.2.13 for the purpose of inference).

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d.⁢f⁢(x,θ), θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. Suppose

n⁢(θ^n⁢(X)−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,σ2)

for some σ>0. Let g:ℝ→ℝ be a function that is differentiable at θ, with g′⁢(θ)≠0. Then

n⁢(g⁢(θ^n⁢(X))−g⁢(θ))⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,(g′⁢(θ))2⁢σ2).
Example 6.3.13.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d.⁢Ber⁢(p), p∈(0,1). Recall from Exercise 6.2.6, the MLE for p is p^=X¯n, and

n⁢(p^−p)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,p⁢(1−p)),

by either the CLT or by computing the Fisher information I⁢(p)=1p⁢(1−p) (See Example 6.3.6).

Now, suppose we want to estimate the log-odds

g⁢(p)=log⁡p1−p.

The derivative of g⁢(p) is

g′⁢(p)=∂∂p⁢(log⁡p−log⁡(1−p))=1p+11−p=1p⁢(1−p)≠0.

Therefore, using the plug-in estimator g⁢(p^) and applying the delta method, we obtain

n⁢(log⁡p^1−p^−g⁢(p))⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,1p⁢(1−p)).

Since p^⁢⟶ℙ⁢p by the SLLN (also the fact that almost sure convergence implies convergce in probability), then

log⁡p^1−p^±z1−α/2⁢1n⁢p^⁢(1−p^)

is an asymptotic confidence interval (CI) for g⁢(p) at level 1−α.

Theorem 6.3.14.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d.⁢f⁢(x;θ), θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. Let g be any function differentiable on Θ, and let T be any unbiased estimator for g⁢(θ) based on X=(X1,…,Xn). Then

Var⁢(T⁢(X))≥(g′⁢(θ))2n⁢I⁢(θ).
Exercise 6.3.15.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ), where

f⁢(x;θ)=θ⁢e−θ⁢x,x>0,θ>0.
  1. 1.

    Compute the Fisher information I⁢(θ).

  2. 2.

    Recall that θ^M⁢L⁢E=1/X¯n, where X¯n=∑i=1nXi/n. Using asymptotic properties of MLE, find an asymptotic CI for θ at level 1−α with the value Φ−1⁢(1−α/2), where Φ is the CDF for N⁢(0,1), and justify your construction.

  3. 3.

    Using the delta method to find an asymptotic CI for 1/θ at level 1−α with the value Φ−1⁢(1−α/2). Could the same CI be obtained without using the delta method?

Note: You may use the fact that 𝔼⁢(X1)=1/θ,Var⁢(X1)=1/θ2.

6.4 Beyond MLE

It may appear that maximum likelihood estimation has largely ‘solved’ the essential problem of learning from data that statistics is concerned with. Notably, MLEs enjoy a form of optimality in the form of asymptotic efficiency. What are some of its limitations that motivates statistical methodology beyond MLE?

In fact, there are many limitations. In particular, the assumption that we can always ”correctly” pick a statistical model is quite unrealistic. As famously said by George E. P. Box, an eminent British statistician, “all models are wrong, but some are useful”. It would therefore make sense to consider the issue of model misspecification, e.g., X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Exp⁢(θ). but we treated them as X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2).

Recall that we can view MLE as maximizing some objective function, and the objective function that we choose is the likelihood function. In the case that we are not confident about our choice of statistical model, we may pick a different objective function, perhaps motivated by some characteristics that we observed in the data. Specifically, we may consider a slightly general form of obtaining estimators via optimising some objective function M⁢(θ;X). Given X=(X1,…,Xn), X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ, consider

θ^⁢(X):=arg⁡maxθ∈Θ⁡M⁢(θ;X) (6.1)

where

M⁢(θ;X):=∑i=1nm⁢(θ;Xi).

Note that if m⁢(θ;Xi)=log⁡f⁢(Xi;θ) and , then θ^⁢(X)=θ^M⁢L⁢E⁢(X). The estimator defined by (6.1) is known as M-estimators, and in the case Θ⊆ℝ, it can be shown (Van der Vaart, 2000, Chapter 5) under some regularity conditions that

n⁢(θ^⁢(X)−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,𝔼⁢[(∂∂θ⁢m⁢(θ;X1))2](𝔼⁢[∂2∂θ2⁢m⁢(θ;X1)])2).

Note that when m⁢(θ;X1)=log⁡f⁢(X1;θ),

𝔼⁢[(∂∂θ⁢m⁢(θ;X1))2](𝔼⁢[∂2∂θ2⁢m⁢(θ;X1)])2=I⁢(θ)(I⁢(θ))2=1I⁢(θ),

that is if we manage to use the true log-likelihood function as the objective function, then we recover the Cramér-Rao lower bound. Choosing m⁢(θ;X) that is different from log⁡f⁢(X;θ) usually leads to a loss of efficiency but such a loss is usually compensated by some other benefits.

Example 6.4.1.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d.⁢N⁢(θ,1), θ∈ℝ. The MLE for θ is given by (Check this yourself!)

θ^MLE=arg⁡minθ∈ℝ⁢∑i=1n(Xi−θ)2=X¯n.

If we use m⁢(θ,Xi)=|Xi−θ| instead, then

θ^=arg⁡minθ∈ℝ⁢∑i=1n|Xi−θ|=median⁢{X1,…,Xn}.

The median estimator θ^ is not as efficient as θ^MLE if the data are indeed generated from N⁢(θ,1), but it has the benefit of being robust to outliers within the data. Therefore, it can be imagined that θ^ is much more “efficient” when the data are not normally distributed but follow a heavy-tailed distribution.

Example 6.4.2.

In the regression setting, we discussed in Exercise 6.1.4 that both MLE and ordinary least square lead to the estimator

β^MLE=arg⁡minβ∈ℝd⁢∑i=1n(Yi−xi⊤⁢β)2,

which can be solved as

β^MLE=(∑i=1nxi⁢xi⊤)−1⁢(∑i=1nxi⁢Yi),

or equivalently,

β^MLE=(X⊤⁢X)−1⁢X⊤⁢Y,

if we rewrite X=(x1⊤⋮xn⊤)∈ℝn×d and Y=(Y1⋮Yn)∈ℝn. For robustness, we can again consider

β^=arg⁡minβ∈ℝd⁢∑i=1n|Yi−xi⊤⁢β|.

Another significant limitation of MLE in regression problems is that β^MLE only exists when d<n. In modern data sets, such high dimensional data sets are very common. It turns out that if we instead use

β^lasso=arg⁡minβ∈ℝd⁡{∑i=1n(Yi−xi⊤⁢β)2+λ⁢‖β‖1},

where ‖β‖1=∑j=1d|βj|. Then β^lasso is still well-defined, even if d≫n. This estimator is called the Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO), and was proposed in Tibshirani (1996), which becomes the central object in high-dimensional statistics.

Chapter 7 Hypothesis testing

In point estimation, we focus on obtaining an estimator that is close to the true parameter and building confidence intervals based on some estimator can be seen as a way of quantifying the uncertainty of that estimator. Hypothesis testing takes a different perspective and it is about verifying certain hypothesis regarding the true parameter.

Historically, Fisher laid down the foundation of hypothesis test with the following anecdote: A colleague of Fisher claimed to be able to distinguish if in an English tea, milk was added before water (or the other way around). Fisher proposed to give her 8 cups of tea, 4 of which had milk first, and 4 of which had tea first in a random order. The point was roughly, that if she was “labeling” at random then she would have a small chance 1/(84)=1/70=0.014 of getting every cup right. She actually got them all correct, which would have happened by chance with probability 0.014. He concluded that since this probability was less that 0.05 that it was “statistically significant”.

Although the language used in the above story is not based on statistical models, it represents how the null hypothesis is usually formulated in practice. The null hypothesis, denoted by H0, is usually something that you would believe to be true unless you see very strong evidence against it. Examples include that (1) a suspect is usually assumed to innocent unless there is very strong evidence against that assumption; (2) When a new drug is developed, we may assume it is not effective unless experiment results suggest otherwise; (3) We may assume after taking this module, the students’ knowledge about statistics does not change unless the test scores suggest otherwise.

We will discuss how to make decisions based on data regarding whether to reject the null hypothesis. A very important note when interpreting the testing result is that if null hypothesis is not rejected, this does not imply it is true. Therefore, we would like to reject the null hypothesis whenever it is not true (or detect any deviation from the null) and this is essentially the role of alternative hypothesis. An alternative hypothesis, denoted by H1, is usually the complement of the null hypothesis, as implicitly assumed in the example of Fisher, although it can be anything that is different from H0. Jerzy Neyman and Egon Pearson explored the role of alternative hypothesis and developed the theoretical foundation for optimal hypothesis testing, which we shall explore later.

7.1 Testing framework and basic concepts

Suppose we are in the usual setting X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Pθ,θ∈Θ. The problem of hypothesis testing is usually formulated as

H0:θ∈Θ0v.s.H1:θ∈Θ1,

where Θ0∩Θ1=∅, but Θ0∪Θ1 is not necessarily the whole parameter space Θ. We call H0 the null hypothesis and H1 the alternative hypothesis. We say a hypothesis (either null or alternative) is simple if it specifies a specific value of θ, usually in the form of θ=θ0, for some known θ0. A hypothesis is composite if it is not simple, e.g. θ≠θ0,θ>θ0,θ∈[−θ0,2⁢θ0].

For a given testing problem, the goal is to make a choice between H0 and H1 based on some statistics Tn⁢(X)∈S, where X=(X1,…,Xn). We shall call Tn⁢(X) a test statistic and we say

ϕ⁢(X):=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)∈R}={1ifTn⁢(X)∈R0ifTn⁢(X)∉R,

a statistical test with rejection region R⊆S based on Tn⁢(X).

Example 7.1.1.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(θ,1),θ∈ℝ. Suppose we want to test

H0:θ=0v.s.H1:θ≠0.

Consider Tn⁢(X)=X¯n, then we may reject H0 if

|Tn⁢(X)|>c

for some value c>0. The test is then ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{|Tn⁢(X)|>c}, where c is a number that we need to specify. The rejection region is R=(c,∞)∪(−∞,−c), although we do not always need to write it out clearly as it can usually be inferred easily from the test ϕ⁢(X).

In the course of making a choice between H0 and H1, we are subject to two types of errors.

  • •

    Type-I error (false positive): The null hypothesis is rejected when it is true.

  • •

    Type-I error (false negative): The null hypothesis is accepted when the alternative is true.

Definition 7.1.2.

For a given test ϕ, the worst case probability of making a type-I error, supθ∈Θ0ℙθ⁢(Tn⁢(X)∈R)=supθ∈Θ0ℙθ⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1), is called the size or significance level of the test. We say a test has size α, for some α∈(0,1), if

supθ∈Θ0ℙθ⁢(Tn⁢(X)∈R)≤α,

and a test has asymptotic size α if

limn→∞supθ∈Θ0ℙθ⁢(Tn⁢(X)∈R)≤α.

Typically the rejection region will be determined by α and the distribution of Tn⁢(X) under H0. We call the distribution of Tn⁢(X) when H0 is true, the null distribution of Tn⁢(X).

The power function of a test is defined to be

β⁢(θ):=ℙθ⁢(Tn⁢(X)∈R),

and the power of a test is infθ∈Θ1β⁢(θ). We say a test has power β, if infθ∈Θ1β⁢(θ)≥β.

Note that the notion of power is naturally related to the worse case probability of making a Type-II error:

supθ∈Θ1ℙθ⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=0)=1−infθ∈Θ1ℙθ⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)=infθ∈Θ1β⁢(θ),

and having a small Type-II error is equivalent to having high power.

The general goal of hypothesis testing is to maximise β⁢(θ) for θ∈Θ1 subject to supθ∈Θ0β⁢(θ)≤α, by designing a good test ϕ. The key to control the size of a test is to find the distribution of Tn⁢(X) under H0, i.e. the null distribution.

Example 7.1.3 (Continuation from Example 7.1.1).

In Example 7.1.1, to make the test ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{|Tn⁢(X)|>c} have size α, we need to choose a critical value c such that when θ=0

ℙθ=0⁢(|X¯n|>c)≤α.

Note that under H0, i.e. θ=0, we have

n⁢(X¯n−θ)=n⁢X¯n∼N⁢(0,1),

and therefore we can pick c=z1−α/2/n to see that

ℙθ=0⁢(|X¯n|>z1−α/2/n)=α.

Hence the test

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{|X¯n|>z1−α/2/n}, (7.1)

has size α. Much like our study of confidence intervals, we can obtain exact (non-asymptotic) size control of ϕ⁢(X) because we know the distribution X¯n for every finite n. This knowledge is underpinned by the assumption that X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(θ,1). When the data do not follow normal distribution, we usually need to resort to central limit theorem and related asymptotic results to obtain an asymptotic size control.

After controlling the size of ϕ⁢(X), let’s consider the power function, i.e.

β⁢(θ)=ℙθ⁢(Tn⁢(X)∈R)=ℙθ⁢(|X¯n|>z1−α/2/n).

Note that when θ=0, this is just the probability of making a type-I error. For a general θ, we have

ℙθ⁢(|X¯n|>z1−α/2/n)=ℙθ⁢(X¯n>z1−α/2/n)+ℙθ⁢(X¯n<−z1−α/2/n).

To control the first term, we have

ℙθ⁢(X¯n>z1−α/2/n)=ℙθ⁢(n⁢(X¯n−θ)>z1−α/2−n⁢θ)=1−Φ⁢(z1−α/2−θ⁢n),

where the last inequality is due to n⁢(X¯n−θ)∼N⁢(0,1) for any θ∈ℝ and Φ⁢(x) is the CDF for N⁢(0,1). Similarly, for the second term, we have

ℙθ⁢(X¯n<−z1−α/2/n)=ℙθ⁢(n⁢(X¯n−θ)<−z1−α/2−θ⁢n)=Φ⁢(−z1−α/2−θ⁢n).

Together, we obtain the power function for ϕ⁢(X) as

β⁢(θ)=1−Φ⁢(z1−α/2−θ⁢n)+Φ⁢(−z1−α/2−θ⁢n).

We make the following remarks regarding the power function

  • •

    For θ=0, β⁢(θ)=α.

  • •

    For any given value of θ≠0, β⁢(θ)→1 as n→∞. That is, if the data generating distribution is N⁢(θ,1), then the probability that the test ϕ rejects the null hypothesis (making the right decision) will increase as the sample size increases.

  • •

    For any given value of n, β⁢(θ)→1 as |θ|→∞. That is, if we collect n data points, and assume that they are i.i.d from N⁢(θ,1), then the probability that the test ϕ rejects the null hypothesis (making the right decision) will increase as |θ| increases.

Remark 7.1.4.
  1. 1.

    The reason that we need to analyse the power function is that there are infinite number of tests that can have size α, i.e. control the probability of Type-I error to be at most α. Some of the trivial examples include ϕ1⁢(X)=0, which has size 0 and power 0, and ϕ2⁢(X)=Y, where Y∼Ber⁢(α) is a random variable that is independent of X, and it has size α, power α. Therefore, one should aim to choose a test that has the highest power among all size α tests. We will discuss this aspect in the simple vs simple testing scenario.

  2. 2.

    Now, let’s formulate the typical steps that one would take in practice to perform a hypothesis test:

    • •

      Formulate the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis(sometimes implicit) regarding some statistical model.

    • •

      Find a test statistic T⁢(X) and determine the rejection region by controlling the size at α.

    • •

      (*)Find the power function of your test. For a given value β∈(0,1), the power function can be used calculate the smallest n such that β⁢(θ)≥β for some given value of θ. It can also be used to compute {θ:β⁢(θ)≥β}.

    • •

      Collect data and perform the test as determined in the second step.

7.1.1 One-sided tests and confidence intervals

Sometime, we might be interested in a one-sided test which has a different alternative hypothesis than the one in Example 7.1.1.

Exercise 7.1.5.

Let X1⁢…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2), where σ is known. Consider the following testing problem

H0:μ=0v.s.H1:μ>0.

Show that the test

ϕ1⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{n⁢X¯n>σ⁢z1−α}

has size α. Find the power function β1⁢(μ) for ϕ1⁢(X). Show that

ϕ2⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{|n⁢X¯n|>σ⁢z1−α/2}

also has size α. Find the power function β2⁢(μ) for ϕ2⁢(X). For a given value of n, guess which is larger, β1⁢(μ) or β2⁢(μ), when μ>0?

A general way to construct a reasonable test that has size control is using confidence intervals as shown in the following theorem.

Theorem 7.1.6.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. Consider any testing problem that has H0:θ=θ0. Suppose Cn⁢(X) is a confidence interval for θ at level 1−α. Then, the test

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{θ0∉Cn⁢(X)}

has size α. If Cn⁢(X) is an asymptotic confidence interval, then ϕ⁢(X) has asymptotic size α.

Proof.

To show ϕ⁢(X) has size α, we just check when θ=θ0

ℙθ0⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)=ℙθ0⁢(θ0∉Cn⁢(X))≤α,

since ℙθ0⁢(θ0∉Cn⁢(X))≥1−α by the definition of a confidence interval. Taking the limit as n→∞ in the above equation validates the asymptotic case. ∎

Example 7.1.7.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Exp⁢(θ),θ>0. Recall from Exercise 6.3.15 that the MLE for θ is Tn⁢(X)=1/X¯n and it holds that

n⁢(Tn⁢(X)−θ)⁢⟶𝑑⁢N⁢(0,θ2),

which implies

Cn⁢(X)=[Tn⁢(X)−z1−α/2⁢Tn⁢(X)n,Tn⁢(X)+z1−α/2⁢Tn⁢(X)n]

is an asymptotic CI for θ at level 1−α. Then consider the testing problem

H0:θ=θ0v.s.H1:θ≠θ0.

with the test

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{θ0∉Cn⁢(X)}=𝟏⁢{|Tn⁢(X)−θ0|>z1−α/2⁢Tn⁢(X)n}.

To see this test has asymptotic size α, we compute under H0⁢(θ=θ0),

ℙθ0⁢(|Tn⁢(X)−θ0|>z1−α/2⁢Tn⁢(X)n)=ℙθ0⁢(|n⁢Tn⁢(X)−θ0Tn⁢(X)|>z1−α/2)→ℙ⁢(|Z|>z1−α/2)=α.

7.2 Testing in normal models

We introduce some of the common tests in this section under the assumption that the data are normally distributed. The normal assumptions are critical in deriving the null distribution of test statistics and therefore we can have non-asymptotic size control in these cases.

7.2.1 One-sample t test

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2),μ∈ℝ,σ>0, with both μ and σ unknown. Consider the testing problem:

H0:μ=μ0v.s.H1:μ≠μ0.

with the test statistic

Tn⁢(X)=n⁢X¯n−μ0S,

where S=1n−1⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2 is the sample variance. The (one-sample) t test takes the form

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{|Tn⁢(X)|>c},

where c is chosen such that the test has size α. To choose the critical value c, we need to understand the distribution of Tn⁢(X) under H0, i.e. the null distribution.

Recall that (n−1)⁢S2/σ2∼χn−12. Therefore, we have under H0,

Tn⁢(X)=n⁢X¯n−μ0S=n⁢X¯n−μ0σS/σ⁢=𝑑⁢ZW,

where Z∼N⁢(0,1) and W2∼1n−1⁢χn−12, and in fact Z and W are independent since X¯n and ∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2 are independent under the normal distribution assumption.

Definition 7.2.1.

If Z∼N⁢(0,1) and U∼χn2 and Z and U are independent, then the distribution of

ZU/n

is call the t distribution with n degree of freedom, denoted as tn.

Therefore, under H0, we have

Tn⁢(X)∼tn−1

and this null distribution suggests that choosing c=tn−1,1−α, i.e. the value such that

ℙμ0⁢(|Tn⁢(X)|>tn−1,1−α/2)=α, (7.2)

ensures the test ϕ⁢(X) has size α.

Remark 7.2.2.

More generally, for one-sided tests, e.g. H1:μ>μ0 or H1:μ<μ0. Tests ϕ1⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)>tn−1,1−α} and ϕ2⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)<−tn−1,1−α} would be preferred correspondingly.

Moreover, (7.2) actually implies a non-asymptotic CI for μ0, since

ℙμ0⁢(|Tn⁢(X)|≤tn−1,1−α/2) =ℙμ0⁢(|n⁢X¯n−μ0S|≤tn−1,1−α/2)
=ℙμ0⁢(X¯n−Sn⁢tn−1,1−α/2≤μ0≤X¯n+Sn⁢tn−1,1−α/2)=1−α

In fact, we can always obtain confidence intervals from the acceptance region of a test, as stated in the following result.

Theorem 7.2.3.

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. Consider any testing problem that has H0:θ=θ0. If the test

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)∈Rα⁢(θ0)}

has size α, then

Cn⁢(X)={θ0:Tn⁢(X)∉Rα⁢(θ0)},

is a CI for θ0 at level 1−α.

Exercise 7.2.4.

Prove the above theorem.

7.2.2 Two-Sample t Test

Many hypothesis testing problems arise in the context of comparing two sets of samples. The two-sample t test considers the following setup:

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μX,σ2) and Y1,…,Ym⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μY,σ2) with μX∈ℝ,μY∈ℝ,σ>0 all unknown. We are interested in testing

H0:μX=μYv.s.H1:μX≠μY

We shall use the following test statistic

T:=Tn,m⁢(X,Y)=X¯n−Y¯mSp⁢1n+1m

where X¯n and Y¯m are the sample means for X=(X1,…,Xn) and Y=(Y1,…,Ym), respectively, and

Sp2=(n−1)⁢SX2+(m−1)⁢SY2n+m−2=1n+m−2⁢(∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2+∑i=1m(Yi−Y¯m)2).

The test will be

ϕ⁢(X,Y)=𝟏⁢{|T|>c},

where c is chosen such that ϕ⁢(X,Y) has size α.

To choose the critical value, we need to again understand the null distribution of Tn. To that end, we write

T=X¯n−Y¯mSp⁢1n+1m=X¯n−Y¯mσ⁢1n+1m⋅σ2/Sp2.

Note that under H0, X¯n−Y¯m∼N⁢(0,σ2⁢(1/n+1/m)) and

Sp2σ2∼1n+m−2⁢χn+m−22,

since X and Y are independent. Therefore,

T⁢=𝑑⁢ZW,

where Z∼N⁢(0,1) and W2∼1n+m−2⁢χn+m−22, and that means T∼tn+m−2. Hence, choosing c=tn+m−2,1−α/2 ensures that ϕ⁢(X,Y) has size α since t distribution is symmetric.

7.3 Likelihood ratio tests

Using the duality between confidence interval and hypothesis tests, we can easily obtain tests with size control; see Theorem 7.1.6. These CIs are often obtained by the asymptotic properties of MLE. However, this approach of obtaining tests are (at least in our discussion) restricted to the case of testing a single univarite parameter, i.e. θ∈Θ⊆ℝ. In this section, we introduce a more general approach that leads to tests for general parameter spaces Θ based on likelihood ratios.

7.3.1 Simple vs simple

We start with the following simple vs simple testing problem. Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ, and we are interested in testing

H0:θ=θ0v.s.H1:θ=θ1.

Consider the test statistic

Tn⁢(X)=L⁢(θ1;X)L⁢(θ0;X),

where L⁢(θ;X)=∏i=1nf⁢(Xi;θ) is the likelihood function. The likelihood ratio test in this case is

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)>c},
Theorem 7.3.1 (Neyman-Pearson Lemma).

In the likelihood ratio test ϕ⁢(X) defined above, if c is chosen such that Pθ0⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)=α, i.e. the size of the test is equal to α, then for any other test ϕ′⁢(X) that has size α, it holds that

βϕ⁢(θ1)=Pθ1⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)≥Pθ1⁢(ϕ′⁢(X)=1)=βϕ′⁢(θ1).

In other words, ϕ⁢(X) has the highest power among all size-α tests. If the size of likelihood ratio test is asymptotically equal to α, then it has the highest power among all size-α tests asymptotically.

Proof.

We write

ℙθ1⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)−ℙθ1⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1) =𝔼θ1⁢[ϕ⁢(X)]−𝔼θ1⁢[ϕ′⁢(X)]=𝔼⁢[ϕ⁢(X)−ϕ′⁢(X)]
=∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢∏i=1nf⁢(xi;θ1)⁢d⁢x
=∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢L⁢(θ1;x)⁢𝑑x

Note that due to the size constraints

𝔼θ0⁢[ϕ⁢(X)]=α=∫ϕ⁢(x)⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⁢𝑑x,𝔼θ0⁢[ϕ′⁢(X)]=∫ϕ′⁢(x)⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⁢𝑑x≤α,

which implies

∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⁢𝑑x≥0and∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢c⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⁢𝑑x≥0 (7.3)

for any constant c>0. Now, consider the quantity

∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢(L⁢(θ1;x)−c⁢L⁢(θ0;x))⁢𝑑x,

and notice that

if ⁢L⁢(θ1;x)>c⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⟹ϕ⁢(x)=1⟹ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x)≥0,

since ϕ′⁢(x) and ϕ⁢(x) both only take value from {0,1}, and

if ⁢L⁢(θ1;x)≤c⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⟹ϕ⁢(x)=0⟹ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x)≤0.

With these two observations, we conclude that

∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢(L⁢(θ1;x)−c⁢L⁢(θ0;x))⁢𝑑x≥0.

Since

∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢c⁢L⁢(θ0;x)⁢𝑑x≥0,

from (7.3), it holds that

ℙθ1⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)−ℙθ1⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)=∫(ϕ⁢(x)−ϕ′⁢(x))⁢L⁢(θ1;x)⁢𝑑x≥0,

which is the statement that we aim to prove. ∎

Example 7.3.2.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2) with known variance σ2. We want to test:

H0:μ=μ0v.s.H1:μ=μ1,

where μ1>μ0. The likelihood ratio test statistic can be computed as

L⁢(μ0) =∏i=1nf⁢(Xi;μ0)=(12⁢π⁢σ2)n⁢exp⁡(−∑i=1n(Xi−μ0)22⁢σ2),
L⁢(μ1) =∏i=1nf⁢(Xi;μ1)=(12⁢π⁢σ2)n⁢exp⁡(−∑i=1n(Xi−μ1)22⁢σ2).
Tn⁢(X) =exp⁡(∑i=1n{(Xi−μ0)2−(Xi−μ1)2}2⁢σ2).

Since

∑i=1n{(Xi−μ0)2−(Xi−μ1)2}=−2⁢∑i=1nXi⁢(μ0−μ1)+n⁢(μ02−μ12),

We have

Tn⁢(X)=exp⁡(2⁢n⁢X¯n⁢(μ1−μ0)+n⁢(μ02−μ12)2⁢σ2).

Now the likelihood ratio test suggests that we use

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)>c},

where c is chosen to make the test has size α. However, Tn⁢(X) is a complicated function of the data and we notice that since μ1>μ0, Tn⁢(X) is an increasing function of X¯n, which implies

{Tn⁢(X)>c}⇔{X¯n>c′}.

Therefore, we can just find the value c′ and the test ϕ′⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{X¯n>c′} would be equivalent to ϕ⁢(X) with a corresponding value c, i.e. they have the same power function. Now, since under H0, X¯n∼N⁢(μ0,σ2/n), we have

ℙμ0⁢(n⁢(X¯n−μ0)σ>z1−α)=α⟹ℙμ0⁢(X¯n>μ0+σn⁢z1−α)=α.

Therefore,

ϕ′⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{X¯n>μ0+σn⁢z1−α}

has size equal to α and according to the Neyman-Pearson Lemma, it is the most power test against H1 among all size α tests.

7.3.2 Generalised likelihood ratio tests

Let X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ. In this section, we are interested in a general hypothesis testing that is beyond the simple vs simple case. In particualr, consider

H0:θ∈Θ0v.s.H1:θ∉Θ0.

The generalised likelihood ratio (GLR) statistics is defined as

Tn⁢(X)=maxθ∈Θ0⁡L⁢(θ;X)maxθ∈Θ⁡L⁢(θ;X),

where L⁢(θ;X) is the likelihood function. The GLR test is defined as

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)≤c},

where c is some value that is chosen to make ϕ⁢(X) has size α or asymptotic size α.

To compute this test statistic, we need to find two ‘MLE’s. One of them is the usual MLE, i.e. θ^=arg⁢maxθ∈Θ⁡L⁢(θ) and the other is the MLE when the parameter space is restricted to Θ0, i.e. θ^0=arg⁢maxθ∈Θ0⁡L⁢(θ). Once these two MLEs are found, the GLR statistic is just

Tn⁢(X)=L⁢(θ^0;X)L⁢(θ^;X).

Note that when H0 is a simple hypothesis, i.e. H0:θ=θ0 (which implies H1:θ≠θ0), then the GLR statistic simplifies to

Tn⁢(X)=L⁢(θ0;X)L⁢(θ^;X).
Example 7.3.3.

Suppose X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2) with known variance σ2, μ∈ℝ. We want to test:

H0:μ=μ0v.s.H1:μ≠μ0.

The likelihood function is:

L⁢(μ)=∏i=1n12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−(Xi−μ)22⁢σ2).

Under H0, which is a simple hypothesis

L⁢(μ0)=∏i=1n12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−(Xi−μ0)22⁢σ2).

Recall that the MLE of μ is μ^=X¯n=1n⁢∑i=1nXi. Thus:

L⁢(μ^)=∏i=1n12⁢π⁢σ⁢exp⁡(−(Xi−X¯n)22⁢σ2).

The GLR test statistic is:

Tn⁢(X)=L⁢(μ0)L⁢(μ^)=exp⁡(∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)22⁢σ2−∑i=1n(Xi−μ0)22⁢σ2).

Using the decomposition ∑i=1n(Xi−μ0)2=∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2+n⁢(X¯n−μ0)2, we get:

Tn⁢(X)=exp⁡(−n⁢(X¯n−μ0)22⁢σ2)

There are two ways we can find tests that are equivalent to 𝟏⁢{Tn⁢(X)≤c}, one is noticing that the function e−x2 is a decreasing function of |x|, and therefore

Tn⁢(X)≤c⇔|n⁢(X¯n−μ0)2⁢σ|≥c′.

It is sufficient to choose c′ such that the equivalent test has size α. Observe that under H0

ℙ⁢(|n⁢(X¯n−μ0)σ|≥z1−α/2)=α.

Therefore, we can use the test

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{|n⁢(X¯n−μ0)σ|≥z1−α/2},

which is equivalent to the likelihood ratio test that has size α.

Another possibility that is more general is to consider

−2⁢log⁡(Tn⁢(X))=n⁢(X¯n−μ0)2σ2.

Since the function −2⁢log⁡(x) is decreasing in x, we can equivalently reject H0 when

n⁢(X¯n−μ0)2σ2≥c′′

for some c′′. Under H0, (X¯n−μ0)/(σ/n)∼N⁢(0,1), so −2⁢log⁡(Tn⁢(X)) follows a χ12 distribution. Therefore, we have

ℙμ0⁢(n⁢(X¯n−μ0)2σ2>χ1,1−α2)=α,

and an equivalent test to the likelihood ratio test that has has size α is

𝟏⁢{n⁢(X¯n−μ0)2σ2>χ1,1−α2}.

This example also shows χ1,1−α2=(z1−α/2)2, e.g. z0.975=1.96,χ1,0.952=3.84 which can be obtained using qnorm⁢(0.975) and qchisq⁢(0.95,1) in R, respectively.

A general rule to select critical values for a GLR test to achieve asymptotic size α is stated in the following theorem.

Theorem 7.3.4 (Asymptotic property of the GLR test under H0).

Suppose that X1,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢f⁢(x;θ),θ∈Θ0, where Θ0 is the space in H0. Under some regularity conditions (similar to those required for the asymptotic properties of MLE to hold), then

−2⁢log⁡(Tn⁢(X))⁢⟶𝑑⁢χk2,

where

Tn⁢(X)=maxθ∈Θ0⁡L⁢(θ;X)maxθ∈Θ⁡L⁢(θ;X),

and k=dim⁢(Θ)−dim⁢(Θ0).

Recall that −2⁢log⁡(x) is a decreasing function in x, the above theorem shows that the test

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{−2⁢log⁡(Tn⁢(X))>χk,1−α2}

has asymptotic size α111Technically speaking, Theorem 7.3.4 only implies limn→∞ℙθ⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)=α for all θ∈Θ0. When Θ0 is a composite hypothesis, we essentially need limn→∞supθ∈Θ0ℙθ⁢(ϕ⁢(X)=1)≤α to claim it has asymptotic size α; See Definition 7.1.2. However, we ignore this difference between pointwise convergence and uniform convergence and still say that ϕ⁢(X) has asymptotic size α..

The dimension in the theorem statement can be thought as the number of free variables in the space, e.g. in Example 7.3.3

  • •

    H0:μ=μ0 can be written as H0:μ∈{μ:μ=μ0}. Since there is no free variable (the only variable μ is fixed to the value μ0), therefore dim(Θ0) = 0. The whole parameter space {μ:μ∈ℝ}={μ:μ∈(−∞,∞)} has dimension one, i.e. dim(Θ)=1.

Note that the above theorem does not apply to the simple vs simple testing problem! - this is because the proof of this theorem relies on asymptotic property of MLEs whereas in the simple vs simple testing problem, no computation of MLE is involved.

Example 7.3.5.

X1,X2,…,Xn⁢∼i.i.d⁢N⁢(μ,σ2), μ∈ℝ and σ>0. Both μ and σ are unknown. Consider

H0:μ=μ0v.s.H1:μ≠μ0.

Note that this is exactly the same setup as the one-sample t test. You will show in an exercise the t-test is equivalent to the GLR test. Let θ=(μ,σ2), since σ is unknown, the full parameter space is

Θ={(μ,σ2):−∞<μ<∞,σ2>0}

and

Θ0={(μ0,σ2):σ2>0}.

H0 is a composite hypothesis with one free variable, and therefore dimΘ0=1. Hence k=dimΘ−dimΘ0=2−1=1.

Now the likelihood is

L⁢(μ,σ2;X)=(2⁢π⁢σ2)−n2⁢exp⁡{−12⁢σ2⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ)2}.

Under H0, μ=μ0 and L⁢(μ0,σ2;X) is maximised by taking σ2 equal to

σ~2=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−μ0)2.

(Check this!) That is

maxθ∈Θ0⁡L⁢(μ0,σ2;X)=(2⁢π⁢σ~2)−n2⁢exp⁡{−n2}.

The usual unrestricted MLEs are μ^=X¯n and σ^2=1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−X¯n)2, so that

maxθ∈Θ⁡L⁢(μ,σ2;X)=(2⁢π⁢σ^2)−n2⁢exp⁡{−n2}.

Therefore the GLR statistic is

Tn⁢(X)=(σ~2σ^2)−n2,

and H0 is rejected if Tn⁢(X)≤c for some c. One way to determine the critical value is by realising that the one-sample t-test is an equivalent test and we can achieve non-asymptotic size α control. Alternatively, we can use the asymptotic property of GLR in Theorem 7.3.4, i.e. Under H0,

−2⁢log⁡(Tn⁢(X))=n⁢(log⁡(σ~2)−log⁡(σ^2))⁢⟶𝑑⁢χ2−12=χ12.

Therefore,

ϕ⁢(X)=𝟏⁢{n⁢(log⁡(σ~2)−log⁡(σ^2))>χ1,1−α2}

has asymptotic size α. ∎

We will cover the material below if there is sufficient time.

We conclude our discussion on hypothesis testing with a multinomial example. We first introduce the multinomial distribution. Recall that if Y1,…,Yn⁢∼i.i.d⁢Ber⁢(p), then Y=∑i=1nYi∼Bin⁢(n,p), where Y just counts the number of successful trials. Multinomial distribution is an extension of the binomial distribution. Suppose each trial has k distinct possible outcomes, and we independently perform n such trials. Let Xi denote the number of trials that i-th outcome occurs. We write

(X1,…,Xk)∼Multinomial⁢(n;p1,…,pk),with ⁢∑i=1kpi=1.

and it has probability mass function

P⁢(X1=x1,…,Xk=xk)=n!x1!⁢⋯⁢xk!⁢p1x1⁢p2x2⁢⋯⁢pkxk,for ⁢∑i=1kxi=n.

Note that the parameter space Θ={p1,…,pk:∑i=1kpi=1,0≤pi≤1,i=1⁢…,k} has dimension k−1, as once k−1 of the values of pi are known the remaining value is also known. Note that X1,…,Xn are not independent as ∑i=1nXi=n. Given the pmf, we may find the MLE for p1,…,pk with the constraint that ∑i=1kpi=1, i.e.

arg⁢maxp1,…,pk:∑i=1kpi=1⁡L⁢(p1,…,pk)=arg⁢maxp1,…,pk:∑i=1kpi=1⁡n!X1!⁢⋯⁢Xk!⁢p1X1⁢p2X2⁢⋯⁢pkXk

This constraint optimisation problem can be solved using the Lagrange multipliers method, i.e.

l⁢(p1,…,pk,λ):=log⁡(L⁢(p1,…,pk))+λ⁢(∑i=1kpi−1).

Setting the partial derivative with respect to each pi and λ to 0, yields

p^i=Xiλ∀i={1,…,k},∑i=1kp^i=1⟹p^i=Xin,

which are in fact the MLE for pi.

Example 7.3.6 (Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium).

Now, we consider a specific example of hypothesis testing that involves the multinomial example. At a single diallelic locus in the genome with two possible alleles A and a, any individual can have genotype A⁢A, A⁢a, or a⁢a. If we randomly select n individuals from a population, we may model the numbers of individuals with these genotypes as (XA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a)∼Multinomial⁢(n,(pA⁢A,pA⁢a,pa⁢a)).

When the alleles A and a are present in the population with proportions θ and 1−θ, then under an assumption of random mating, quantitative genetics theory predicts that pA⁢A,pA⁢a, and pa⁢a should be given by

pA⁢A=θ2,pA⁢a=2⁢θ⁢(1−θ),pa⁢a=(1−θ)2

—this is called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. In practice, we do not know θ, but we may still test the null hypothesis that Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium holds for some θ:

H0:pA⁢A=θ2,pA⁢a=2⁢θ⁢(1−θ),pa⁢a=(1−θ)2⁢for some ⁢θ∈(0,1).

and H1 is simply H0 is not true. This null hypothesis has dimension 1 (with a single free parameter θ) and the full parameter space {pA⁢A,pA⁢a,pa⁢a:pA⁢A+pA⁢a+pa⁢a=1} has dimension 2. We first find the GLR test statistic.

The multinomial likelihood is given by

L⁢(pA⁢A,pA⁢a,pa⁢a)=(nXA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a)⁢pA⁢AXA⁢A⁢pA⁢aXA⁢a⁢pa⁢aXa⁢a,

where (nXA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a)=n!XA⁢A!⁢XA⁢a!⁢Xa⁢a!. Letting p^A⁢A,p^A⁢a,p^a⁢a denote the full-model MLEs and p^0,A⁢A,p^0,A⁢a,p^0,a⁢a denote the MLE under H0, the generalized likelihood ratio is

Tn=(p^0,A⁢Ap^A⁢A)XA⁢A⁢(p^0,A⁢ap^A⁢a)XA⁢a⁢(p^0,a⁢ap^a⁢a)Xa⁢a,

so

−2⁢log⁡Tn=2⁢XA⁢A⁢log⁡p^A⁢Ap^0,A⁢A+2⁢XA⁢a⁢log⁡p^A⁢ap^0,A⁢a+2⁢Xa⁢a⁢log⁡p^a⁢ap^0,a⁢a.

The full-model MLEs are p^A⁢A=XA⁢An, p^A⁢a=XA⁢an, and p^a⁢a=Xa⁢an as discussed before this example. To find the MLEs under H0, note that under H0, the multinomial likelihood as a function of θ is

L⁢(θ)=(nXA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a)⁢(θ2)XA⁢A⁢(2⁢θ⁢(1−θ))XA⁢a⁢((1−θ)2)Xa⁢a=(nXA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a)⁢2XA⁢a⁢θ2⁢XA⁢A+XA⁢a⁢(1−θ)XA⁢a+2⁢Xa⁢a.

Maximizing the likelihood over parameters (pA⁢A,pA⁢a,pa⁢a) when H0 is true is equivalent to maximizing the above over θ. Differentiating the logarithm of the above likelihood and setting it equal to 0, we obtain the MLE

θ^=2⁢XA⁢A+XA⁢a2⁢XA⁢A+2⁢XA⁢a+2⁢Xa⁢a=2⁢XA⁢A+XA⁢a2⁢n

for θ (Check the second order derivative yourself!), which yields

p^0,A⁢A=(2⁢XA⁢A+XA⁢a2⁢n)2,
p^0,A⁢a=2⁢(2⁢XA⁢A+XA⁢a2⁢n)⁢(XA⁢a+2⁢Xa⁢a2⁢n),
p^0,a⁢a=(XA⁢a+2⁢Xa⁢a2⁢n)2.

Substituting these expressions into equation (22.1) yields the formula for −2⁢log⁡Λ in terms of the data XA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a. The difference in dimensionality of Θ0 and Θ is 2−1=1, so by the asymptotic property of the GLR test,

ϕ⁢(XA⁢A,XA⁢a,Xa⁢a)=𝟏⁢{−2⁢log⁡Tn>χ1,1−α2}

has asymptotic size-α.

As a numerical example, suppose n=1029 and XA⁢A=342, XA⁢a=500, Xa⁢a=187, and we may calculate −2⁢log⁡Λ=0.0325. Since χ1,0.952=3.84, we cannot reject H0 with a test has asymptotic size 0.05. If we choose an α>0.05, then it is easier to reject H0. One may ask what is the smallest α, such that we can reject H0 given this data. It turns out that since χ1,0.1432=0.03247, we can reject H0 at level 1−0.143=0.857, which means the probability that we wrongly H0 is as high as 0.857! The notion of the smallest α, such that we can reject H0 is known as p-value. In words, the p-value of a test is the probability of the test statistics being at least as extreme as the result actually observed, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is correct. The value of 0.014 in Fisher’s story is also an example of p-value. The notion of p-value is none-examinable, but for some technical details, see Section 2.5.

Appendix A Technical Appendix

Proof of Lemma 1.1.14.
  1. (i)

    Let (Bn)n∈ℕ be defined by

    B1 =A1
    B2 =A2∖A1
    ⋮
    Bn =An∖(A1∪⋯∪An−1).

    Clearly, this sequence is pairwise disjoint. Moreover, observe that

    An+1=(An+1∖⋃k=1nAk)∪⋃k=1nAk=Bn+1∪⋃k=1nAk,

    since (An)n is increasing. It therefore follows easily by induction that for any n∈ℕ, ⋃k=1nAk=⋃k=1nBk and therefore also ⋃n=1∞An=⋃n=1∞Bn. Consequently, using disjointness and σ-additivity, we have

    μ⁢(⋃n∈ℕAn)=μ⁢(⋃n∈ℕBn) =∑n∈ℕμ⁢(Bn)
    =limn→∞∑k=1nμ⁢(Bk)
    =limn→∞μ⁢(⋃k=1nBk)
    =limn→∞μ⁢(⋃k=1nAk)
    =limn→∞μ⁢(An),

    where the last line follows from the assumption that (An)n is increasing.

  2. (ii)

    Since An+1⊃An we have A1∖An⊂A1∖An+1. Thus, the sequence (A1∖An)n is increasing and (i) yields

    μ⁢(A1∖⋂n∈ℕAn)=μ⁢(⋃n∈ℕ(A1∖An))=limn→∞μ⁢(A1∖An)=limn→∞(μ⁢(A1)−μ⁢(An))=μ⁢(A1)−limn→∞μ⁢(An),

    where we used the assumption μ⁢(A1)<∞ for the third equality. The statement now follows from μ⁢((⋂n∈ℕAn)c)=1−μ⁢(⋂n∈ℕAn).

∎

Proof of Proposition 2.1.2.

If f is measurable, then since ℰ⊂σ⁢(ℰ)=ℬ⁢(ℝ) it holds that f−1⁢(ℰ)⊂ℬ⁢(ℝ). Conversely, suppose that f−1⁢(ℰ)⊂ℬ⁢(ℝ). Consider the family of sets

𝒞≔{B∈ℬ⁢(ℝ):f−1⁢(B)∈𝒜}.

We claim that 𝒞 is a σ-algebra over ℝ. Indeed,

  1. (i)

    ℝ∈𝒞 since f−1⁢(ℝ)=E∈𝒜;

  2. (ii)

    if B∈𝒞 then

    f−1⁢(Bc)=f−1⁢(ℝ)∖f−1⁢(B)=ℝ∖f−1⁢(B)⏟∈𝒜∈𝒜,

    since the σ-algebra 𝒜 is closed under taking complements. It follows that Bc∈𝒞 as well;

  3. (iii)

    for a sequence (Bn)n∈ℕ⊂𝒞 we have

    f−1⁢(⋃n∈ℕBn)=⋃n∈ℕf−1⁢(Bn)⏟∈𝒜∈𝒜,

    where the inclusion follows from σ-stability of a σ-algebra. Therefore, ⋃nBn∈𝒞.

We have shown that 𝒞 is a σ-algebra and by definition of 𝒞 we have ℰ⊂𝒞. Since σ⁢(ℰ) is the smallest σ-algebra containing ℰ, this entails ℬ⁢(ℝ)=σ⁢(ℰ)⊂𝒞 as desired. ∎

Proof of Proposition 3.3.2.

Linearity is not obvious from the definition that we provide for the conditional expectation and requires a deeper measure theoretic understanding that is out of scope of this module. The tower property follows from the calculation

𝔼⁢[𝔼⁢[X∣Y]]=𝔼⁢[∫ℝx⁢fX∣Y⁢(x∣Y)⁢dμ⁢(x)] =∫ℝm∫ℝx⁢fX∣Y⁢(x∣y)⁢fX⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x)⁢dν⁢(y)
=∫{fY≠0}∫ℝx⁢fX∣Y⁢(x∣y)⁢fY⁢(y)⏟=fX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢ on ⁢{y:fY⁢(y)=0}⁢dμ⁢(x)⁢dν⁢(y)
=∫ℝm+1fX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢dμ⊗ν⁢(x,y)
=1,

where we used a version of Fubini’s theorem for integrable functions, usually referred to as Tonelli’s theorem (or often also Fubini–Tonelli theorem). Finally, if X and Y are independent we have ℙ-a.s.

𝔼⁢[X∣Y]=∫ℝx⁢fX,Y⁢(x,Y)⏞=fX⁢(x)⁢fY⁢(Y)fY⁢(Y)⁢dμ⁢(x)⁢𝟏{fY⁢(Y)≠0}=∫ℝx⁢fX⁢(x)⁢dμ⁢(x)=𝔼⁢[X],

where we used ℙ⁢(fY⁢(Y)=0)=∫{y:fY⁢(y)=0}fY⁢(y)⁢dν⁢(y)=0. ∎

A.1 Borel–Cantelli lemma

Let (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) be a probability space and (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℱ be a sequence of events. We define

lim supn→∞An =⋂n=1∞⋃m=n∞Am
={ω∈Ω:∀n∈ℕ⁢∃m≥n⁢ s.t. ⁢ω∈Am}
={ω∈Ω:ω∈An⁢ for infinitely many ⁢n∈ℕ}.
Lemma A.1.1 (Borel–Cantelli).

Let (Ω,ℱ,ℙ) be a probability space and (An)n∈ℕ⊂ℱ be a sequence of events. Then,

∑n=1∞ℙ⁢(An)<∞⟹ℙ⁢(lim supn→∞An)=0.
Proof.

Let Bn=⋃m≥nAm. then, (Bn)n is decreasing, whence continuity of probability measures implies that

ℙ⁢(lim supn→∞An)=ℙ⁢(⋂n=1∞Bn)=limn→∞ℙ⁢(Bn). (A.1)

Since by assumption ∑n=1∞ℙ⁢(An)<∞, we have limn→∞∑m≥nℙ⁢(Am)=0. Monotonicity of probability measures gives

limn→∞ℙ⁢(Bn)≤limn→∞∑m≥nℙ⁢(Am)=0.

Plugging this into (A.1) yields the result. ∎

This allows to prove Lemma 4.1.6.

Proof of Lemma 4.1.6.

Let

Λ:-{limn→∞Yn=Y}.

We have to show that the given assumption implies ℙ⁢(Λ)=0, or equivalently, ℙ⁢(Λc)=1. Noting that

Λc={lim supn|Yn−Y|>0}=⋃N=1∞⋂n=1∞⋃m≥n{|Yn−Y|>1/N}=⋃N=1∞lim supn→∞{|Yn−Y|>1/N},

continuity of probability measures gives

ℙ⁢(Λc)=limN→∞ℙ⁢(lim supn→∞{|Yn−Y|>1/N}).

By assumption, for any N∈ℕ it holds that

∑n=1∞ℙ⁢(|Yn−Y|>1/N)<∞,

so Borel–Cantelli yields that for any N∈ℕ,

ℙ⁢(lim supn→∞{|Yn−Y|>1/N})=0.

This now implies ℙ⁢(Λc)=0, which finishes the proof. ∎
